When the color dice numbers don't match the white, use numbered cards to increase or decrease the color dice number. Or use your special card to reroll the color dice, change the white dice number or to change the opponents game.

After 5 rounds, the one with most points win the game, but don't forget to count the number of cards that you played during the game!

name: COMBAT: WWII
description:
A set of simple, fast, & furious World War II combat rules with features like: Minefields, Weather, Commanders, Snipers, Engineers, Paratroopers, Commandos, National Abilities, Flamethrowers, Mortars, Artillery, Tanks, Aircraft and more.

Multiple foot figures per base. Vehicles require no basing. D6 based system gameplay. IGOUGO turn sequence. Four scenarios included. Designed for use with 15mm wargaming miniatures but can be expaned for use with 25mm.

Army Lists, TOES and National Abilities for:

Union of Soviet Socialists Republics
United States
United Kingdom
France
Italy
Japan
Germany
categories: Book, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II

name: Gramopoly
description: Gramopoly is a Monopoly-style roll and move educational game about grammatical parts of speech. There are three levels of play (Beginner, Intermediate, and Advanced), and the object of the game is "to become the first player to buy each part of his sentence".

name: Phraze-It! The Game of Crazy Phrazes
description:
Phraze-It! is a game for the whole family. Players age 8 and up will love turning initials into crazy phrases.

It's easy. The judge rolls the 30-sided dice and players get three random letters. Turn over the timer and let your creativity loose, making each letter the first letter of a word in a 3-word phrase. Write your phrase...then say it aloud...with feeling! The judge draws a judgment card and determines points in multiple categories. And everyone gets a chance to be the judge!

You could get points for being first to finish...or last! You could get points for most unpronounceable phrase...or the shortest! Or maybe you had the saddest performance...or the funniest. Nobody knows what's on the judge's card until after the phrases are created.

You play in rounds. The last round can mean big bonuses. The winner is the player with the most points.

Each round is guaranteed to surprise, delight or make you laugh. After all, the sillier the phrase, the better!

Phraze-It! can be learned in minutes, played by young and old. Great for families, friends, and adults.

And it's all about letting your creativity run wild and having fun.

Source: www.lotsowattsgames.com
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Paper-and-Pencil, Variable Phase Order

name: OCCO
description:
Strategic multi-player card game featuring an original, colour-coded, 80 card, tarot based deck. Cards are imbued with "special powers" to help players formulate their plans to dominate gameplay.

A hand of seven (or eight) cards is dealt to each player. The first player to play all cards in his/her hand, "goes out" and wins the hand with zero Points. The other players count the point value of the cards they are still holding, and record them. A Game consists of five hands. Lowest score wins.

Reviving the historic gaming tradition of the Tarot, Tarocchi or Tarok that originated in Europe during the 15th Century... Alliances, Accusations, Attacks, Arguments, Bluffing, Banter, Control, Challenges and Cheating are the ABC's of OCCO. Simple to Learn, Challenging to Master, Fun for ALL AGES!
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Betting and Bluffing, Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Cooperative Game, Hand Management, Memory, Variable Player Powers

name: Klima, Wetter, Jahreszeiten: Lernquiz Geographie
description:
Climate, weather, seasons - Geography lerning trivia.

With this trivia game students can test how well they have mastered the basic knowledge on the topic and how far they have understood the key concepts of this area of geography.
For each task there are four answers to choose from - but only one is correct. Which answer is correct (and why), is shown on the backside of the card. Each player plays one of the four answer card: A,B,C or D, and all players reveal these simultanously. Then the trivia card is turned around as well to check the correct answer. Each correct answer scores a point. Player with the most points after the deck is exhausted is the winner.

name: Topographie:  Europa – Lernquiz Geographie
description:
Topography Europe - Geography lerning trivia.

With this trivia game students can test how well they have mastered the basic knowledge on the topic and how far they have understood the key concepts of this area of geography.
For each task there are four answers to choose from - but only one is correct. Which answer is correct (and why), is shown on the backside of the card. Each player plays one of the four answer card: A,B,C or D, and all players reveal these simultanously. Then the trivia card is turned around as well to check the correct answer. Each correct answer scores a point. Player with the most points after the deck is exhausted is the winner.

name: Topographie: Deutschland – Lernquiz Geographie
description:
Topography Germany - Geography lerning trivia.

With this trivia game students can test how well they have mastered the basic knowledge on the topic and how far they have understood the key concepts of this area of geography.
For each task there are four answers to choose from - but only one is correct. Which answer is correct (and why), is shown on the backside of the card. Each player plays one of the four answer card: A,B,C or D, and all players reveal these simultanously. Then the trivia card is turned around as well to check the correct answer. Each correct answer scores a point. Player with the most points after the deck is exhausted is the winner.

name: Landeskunde: Great Britain and Northern Ireland – Lernquiz Englisch
description:
Geography: Great Britain and Northern Ireland - English learning quiz

With this trivia game students can test how well they have mastered the basic knowledge on the topic and how far they have understood the key concepts of this area of geography.
For each task there are four answers to choose from - but only one is correct. Which answer is correct (and why), is shown on the backside of the card. Each player plays one of the four answer card: A,B,C or D, and all players reveal these simultanously. Then the trivia card is turned around as well to check the correct answer. Each correct answer scores a point. Player with the most points after the deck is exhausted is the winner.

name: Equals: The Number Strategy Game
description:
Players use number combinations and strategy to get rid of all their cards to win the game. The two face up active cards are added, subtracted, multiplied or divided to create "target numbers". At each turn players put down one or more number cards that add up to (or Equal) those target numbers.

There are also 8 different Action Cards that add variety, strategy, and surprises to the game. The game can last under 10 minutes if a player can get rid of the cards in just a few turns, or it can run up to about 20 minutes.

Players get better, faster and more confident with numbers just by playing Equals. This makes Equals perfect for families with children and classroom teachers.

name: LOCAL HERO !
description:
LOCAL HERO!
Devious political strategy in a box - can you stop people opening the lid on it? Grass roots politics with all the mud thrown in!

CITY HALL PROTEST! New fast paced board game based in a fictional local community, but maybe something like yours! You run your own protest group NO! NEVER! ACTION! NOW! STOP! OR NIMBY! Be the first to get 20 protest points and become a LOCAL HERO! by making your community a better place!

Based in a fictional local community, You lead your own protest group and each turn try to run the City! Each player competes to fill City Hall with their supporters and stay in control of the mob (the other players).

The player who runs the City Hall is City Leader! There can only ever be one Leader, so staying in control of the City means learning the rules and using them to your advantage! If no one player dominates City Hall then deals have to be done and undone between players about who stays in power.

Each turn players move around the board along the green belt as they protest to improve their city and have to make decisions about which other players they support. Decisions are made on the basis of facts, feelings and trust, reasoned argument or power play and determined by the number of cards players have in City Hall.

Each turn can change the number of cards a player has and so alter their influence. Players have to manoeuvre themselves between seeking power and staying true to their cause until one player has gained 20 protest points and becomes the LOCAL HERO! Points are gained by taking control of the City, time served as Leader and from doing deals with other players to get their support.

This leads to a fast paced game, players are constantly changing sides, working out who best to support, and not being corrupt. It is an exhausting game of wit, strategy, coercion and survival that brings out the best and the worst in participants!

In the end you don't just win you make the World a better place! and had an exciting evenings entertainment with family and friends.

name: Die to Live
description: Many are called but few are chosen! Who will stand and fight against the forces of darkness? Fear not, for you have been chosen by the Host of Heaven to die to yourself so others may live. In this exciting new game players are challenged to live out an ancient principle that you die to gain, and you live to die. Filled with unusual scenarios and life changing scriptures, this game turns spirituality into practicality! Is the game about luck, or is it fate, you be the judge as you become a missionary in your own backyard. Your task is to fight to win lost souls, and redeem your poverty stricken neighborhood back into a plush thriving community. As players travel around the board using dice, each person will encounter 4 types of spaces: natural, spiritual, witness, and proprty spaces. Each player's goal is to equire the most souls, buy property, and build an underground church. The player with 6 souls on one property wins and game play stops. However, achievements will be divided up amongst players (most property, most money, most souls, most property). Each space corresponds with a card. Natural cards have consequences to gain money, lose turns, etc. Spirtural cards: players read inspiring passages, play act, etc. Witness cards are the only cards players can win souls with. Players can win or lose souls depending on scenior. So put on the whole armor of God as this game will put your skills to the test! The table is set, everything’s unwrapped, and it’s game time, are you ready to die to live?
mechanics: Acting, Dice Rolling, Push Your Luck, Roll / Spin and Move

name: St. George and the Dragon
description:
St. George and the Dragon is played on a round board shaped like a wheel with 14 spokes, with a pattern of points on those lines starting from its center and radiating out to the edge of the board. Longitudinal lines are also drawn connecting the points. The central circle is green and is called the Dragon’s Lair. At four equidistant locations on the outer circle, an additional three points (connected by lines to each other and to three points on the board’s outer edge) form Knight’s Castles, one each named for St. George, St. Patrick, St. Andrew, and St. David. The Dragon’s lone piece begins the game on the Dragon’s Lair; the Knights’ three pieces each begin on the points of the Knight’s Castle.

Beginning with the Knights and ending with the Dragon, players take turns rolling a die and moving according to the results. The player will move any one of their pieces the exact number of points rolled on the die, in any combination of directions, so long as the lines between points are followed and points are not crossed or landed on a second time. Pieces cannot move to or jump over occupied points, except when the Dragon captures a Knight. Dragons move in the same fashion as Knights, but when their move ends on an occupied point, that Knight is removed from play. The Dragon may win the game by taking two of each Knight’s pieces. Knights may not capture or slay the Dragon, but may win by reaching the Dragon’s Lair central point with two of their pieces. The first Knight to do so wins the game. A Knight may not pass over the Dragon’s Lair as part of a move; they must land there only on the end of their move. Having landed on the board’s central point, the Knight is then removed from play and set behind his Castle to keep score.

The game can be played by two, three, four, or five players. For five players, one each plays a Knight and one the Dragon. For four players the game is the same but St. Patrick’s Knights are not used. For three players, one player takes the Knights of St. Andrew and St. George, one player takes St. David and St. Patrick, and one the Dragon. For two players, one will play all four Knights and the other the Dragon.

St. George and the Dragon takes its inspiration from the old tale of the same name.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Static Capture

name: The Red Queen
description:
The Red Queen is a card game pitting a team of 2 to 5 players against the infamous Queen of Hearts, a character as unpredictable as Lewis Caroll described in Alice's Adventures in Wonderland. Using deduction to work out how best to advance their plans, the team must assemble an army of soldiers to challenge the Red Queen.

In The Red Queen, the player cards are facing outwards in such a manner that all players except the one holding them will know what they are. Each round players will be able to give clues to one another to lift part of the mystery surrounding the pool of cards they collectively possess, build their army, or use special roles actions to help them in this endeavour.

... meanwhile the evil Red Queen will continually interfere with the team using a set of treacherous actions in the hope to make them lose 'heart', literraly, the currency representing the team's morale in the game. Her own army will also grow throughout the game, putting the team under pressure to raise their own as efficiently as possible.

The game features a strong thematic element and role cards based on characters directly inspired by Lewis Caroll's work. Alice herself takes on a key role too, unsurprisingly, but as an outsider will be of equal support to both sides and it is up to the players to make the most of her abilities.
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Hand Management, Variable Player Powers

name: Reign of Evil
description:
It is the year 2025 and the entire world has fallen under the reign of a group of super villains known only as "The Collective". People are oppressed and the world has fallen deep into darkness with little hope of even a glimpse of light. In this dark world, a group of superheroes has risen to combat the villains and retake the world from their grasp.

Each mission is deadly, as both villains and superheroes must enter combat, defend themselves, and collect the previous element "levinium" or face destruction. Levinium is the heroes's hope of taking down the villains.

Reign of Evil is a print-and-play game in the genre of superheroes and supervillians. The game uses a card mechanic, and no dice, in order to perform combat. It plays quickly with minimal down time for players. Players move figures around the board to collect levinium until all wound markers are exhausted, until the deck runs out, or all levinium pieces are gone. Alternatively, players can play timed games. On their turns, players draw a hand of cards that contain a mix of Move and Action cards. Using these cards, players move around the board and take various actions, such as combat or collecting levinium.
mechanics: Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Point to Point Movement

name: Epic Chess
description:
A fantasy expansion for chess, adding dice, cards, tokens, and treasure chests.

Players receive Mana tokens that may be traded to activate special abilities, cast spells, or upgrade units.

Treasure chests, scattered across the field, contain weapons, armor, potions, and accessories to boost individual pieces.

Each piece is assigned a die value (D4, D6, D8, etc.) for combat, as well as three special abilities. Pawns dig up treasure. Bishops cast healing and other protective spells. Queens send lightning bolts across the playing field. Kings inspire nearby units, and so forth.

Winning conditions are similar to traditional Chess, except that the king must be defeated in combat. Check and Check Mate simply offer bonuses to defeating the King.

Epic Chess preserves the sound strategic elements of traditional Chess, while adding many new elements for Chess players of any level to enjoy!
categories: Abstract Strategy, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy
mechanics: Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Dice Rolling, Grid Movement

name: Slaughterama!
description:
In Slaughterama, you are a vigilante hero who sets out to rid the land of evil, while also acting as clerk of your very own medieval store called a Bazaar. Traverse a unique board made up of tiles and fight a variety of demented foes. Once defeated, rob them of their treasures and use them to buy weapons and magic at opponent’s shops. There are also traps to avoid, the risk of becoming a zombie, snipers to watch out for, & magic portals that open up as the game progresses. This is a multi-player game, in fact, the more people playing...the more insane it becomes!

Slaughterama is a new, innovative table top game that is easy to learn yet quite challenging to win. There’s a good balance between luck and strategy, and the gameplay is fun NOT frustrating. With a variety of game mechanics at work, Slaughterama offers an engaging experience that is unlike anything else on the market today.

Amount of Players: 4 players (more by adding future deckpacks)

Object: Kill all 10 of the monsters in your deck before your opponents kill the ones in theirs.

Setting: A “medievalish” alternate universe where anarchy & chaos go for breakfast.

Duration: Customizable. A normal 4 player game on average takes about 90 minutes.

Game Mechanics: Dice rolling, pawn moving, simple RPG fighting system, card playing, buying/selling goods.

name: GOV'NOR!    The Dartmoor Prison Boardgame
description:
Be the first to get released from the Infamous Dartmoor Prison. Shrouded in mist and mystery! A game of twists and barbed wire turns.

THE GUV'NOR! You play rival prison gangs; the Landing Mob, the Kitchen Gang, the Gym Boyz, the Garden Crew, the Laundry Syndicate and the Library Club

Win the game by earning 20 parole points and be the first to get released!!

The game is designed by people who know what it's like, so the game has an authenticity beyond the traditional escape scenario!. In this game it's a bad move when a gang member escapes, because it weakens the gang left inside!

Players compete to gain territory across the prison map. Winners place their cards in one of the vacant cells in the block. The block makes a decision by a majority vote about who is to be The GUV"NOR. Unless one player has more than half the cells deals need to be done between players. Players then move along the track (called the perimeter wall) and where they land decides what actions take place. Actions can change the number of cards in the block, place or remove trouble cards on the prison map, or require the block to make decisions. Decisions will be determined by both the cards in the block at the time and the relationship between the players.

This game enables all members of the family to play as it provides lots of times when "I win you lose" scenarios to arise.

Simple rules means they are easily mastered and that enables more sophisticated game play as players try to use the rules to get ahead.

Further rules including challenging the leadership of the GUV'NOR - making regular decisions about who to back and what parole points to deal with and lockdown - which gives the current GUV'NOR power to make the decisions the block did, including being ale to win a leadership challenge whatever the number of cards in the block raise tension as players try to find away to either stay in control or wrestle it away from others without the wrong rivals taking control.

If no one player dominates the Block then deals have to be done between players to form packs. But trust no one. Each turn players roll a dice and move around the board along the perimiter wall as they serve their sentence and have to make decisions about who they support. Decisions are determined by the number of gang member cards they have in The Block. Each turn can change the number of cards a player has and so alter their influence. Players have to manoeuvre themselves through their sentence until one player has gained 20 parole points. Points are lost or gained by getting caught by the staff, taking control of the Block, time served and from doing deals with other players to get their support.

This leads to a fast paced game, players are constantly changing sides, working out who best to support, and not getting caught by the staff. Watch as the staff increase security, send you to solitary and threatens lockdown! It is an exhausting game of wit, strategy, coercion and survival that brings out the best and the worst in participants! In the end you don't just win you probably get rehabilitated!

The rules are designed to be interdependent, hence the block makes decisions that effect the level of security. At both extremes, ie too high or too low the scale has a trouble space. If the scale is on trouble and all of the trouble cards are placed on the map then trouble starts. this is a spontaneous battle for territory that lasts 4 turns and enables a potentially dramatic change in who runs the block. This rule, like many others provides an exciting tension where players can predict what could happen next (within the dice roll) to change who is winning or what opportunities were lost to defeat who is currently in charge.

The game is very visual, so it matters where the players pieces are along the perimeter wall, how many cards are held in the block, what bonus cards are in solitary, whether the prison is in lockdown or not, and how many trouble cards there are on the map.
mechanics: Acting, Area Majority / Influence, Cooperative Game, Simulation, Team-Based Game, Trading, Turn Order: Time Track, Voting

name: NORTH KOREA!
description:
A game where your best strategy is paranoia! Take brinkmanship to a nuclear level and control the World's most secret State!

The game is played in a fictional future North Korea. Play the leader of your own faction - THE ARMY, NAVY, AIRFORCE, BIG BUSINESS, THE PARTY AND THE FAMILY. Win by getting BRINKMANSHIP points, which reflect how good you are at manipulating your opponents and surviving as you raise the levels of international tension to nuclear levels. Win by getting to 20 points without blowing up the World

The Armed Forces, Big Business, The Party and the Family compete to fill the Central Committee with their supporters. The player who runs the Central Committee is The Leader! There can only ever be one Leader, so it is importnat to understand the rules of the game and use them to your advantage! If no one player dominates the Committee then deals have to be done. Each turn players move around the board along the demilitarised zone which runs along the perimeter of the board and have to make decisions. Decisions are determined by the number of cards they have in The Central Committee. Each turn can change the number of cards a player has and so alter their influence. Players have to manoeuvre themselves through the politics until one player has gained 20 brinkmanship points. Points are gained by taking control of the Committee, time as Leader and from doing deals with other players to get their support.

At the same time the committee decides the level of international tension. As public parades whip up popular fervour and brinkmanship is taken to a nuclear level so the opportunities for players to decide how to run the World's most secret State determine who ends up winning the game and who gets manipulated.

This leads to a fast paced game, players are constantly changing sides, working out who best to support, and not getting caught out in political exile. It is an exhausting game of wit, strategy, coercion and survival that brings out the best and the worst in participants! In the end you don't just win you have an great evening's entertainment!

Each space on the demilitarised zone offers the opportunity for the composition of central committee to change as players are beset with show trials, parades, rocket launches, 6 party peace talks and nuclear tests!

Past deals, double deals, double cross and you see where the strategy starts. Each player's strategy will be determined by their own strength of character, belief in their own destiny, how well they can manipulate others to support them and how they make best use of the opportunities as they arise.

As the game evolves so moments of growing tension occur as the population get ever more excited with increasing parades across the the Country, international tension nears extreme levels, infighting means there are no clear alliances and the date of the next central committee election approaches, only to be disrupted by a spontaneous war game! and rocket launch. Leadership crisis and mayhem. But then players only have themselves to blame as what happens is a result of the choices players make in the central committee. Ultimately players have the choice to create a peace agreement where the right strategies are promoted rather than a dash to the winning line! It is interesting to see how as a player nears the winning line that choice becomes more challenging!

As they say - Your best strategy is paranoia, take brinkmanship to a nuclear level and tale control of the Worlds most secret State!
categories: Abstract Strategy, Bluffing, Civil War, Korean War, Negotiation, Political, Territory Building
mechanics: Acting, Area Majority / Influence, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Simulation, Team-Based Game, Trading, Turn Order: Time Track

name: The Martin Luther King Jr. Game
description:
The game is labeled as suitable for ages 6 and up, and has the King estate´s approval. The Martin Luther King Jr. Centre gets royalties.

It is an educational game. They can also switch places, take extra turns if they want to.The players have to choose if they want to marry Coretta Scott, meet President Kennedy or meet Ghandhi in India.

You spin the spinner, then you can move around the 63-space board, which includes historical milestones like the birth of King, his "I have a dream speech" , his assasination or his national holiday.
Some squares make the players to draw a quote card, then the quote from that card has to be read.

name: Breyer-Opoly
description:
Breyer-Opoly is a version of Monopoly published by Late for the Sky, a company that specializes in Monopoly clones. The game features model horses made by Breyer. All the spaces have images of model horses and all the deeds and cards have the names of horse breeds on them.

Players roll dice to determine how far they move. Landing on a space gives the player the option of buying the property. When a player collects all the properties in one color group, the properties can be improved by building. When players land on a space owned by another player they must pay rent. Rent is determined by the location of the property and the number of improvements on the space. Some spaces instruct a player to draw a card which can be beneficial or harmful to the player. Players must avoid going bankrupt to stay in the game. The winner is the last player left in the game.
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading
publishers: Late for the Sky Production Company

name: Spellbound Champions
description:
On a remote island, labeled "cursed" to ward off curious eyes, six exemplary people have been summoned against their will to fight against each other in the colosseum. None may leave until a Champion is chosen.

In Spellbound Champions you take the part of one of these six characters to compete as:

Vogak, the Steadfast Orc Warrior
Aurora, the Enchanting Human Magi
Cyrid, the Auspicious Goblin Gambler
Lavanna, the Agile Elf Ranger
Rosie, the Entertaining Halfing Bard
Baeddan, the Virtuous Dwarf Cleric

In a kill or be killed environment, you must push yourself to the limits, or hope you're equipped enough to survive a fight to the death.

"Spellbound Champions" is a player versus player role-playing game for 2-6 players that takes about an hour to play. Try Free-For-All, teams, or take on your nemesis 1 on 1.

Each character has a pre-constructed deck of 60 cards they must use to defeat their opponents. 3 types of action cards are in place: Whenever, Combat, and Ability. Abilities may only be used on your turn, while Whenever cards have no limit on them. Combat cards have a limit of 1 card on your turn.

Last player alive is the winner, unless on a team, in which the team is the winner.
categories: Card Game, Dice, Fantasy, Fighting, Math, Medieval, Negotiation, Real-time
mechanics: Action Points, Cooperative Game, Hand Management, Player Elimination

name: Emperor of the World
description:
From the Developer/Publisher:
You want to rule the world. You have plans to do just that. Execute your plans, and maybe some pesky Rebels, before anyone else does. In the end, they will call you "Emperor".

Emperor of the World is a casual game of reaching your goals before anyone else can. The rules are simple. Roll 2 dice. Turn over a token of one of the numbers rolled. If, at the end of your turn, the tokens listed on your Imperial Plans cards are light-side up, you score that card. First person to score two Imperial Goals cards is the Emperor. Just be wary of those pesky Rebels that show up to ruin your plans anytime you roll a 12.

name: Duel fantastique
description: Duel fantastique is a set of additional rules to allow the use of heroes, non humans (elves, ratmen, werewolves, ...), magical equipement or spells in the groups of fighters the players use.
mechanics: Action Queue, Dice Rolling, Simulation, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Goblin Garage Sale
description:
Life's tough for goblins. As if the klastra birds and grignak spiders weren't enough, there's also the constant possibility of having your house blown up by your neighbors (not always on purpose, it's just that most goblins are too curious for their own good). Mix that with a goblin's natural packrat tendency and what do you get? A lot of junk left behind in storage (a booming industry for the last 79 years), usually without an owner.

In Goblin Garage Sale, players are goblin entrepreneurs hoping to get lucky. Gobo Storing Places Inc. is having a large blind auction of many of its storage garages. However, players are allowed to see only part of the items in the garage. Using their specific knowledge, players bid their hard-earned monies against the others for the contents. To the winner: the garage! Hopefully, it will be filled with glorious junk that the player can add to his personal hoard (for the goblin with the greatest hoard has the greatest bragging rights). If you're lucky, you may even find more monies for future bids! Just hope that the unfortunate former owner didn't hoard useless things, like soap, and pray that when you open your garage it isn't full of horrors, like kittens (how embarrassing) or even a grignak spider (run!).

Goblin Garage Sale is a game of bluffing and luck.

name: Bear in Mind
description:
The object of the game is to be the first player to cross the opponent's forest (made of a 4*4 grid of trees), by removing enough of his trees to create a path connecting the border line between the players with the far edge of the forest (the side closer to the player).

This is achieved by rolling a die with 6 differently coloured sides, and trying to guess (and later, remember) which of the opponent's trees fit the colour rolled. Each forest is made of 6 pairs of differently coloured trees (the 6 colours are the same as the different sides of the die), one 'wild' tree that counts as every colour, and 3 bear trees that cannot be removed from the board.

The first player to cross his opponent's forest (diagonals don't count!) wins the game.

name: Pursuit of Harmony
description:
"it's more than a game"

"A TRIBUTE TO

Forrest C. Shaklee, Sr.

1894-1985"

A roll and move game, with the space landed upon requiring the player to answer a categorized trivia question, (based on the space landed upon), with the questions all referencing Shaklee Naturals products and employee rules and regulations.

name: Kilimanjaro
description:
Kilimanjaro is a game that teaches about African and African-American history and traditions.

It is a basic roll-and-move game with spaces that cause you to draw and read cards that are either informational and earn you points automatically, or players must answer the question to receive 5 points.

At the beginning of the game you roll to determine your 'name' based on the day of the week (you get the appropriate male or female name for that particular day) OR you can choose the 7th day (since you cannot roll it) if you prefer.

You then progress down different tracks and read about or answer questions about Ghana. Some spaces give you points automatically, some tell you to draw a card, some do nothing, and some will tell you to go to other spaces on the board (generally further back) - however you win by getting the most points, NOT by finishing first, so this isn't necessarily bad.

At the end of your trek around the board, you come to the 'Self Reliance' square where you 'wish' on a star (choose one of 3) and then attempt to roll one of the two numbers on it (they have 1-6, 2-5 and 3-4 on them) If you roll correctly you collect the points and you are done. Otherwise you draw a card.

After 2 players have landed on their wished star, the game ends. The player obtaining the most points wins the game.

The game consists of:

A Game Board
64 cards
5 marbles (pawns)
1 Die (D6)
Instructions

name: 321 and Bullseye GameShow Duo
description:
From the Box:

"Are you a general knowledge buff in need of a new challenge? A champion darts who wants to spice up the game? Or maybe you're looking to win some big prizes? This Double bill of TV Game Shows is just what you need for an entertaining evening of game show fun Split into teams, throw some darts and try to win Bully's mystery prize or work out the clues to try and bin the bin. with a little bit of general knowledge and practical playing. you and your teammate could soon be winning big in this double game show compendium."
categories: Humor, Memory, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Party Game, Puzzle, Trivia

name: Dies Irae
description:
Este suplemento incluirá:

- Más trasfondo acerca de cada una de las cuatro Facciones de 1650 (Antiguo Régimen, Nuevo Orden, Usurpadores y Mercenarios). Desde detalladas descripciones de sus territorios, plazas fuertes y gobiernos, hasta un completo análisis de sus fuerzas.

- El trasfondo y las reglas de todas las Personalidades de 1650, presentes y futuras.

- Las listas de las 2 cuadrillas de cada Facción de 1650 (haciendo un total de 8 cuadrillas).

- Listas alternativas, como los Picas Rotas, los más veteranos de entre los veteranos Morados Viejos. O las cuadrillas propias de cada Personalidad de 1650, como la Leva de Prisioneros dirigida por Degoyito, o la Embajada de El Embajador.

- Compendio de todos los Enclaves, Antagonistas, Cartas de Panoplia y Destreza, habidas y por haber.

- Reglas para el uso de vehículos y caballería.

- Reglas para la creación de tus propios peones.

- Sistema de Campañas, con reglas para la mejora de peones mediante la obtención de experiencia.


This supplement will include:

- More background for each of the four Factions of 1650 (Old Regime, New Order, Usurpers and Mercenaries). Detailed descriptions of their territories and government strongholds, even a complete analysis of their forces.

- The background and the rules of all the Personalities of 1650, present and future.

- 2 lists of bands for each faction of 1650 (making a total of 8 bands).

- Alternative lists, such as the Broken Pikes, the most veteran among veterans of the Old Purple, and rules for the bands of each Personality of 1650, for example the Levy of Prisoners, led by Degoyito, or the Embassy led by El Embajador.

- Compendium of all Enclaves, Antagonists, Panoply and Dexterity cards, past and future.

- Rules for the use of vehicles and horsemen.

- Rules for creating your own pawns.

- Campaign system, with rules for the improvement of pawns by obtaining experience.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Fighting, Miniatures, Renaissance

name: Stinky Donkey Cards Game
description:
Stinky Donkey (Burro Apestoso) is a fun cards game for 2 – 6 players, age 6 and up in English and Spanish. Packaged in a convenient pocket size box that you can take to a party, family gathering, camping, or just have fun with your friends and family.

Objective
Get rid of your cards as fast as possible by removing all pairs from your hand with the help of command cards. Avoid the Stinky Donkey card. Once all pairs have been removed from all the players, the player left with the Stinky Donkey card will be marked as a Stinky Donkey (sticker).

Components
49 Stinky Donkey cards, 23 Command cards, 120 Stinky Donkey stickers, 1 Rules document.
Setup
Open your box, start by separating stinky donkey cards (animal drawings with stinky donkey logo on the back) and command cards. Shuffle both decks. Place command cards face down in the middle of the table. Pass out all stinky donkey cards evenly to every player.

Starting The Game
Each player must make pairs, remove them from their hand, and set them aside. The player on the right of the dealer goes first by picking a command card from the top of the command card stack and follows the command.
The Second Turn And Beyond
Going counterclockwise, each player must pick a command card and follow its command.

Winning And Losing The Game
Once a player gets rid of all the cards on his/her hand, him/her is now safe from being a stinky donkey. And once all the players get rid of their cards, the player left with the Stinky Donkey card will be marked as a Stinky Donkey with a Stinky Donkey sticker “HEE- HAWWH!, HEE- HAWWH!”.

Additional Instructions
Take the command cards and the Stinky Donkey out and play as a memory game.
mechanics: Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Pattern Building, Set Collection

name: Alteil: Horizons
description:
Turn based tactics meets collectible card gaming in a Japanese RPG-style online game by the creators of Star Ocean & Valkyrie Profile

Take a collectible card game, add turn-based strategy, and bring it to life with stunning Japanese artwork and story-driven role-playing. This is Alteil: Horizons, the all new sequel to one of Japan’s most popular online card games, soon to be ready for fantasy, tactical combat, card game, and anime enthusiasts worldwide.

Four Gods Sleep Under Lavato…

Harness Their Power!

You are an Iczer, a summoner and master strategist tasked with protecting the world of Lavato from the forces of Batora, the embodiment of evil accross all dimensions. An ancient struggle between Batora and the four Old Gods of Lavato drained the Gods of power, sinking them into a sleep that has lasted thousands of years. But the Gods still influence Lavato from the depths of slumber…

One night, a new Prince is born, and the sun suddenly rises. Night becomes day, and a miracle is proclaimed. The Church of the True God takes advantage of the miracle to orchestrate the installation of the Solar Prince to the throne - and the ensuing power struggle plunges Lavato into war.

With the violence, tragedy, and death of the war, Batora’s hunger for evil and chaos is stoked - and he’s set his sights on Lavato again! But with the Old Gods deep in slumber, who will protect Lavato from Batora’s endless rage?

Now is the time of the Iczers. They’ve studied the legends of Lavato’s Old Gods. They’ve learned to command the Gods’ powerful Four Spheres of Influence. They’ve mastered the art of using these Spheres to summon heroes, monsters, and dragons to battle the forces of chaos and evil. Will you be the brave Iczer who saves Lavato from destruction?

As in any collectible card game, a game of Alteil: Horizons begins with carefully crafting a deck. There’s a universe of over 1,000 cards to choose from, each representing the factions, heroes, villains, monsters and magic of Lavato’s past and present. Your collection begins with any of four free 30-card starter decks, themed around the four Spheres.

Once you’ve challenged another Iczer to a duel, use your resources wisely to play your cards. Spell cards represent your command of the Spheres; unit cards represent your ability to summon heroes and monsters. Each unit is a fully fleshed-out combatant, complete with hit points, attack and defense power, agility, and range. Combat takes place on a battle grid - maneuver your units so that their unique abilities fit your winning strategy. And their abilities really are unique! A fighter with two swords might be able to hit two enemies at once; a mage can tap into your resources to play spells that wreak havoc on the entire battlefield! You have complete control of each unit’s abilities during combat.

A number of features set Alteil apart from the other online card games out there. For example...

Range based grid: position archers behind your front-line fighters to launch a ranged attack. Position your mages in the rear to protect them as they cast powerful defensive and offensive spells.

Resource recycling: when a card dies, you get back the resources you spent on it. Two small soldiers die? Use the Spell Points they originally cost to bring out something big and scary.

Revival system: if a unit dies you can spend a copy of it from your deck to revive it on the battlefield. Keep your best soldiers alive to execute killer multi-unit combos!

Soul Cards: influence the pace of the game by choosing your starting Life Points and Soul Skills. Give yourself stronger Soul Skills and less Life for a more offense-based approach, or give yourself more Life Points to buy time for a crafty strategy.

Day/Night cycle: as duels rage on, the sun rises and sets. Units like the Undead and Werewolves are stronger at night - while a holy warrior gets bonuses under the first rays of morning - so summon them when they’ll be most effective!

Alteil has over two thousand individual pieces of art completed already. It’s got the visual style and story of a Japanese RPG. It’s got unique game mechanics. We hope you’ll become a huge fan. We already are. This is Alteil: Horizons.
categories: Card Game, Collectible Components, Electronic, Fantasy, Math, Video Game Theme
mechanics: Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Grid Movement, Hand Management, Open Drafting, Player Elimination, Role Playing

name: Era of Prosperity
description:
A quick-playing game of farming and commodity trading at the turn of the century.

Players go into debt investing in land and a workforce, then try to repay their loans selling their crops on the commodity market. All the while, prices go up and down based on what gets sold. The only randomness is the game is the starting selection of available crops.

On your turn, you use workers to plant and harvest crops, selling them on the market.

name: Old McDs Donkey
description:
You are all farmers fighting over a donkey which you all supposedly have equal claim to. The first farmer who can get the donkey over the border into their farm wins ownership of the donkey.

Each players bid for first pick of possible foodstuffs to entice the donkey with. A die is rolled to decide which food the donkey moves towards. (which is nearly always the apple)

The players also bet on which color hexagon the donkey will actually land on. Most of the tactics around the game reside around determining which bets will pay off the most in order to pay just enough to outbid the competition for the top foodstuffs.

name: Battlecruiser
description:
Battlecruiser is a simple game of the Naval Combat developed from the Battleship games we all enjoyed as Children. This has been done before by professional and amateur outfits, but for the first time, modern Conflict Simulation Techniques have been employed to provide more "realism".

The game is designed for two players, but if desired can be played by up to four. Various techniques are included for shortening or lengthening the game.

Each turn , the various players will attempt to determine the location of their opponents ships, and to direct fire into those hexes in an attempt to sink enemy ships. The player in each game who has the last vessel afloat will be declared the winner. It is possible that in a particular game the players may be unable to damage each other further. This can only happen when one has a submarine with no torpedoes left, and the other has a ship with no ASW capability. In this case, the game is a tie.

name: GEO: A Game Of The United States
description:
From the rules sheet:

"GEO is the opportunity to learn and enjoy the geography of the U.S. For as little as five minutes a day you can learn the geography of the U.S.

"The object of the game is to be the first to collect two of each color token for a total of twelve tokens"

The player rolls the dice and moves that many spaces and lands on a colored space. The another player draws a card the same color as the space that was just landed on and asks a trivia question. If the player gets it right, they get a token of that color. The first player to get 2 tokens of each color wins.

The trivia questions are US based, and consist of history, government, and geography.

name: To Market The New Tractor Game
description:
To Market The New Tractor Game is typical roll and move board game about farming and agriculture made at Harborne, England by Chad Valley Games in approximately 1950s. The game involves various farming related obstacles and successes, mainly based around farming machinery. So for example successes include "You now have your new tractor - succeed as usual", "A post hole digger to re-fence your field - go forward", "Ploughing demonstration - go forward", "Good hammer milled feed keeps up milk yield - transport box moves churns easily - go forward". Obstacles include "Tractor oil should have been changed - go back", "Your field is flooded - go back", "Tractor neglected - go back" etc.
The first player to finish exactly on 200 has arrived at the market and is the winner.

The graphics on game board are lovely. The course goes through typical English landscape starting at an old farm house, and then through country lanes, ploughed fields, past the „Ferguson School of Farm Mechanisation“ (Massey Ferguson farm machinery), past streams, bridges, churches, farmyards, hay bales, and various farm vehicles to a market in a little town at the end. The board provides an image of a lost, bygone England.
publishers: Chad Valley Co Ltd., Glevum Games

name: Over The Alps
description:
Over The Alps board game was made in England as part of the Glevum Series in around 1930s. As the title suggests – it has a mountaineering theme, which is highlighted by the image on the box lid.

It is a simple race game, played with dice and counters. But what makes it more attractive is that the board – which is stored folded in the box needs to be stood up inside the box base to form a mountain. You start at the bottom of one side and the first person to reach 100 is the winner. You go up one side and then down the other. Instead of ‘squares’ on a regular board this one has numbered holes. The reason for this is that the counters slot into those holes. There are four 1½” high metal climbers. They actually look as if they are Boy Scouts. The figures are identical except that their shorts are different colours. They are red, yellow, green and blue.
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Burger Blitz!
description:
Players assume the roles of aspiring chefs who are competing for the head chef position at the swanky Burger Blitz restaurant. Battle your way to the top by attacking other chef's reputations, enlisting the services of food minions, making magic in the kitchen, and getting your hands dirty by taking the plate to speed up your burger-making skills.

Burger Blitz's main mechanic is press-your-luck dice rolling. What you roll determines 6 different bonuses you can earn that round - Reputation, Burger Ingredients, Pepper, Mayo, Attack, and Tips.

In addition to dice, there are 24 minion cards which players can purchase. These minions give players permanent bonuses they can use every turn.

Finally there are magic cards. Magic cards are earned every time a player completes a full burger. These cards are powerful but can only be used once. Play a mayo token with a magic card to boost the effects even more.

Burger Blitz is easy enough for young children to learn but has enough depth and strategy to entertain seasoned gamers. Included in the rulebook are several variants recommended for more casual or more cutthroat games.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Open Drafting, Push Your Luck

name: Moose Hunt
description:
Moose Hunt game made by Chaffee and Selchow (later Selchow & Righter) is a typical roll and move board game with wonderful graphics depicting a hunter and Indian killing moose.

The first player who crosses the "start" line wins the game.

name: Slalom
description:
Slalom is a paper-and-pencil game for "any number" of players. Each player has a sheet with a point grid and a slalom course through it. A turn consists of rolling the dice and choosing one of three movement options. Players must pass each gate on the correct side.

Players mark off "seconds" for each die roll and mark off more for deviating from the ideal slalom line and for brushing a gate. The player marking off the fewest seconds wins.

name: Penny Patterns
description:
Penny Patterns is played with thirty-six pennies on a board made up of blue and red circles. On each turn the active player flips a penny and places it in a red (inner) circle if it comes up tails and a blue (outer) circle if it comes up heads. Placing in a blue circle entitles a player to go again.

The object is to form symmetrical patterns of at least four pennies, and all the pennies on the board must be used. A point is scored for each axis of symmetry in such a pattern.

The game can be played competitively, but can also be played solitaire, with the object being to beat one's previous best score.

name: Skirmish! The Scrambles: Expansion #1 Antimagic
description:
New allies have come to the somewhat silly monsters. Mage adventures are getting more and more overpowered, so the monsters try to nerf them by recruiting guys that are immune. But if both sides recruit the same, nothing will change. We're still looking for someone who can inform the monsters of that… in the meantime, they're still fighting!

This 4 cards expansion add one new monster "Gazer" and one new magic "Gargoyle" to the basic game for each player.
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy

name: Skirmish! The Scrambles: Expansion #2 Breakthrough
description:
As the monsters aren't really smart, they've just fought straight on. But as they hit their heads against each other, some learned to think.
A valiant warrior, that's a warrior who doesn't rest after a fight, but prepares for the next! But well… sometimes it's a bit too scary so you end up running away instead… meanwhile the others are still fighting!

This 4 cards expansion brings 2 kinds of magic "Return" & "Fear" to the Basic game.
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy

name: NineTacToe
description: The NineTacToe playsheet depicts nine Tic-Tac-Toe boards with numbers in the spaces; the numbers 1-27 each appear three times throughout the boards. Players take turns choosing a number and marking their symbol in the three spaces where it appears. In effect, each number choice is a play on three of the nine Tic-Tac-Toe games at once. The object is for a player to win a majority of the nine sub-games.
publishers: GAMES Magazine, Hoi Polloi Inc., Reiss Games

name: Back Up!
description:
In Back Up! the object is to reduce your back pain to zero. Each turn, players pick up a card from the deck and discard, while trying to collect HEALTH cards in their hand. HEALTH cards reduce your pain, while PAIN cards increase it. ACTION cards allow players to take cards from other players, discard cards, or draw extra cards from the deck. Finally, some HEALTH cards cannot be played without a MONEY or INSURANCE card.

Players start with 5 cards, but the ACTION cards change the number of cards in your hand. Sometimes you are forced to discard cards that you need. The rules are simple, but the ACTION cards add a layer of strategy. It has a light humorous feel. There are 68 cards in a deck.

name: Chase
description: Chase is played on a Backgammon board and uses similar movement rules. However, the setup is different and the object of the game is completely different; the winner is the player who captures all of the opposing pieces. Consequently, there is no bearing off (the board is a continuous loop) and captured pieces cannot be re-entered.
publishers: Research Games, Inc. / Athol / RGI / ARC

name: Robot Commando
description:
Robot Commando (ロボコマ) is combat game for 2 players. Before fighting, each player make one's combat robot by combination of cards. Card has Three types of the Robot, Ability and Arms.

First, the player choose a Robot card. Player get Ability cards set and any Armed cards by the Robot. Equipped with Arms is limited by weight and shape.
Cards become commands for maneuver of Robot. And a card is 1 Hit Points. The damage decreases battle performance of the Robot and will destroy it.

By original card plot system, this game will not roll the dice for damage and decisions hit. The rule is simple, but game is technical and tactical.

This is indies game.
mechanics: Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Hand Management, Hexagon Grid, Simulation

name: Santa Claus Game
description: Parker Brothers' Santa Claus Game consists of a simple race game governed by a spinner. Holiday themed toys and games appealed to present-buying adults during the holiday season. The first player, who cross finish line wins the game.

name: Malvern Hill: July 1st 1862
description:
Malvern Hill is the seventeenth battle in the series and is the seventh in our Peninsula Campaign set of 1862. The Confederates have attacked the Union army at Glendale and they have again retreated south to Malvern Hill.

Combat is designed around the three factors that appear on the unit counters; these indicate the Range, Attack and Strength of the represented unit. You don’t even need any dice to play the game since a dice tile system is included with the game, but if you want to roll dice then it’s the simple six sided variety that you will require.

The game board is designed to be used either 2 dimensionally as a straight print and play or 3 dimensionally, this takes a little more time to construct but it is well worth the effort for the impressive game board you get at its completion. The final 3D game board gives a realistic feel to the terrain and shows the tactical dispositions of all the game counters.
categories: American Civil War, Print & Play, Wargame

name: Unità di Soccorso Giapponesi
description:
Unità di Soccorso Giapponesi (Japanese Rescue Teams) is a cooperative game portraying the aim of the Japanese Rescue Teams to save and protect the Japanese population from the dangers which can occur in the Japanese cities, like earthquakes, typhoons, tsunamis and nuclear pollution. This game is in memory of all the people died during the March 2011 Japanese earthquake and tsunami.
Each player represent a Japanese Rescue Team and will try to solve the problems ariring in the Japaed on the map.

The objective of the players is to reach the level 8 of the Level of Saved Lifes Track (LSL) depicted on the map, which means having saved most of the affected population and thus avoiding to reach the level -7, which would mean the loss of too many lives.
Each player chooses its set of Japanese Rescue Teams (JRT) and deploy the Team 1 in a city on the map. All the Problem Tiles are put in a cup and shuffled together.
The Sequence of play is like the following:
The playing player rolls the d12 die: if the result is 1-6 a new Problem arises (go to c); if the result is 7-12, no new Problems! (go to e.)
c. Roll the d12 die to see in which city the Problem occur (each city has a name and a reference number)
d. Take one Problem Tile form the cup, see which kind of problem is shown and put it near the city rolled during c.
e. Every Player can move his/her JRT in any city shown in the map, normally where there is a Problem or Ruins; there he/she tries to solve a Problem, starting from the playing Player.
A JRT can try to solve one Problem per turn, so if there is more than one Problem Tile in a city, the playing Player must choose which one will be tried by his/her JRT.
If the JRT manages to resolve the Problem, raise by 1 level the LSL Track, turn the Problem tile on the Ruins side.
If the JRT does not manage to solve the Problem, the Problem remains and at the start of the next turn, will decrease the LSL:
The players have to clear Ruins in order to avoid negative DRM in solving the Problems.

A nice small cooperative game!

name: Glendale: June 30th 1862
description:
Glendale is the sixteenth battle in the series and is the sixth in our Peninsula Campaign set of 1862. The Confederates are in a position to attack the Union army who is retreating towards Harrison's Landing on the James River. Combat is designed around the three factors that appear on the unit counters, these indicate the Range, Attack and Strength of the represented unit. You don’t even need any dice to play the game since a dice tile system is included with the game, but if you want to roll dice then it’s the simple six sided variety that you will require.

The game board is designed to be used either 2 dimensionally as a straight print and play or 3 dimensionally, this takes a little more time to construct but it is well worth the effort for the impressive game board you get at its completion. The final 3D game board gives a realistic feel to the terrain and shows the tactical dispositions of all the game counters.
categories: American Civil War, Print & Play, Wargame

name: Pearl Harbor Attack  Balls: DARTS – Cards
description:
This is a real naval war game with a unique twist - it uses DARTs and BALLs to play. Players will attack nicely illustrated battleship profiles by tossing and dropping darts along with rolling balls. While tradition pointed darts can be used, the more graphic play uses dart(s) or ball(s) dipped in washable collorinfg for graphic splatters that mimic highly visual and realistic explosions. The game can be very simple dart toss game or be more complex by using the written game guide rules. Game play utilizes an eraser head dart but players can choose their own metal/plastic point type darts. The duration of play is between 20 minutes to more than an 60 minutes, depending if you play one, two, or all three parts. You can play the game in teams, family play or solo. A great game for adults and kids above the age of seven.

Game Parts Include: Target Illustration are legal size (8.5" X 14") black-gray-white (gray scale) colored prints - they are reproducable for non-commercial home/classroom use by the game purchaser

•Top View - Battleship target illustrations include the USS Arizona, USS Neveda, USS California, USS Tennessee, USS Maryland, USS West Virgnia, USS Oklahoma, & USS Pennsylvania

•Side View - Battleship target illustrations include the USS Nevada, USS Arizona, USS West Virginia, USS Oklahoma, and the USS California

•One mini ball and one eraser head dart included
•Game guide

The game shipped regular USPS mail in a sealed 2"w X 16"L tube

Note: Upgrade to the larger 11" X 17" colorized version of the paper battleship target illustrations for an additional $20 - email me for this upgrade option

name: Atomic Race
description:
Atomic Race is played on a 5x5 board. Each player starts with ten pieces occupying the two rows closest to them. A move consists of taking a single piece or the top piece from an "atom" (stack) and moving it in any combination of forwards and sideways moves until it reaches an empty space or a space with an opponent's piece visible (moving through spaces where the player's own color is visible).

The central row of the board (the "plasma zone") cannot contain atoms, so a single piece there controls its space until it moves.

The object is to exit one's pieces off the opposing end of the board. Since the game is short, the designer suggests playing a series of games using a scoring system.

name: Re: Your Brains
description:
Based on the song by Jonathan Coulton, Re: Your Brains pits 2-5 players against each other and the zombie horde. Players play food and office supply cards face up in front of them to give them bonuses, play weapon cards to destroy zombies, and play any card face down in front of their opponents to create more zombies that want to eat their brains.

Each player starts out as a heroic human and can win if they are the sole survivor, OR they can become overrun by zombies and become a zombie master. Each zombie master has a different victory condition.

This game should not be confused with the other card game of the same name. Same inspiration; different implementation.

name: War of the Black Holes
description:
War of the Black Holes is played on a board with four concentric rings of spaces. Each player has a single spacecraft piece which moves each turn, either within a single ring or with one change to an adjacent ring. The number of spaces that can be moved depends on the ring the move ends in, with the inner rings requiring faster movement than the outer rings.

After moving a "black hole" piece is placed in a space adjacent to one's spacecraft. These pieces can be moved over but a move cannot be ended on one; a player wins when their opponent cannot move to an empty space.

name: Rondo
description:
Rondo is played on a board of five concentric rings of twelve spaces each. One player has black pieces and starts on the innermost ring, the other has white pieces and starts on the outermost ring. The object is to connect the innermost and outermost rings with an unbroken chain of your pieces.

Pieces can move outward, inward, diagonally inward or outward, or around the ring they are in. However, Black can only move outward and clockwise and White can only move inward and counterclockwise. Pieces must jump opposing pieces when able to do so (the jumped pieces are not captured).

name: Score Five
description:
Score Five is played on a 6x6 square grid in which someone has randomly placed the numbers 1-9, four times each.

The first player starts by circling the number in one of the four corners and starting a running total with that number. The second player circles an adjacent number and adds it to the running total. This continues until the running total reaches 170, at which point the game ends.

When a player makes the running total a multiple of five, they add that running total to their score. Whoever has the higher score when the game ends, wins.

name: Rescue
description:
Rescue is played on a 5x9 grid. Players each have nine pieces which begin the game in stacks of one, two, or three pieces.

On a turn a player moves one of their stacks as many spaces as the number of pieces in the stack, in any orthogonal direction or combination of such directions. Only empty spaces can be crossed; an opponent's stack can be landed on, which captures the pieces in it.

After moving a player may take one piece and put it in any legal space (empty or on top of one of their one or two-piece stacks).

Certain spaces on the board have numbers in the players' colors. If a player ends a stack's move on a space of their color and the number of pieces in the stack, the stack is "rescued" and removed from the board.

The game ends when one player has no pieces on the board (due to rescue and/or capture). The player who rescued the most pieces wins.

name: Sque-e-e-eze Play
description:
Sque-e-e-eze Play is played on a 7x7 square grid. Players begin by each making a (different) mark in any space. On each subsequent turn, a player begins at their last mark, moves any number of empty spaces in any straight line, and places a new mark in the end space. (The previous mark is crossed out.)

The object is to end on your opponent's last mark (an exception to the rule about only moving in empty spaces) or prevent your opponent from playing.

name: Morro
description:
Morro is played on an 8x8 square grid using two pieces per player and 19 neutral pieces. To start the game one player places all four players' pieces on the edge of the board and any number of neutral pieces on non-edge spaces. The other player may then either move first and choose which color to play, or may take the remaining neutral pieces (counting towards the victory condition) and let the other player choose a color and move first.

A turn consists of moving either of your pieces in any straight line over empty spaces. After a move, if the moving piece and any other piece (including one of the opposing pieces) enclose an unbroken line of neutral pieces (or opposing pieces), the enclosed pieces are captured.

The object of the game is to capture a majority of the 19 neutral pieces.

As a variant, one piece of each player moves as described above, and the other can jump over pieces (jumped pieces are not captured).

name: Crazy Quilt
description: Crazy Quilt is played on a 4x4 grid of squares, with each square being divided into four triangles. Players take turns coloring triangles (with each player using a different color). When all triangles have been colored, players score points for certain shapes made from four triangles each, with overlaps allowed.

name: Max: A Two-Player Game
description:
Max is played on an 8x8 grid filled with positive and negative integers, except for one space marked with a star. One player starts by crossing out any number in the row with the star and adding to his or her total. The other player then crosses out any number in the column where the first player's number is. The players continue choosing numbers based on the row or column where the previous play was until one of them cannot move.

A game consists of two rounds; in the second round players switch so that the player who played rows now plays columns and vice-versa. The high score after both rounds wins.

The game appears to be nothing more than a pencil-and-paper version of Mattix, which was not designed by the "designer" of this game.

name: The Great Snark Rescue
description:
The Great Snark Rescue is played on a hex map depicting a park. Certain hexes are designated as starting spaces for snarks, snark trackers (which are owned by the players), and transportation pieces. On each turn players move their trackers and attempt to land them on snarks, which rescues them. The object is to rescue the majority of the snarks.

The terrain affects movement; a tracker must stop when entering a forest hex and cannot normally enter water hexes. A tracker can move onto a transportation piece and then use it, which may let it move farther (e.g. a bicycle can move any distance, but only along a path) and/or circumvent movement restrictions (e.g., a boat can go in the water and a hot-air balloon can cross water and forest hexes).

Variants allow for free setup of the various pieces.

Since each side has two trackers, the game can be played by four players in teams, with each player controlling one tracker.
mechanics: Grid Movement, Hexagon Grid, Team-Based Game

name: Aquanemo
description:
Aquanemo is a fast magnetic fishing game. There are many look-alike fishes on a deceptive mat whose design is made to handicap the fishermen.

The first player draws a card on which a fish is depicted and every one tries to find the right fish in the ocean. The fastest to find it gets to keep the card and return the fish to the water. Then a new card is drawn. The fisherman with the most cards at the end is the winner.

name: Bastion
description:
Bastion can be played by 2, 3 or 4 players. If there are 2 players, each one will have two fighters' camps, in the corners of the board, diagonally. If there are 3 or 4 players, each one will have one camp. When there are 4 players, they can play individually or in pairs, on the diagonal of the board. The two members of each team can communicate, choosing the strategy that suits them best.

​What does the game board represent?

In the center of the board lies the Bastion, a fortress with four towers, of different colors. Around the Bastion, one square away, is a moat, filled with water, crossed by four bridges. In the corners of the board are situated the fighters' camps, the fighters being represented by four tokens, having different range attacks, as their respective numbers show.

​What is the purpose of the game?

The winner of the game is the player who brings all his fighters, in the order 2, 3, 4 and 5, in the tower of his color. In the case of the team game, it is enough for one of the players to win, so that the team can be victorious.
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Team-Based Game

name: Blasted!
description:
Blasted is a retro space combat and exploration game for 2 to 4 players.

The Mechanisms of a long-dead civilization, The Ascendants, are again activating and imprisoning all of the Galactic Outposts in the sector. The Ascendant Key is needed to deactivate these mechanisms; but it has been separated in to 4 pieces, called the Prime Relics, and scattered throughout space. Players take control of one or more ships and battle against each other using a vast array of Weapons, Technologies and Command tactics, all while attempting to recover the 4 Prime Relics and re-create the Ascendant Key. The first player or team to have all 4 Prime Relics in the Cargo Hold of a single ship saves the galaxy and wins the game.

Rule Book: http://bit.ly/1iuQ4Eg
Print & Play: http://bit.ly/BlastedPNP
categories: Dice, Fantasy, Fighting, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Science Fiction
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Hand Management, Simulation

name: Perfidious Albion: Spain vs. Britain
description:
Two siege battles of the 18th century pitting Spain vs. Britain.

A low complexity simulation of 18th century sieges. Rules will cover mortars, wall breaches, sorties, parallel lines, naval gunfire.

The two battles depicted are:
Cartagena 1741: British Armada. The English sent a fleet against Cartagena de Indias, the key to the Panama isthmus. Composed of 186 ships, with 2,600 guns and some 10,000 troops, the plan was to cut in two the Spanish Empire in the Americas. The fortress was defended by 3,000 Spanish troops and six ships of the line.

Havana 1762. The largest port of Cuba, Havana, was attacked in June 1762 by a large English fleet (53 ships of the line, 15,000 troops, 10,000 sailors). At the peace conference, Spain had to cede Florida to the British to regain Havana.

name: Flash 10 Schnupperspiel
description:
Flash 10 Schnupperspiel is a promotional version of the card game Flash 10 that contains only 32 cards instead of the 120 cards in the original game.

Flash 10 is a quick-playing take on the Rack-O game system, with players trying to arrange cards in numerical order – but doing so all at the same time. Someone shuffles the deck, then each player receives ten cards face down, which they place in a row in front of them. Playing simultaneously and as quickly as possible, players reveal these cards (without rearranging them), then start taking cards one at a time from those scattered in the center of the table and placing them on one of the ten cards in front of them, thereby creating stacks of cards as the game progresses. If a player draws a thunderstorm card, she can place it on any stack.

As soon as a player has ten number cards in ascending order from left to right, she yells "Stop!" and ends the round. If she's correct, she scores 10 points, plus 2 points for ending the round. Each other player scores points for the number of cards in order starting from their left stack. In addition, each card with a lightning bolt (whether in order or not) is worth 1 point, while each thunderstorm card is worth -1 point. Players then shuffle the cards and start another round. Whoever reaches 50 or more points first wins!

name: Fighting Sail
description:
Fighting Sail is a fairly simple naval wargame. It is played on a triangular grid, with the ships moving from intersection to intersection. The ships are represented by pieces of wood with holes drilled to hold small flags; the position of the flag in a ship represents its speed. The color of a flag represents how many operational guns the ship has.

Movement is performed by spending one knot (movement point) for each intersection moved and/or each 60 degrees turned. Ships may not sail directly into the wind, which may shift at the start of each round (based on a die roll).

When a ship fires at a target it declares whether it is aiming at the decks or the rigging and rolls on the appropriate table. The die roll needed to hit further depends on the number of guns the attacker has, the class of the target (1st, 2nd, or 3rd rate), the range, and whether the target is beam on or end on to the attacker.

There are a few additional rules for heaving to and boarding.

The rules were published in Games & Puzzles #1 (May 1972).

name: Numero
description:
Numero is played with 64 tiles depicting the digits 0-9, the standard arithmetical operations, and the root symbol. On each turn one player plays two numbers and an operation to use on them, and their opponent can then add to it in an effort to reduce its value. The reduced value is scored.

Subsequent plays are made crossing earlier ones, using some of their tiles.

The rules were published in Games & Puzzles #2 (June 1972). Sets of tiles could be purchased from the magazine.

name: Nine Holes
description:
Nine Holes is a dice-based golf game. It uses five special dice of which two are used for each stroke (except when putting), at the player's discretion. If both dice show numbers the ball goes straight, but if a number plus H (for hook) or S (for slice) is rolled the ball will go on a defined line to one side or the other.

There are rules for landing in water, lost balls, etc. In addition, landing in certain positions causes the player to draw a Rough Luck card, which will impose a penalty. There are other spaces where Golf Pro cards are drawn, which can be used for benefits on later strokes. Golf Pro cards are also awarded for under-par holes and exact putts.

The rules were published in Games & Puzzles $3 (July 1972). A sample hole is given; players are encouraged to make their own based on courses they like. Lists of the cards were made available by the magazine if you sent in for them.

name: Quirk
description:
Quirk is played on a 9x9 square grid which is divided into four spirals radiating from the center. It requires eight dice with letters on the sides (the distribution is not given). Letters are written in the spaces.

On each turn the player rolls the dice and attempts to make a word using them. After the first word (which begins in the center), each new word must incorporate letters from previously-played words. Words are played along the spirals. However, additional words may be formed in orthogonal directions, which scores extra points.

The rules were published in Games & Puzzles #26 (July 1974).

name: Flotten Versenken
description:
Flotten versenken ist der würdige Nachfolger von dem Pen and Paperspiel Schiffe Versenken. Das Geschicklichkeitsspiel fordert Jung und Alt heraus und verschiedene Schiffstypen geben dem Spiel ein gewissen strategisches Moment.
Jeder Spieler erhält jeweils eine Flotte aus verschiedenen Schiffen, U-Booten und Seemienen. Durch gezielten Wurf kann er gegnerische Schiffe versenken, Mienen legen oder entschärfen oder auf dem Meer kreuzen. Der auf dem Rand aufgedruckte Schaden der das feindliche Schiff berührt muss der Schiffsklasse entsprechen oder überbieten um das feindliche Schiff zu versenken und es als Beute an sich zu nehmen. Das Spiel endet mit dem werfen der letzten Karte, wer dann die meisten Punkte entsprechend der summierten Schiffsklassen gesammelt hat ist Sieger.

Fleets at Battle (english Titel)
"Fleets at Battle" is the modern version of the pen and paper game Battleships. This dexterity game is challenging young and old, the different classes of ships give a strategic moment to the game. Every player receives cards representing a fleet of ships, submarines and sea mines. By throwing these cards onto enemy ships on the table they can sink them and take the victory points, set new mines or disable them or patrol the sea. To sink an enemy ship your damage printed on the overlapping border of your ship must match or exceed the enemies ship class. The game ends with using the last fleet card; the player with the most victory points on their sunken ships is the winner.

name: Hollywoodopoly: A Cityopoly Game
description:
Cityopoly is an entrepreneurial business development and trading game, featuring the world's favorite cities and regions. Players travel throughout the designated area, buying and selling and trading local landmarks and prominent businesses that are an integral part of the community.

Cityopoly helps immortalize the unique sites and spirit that make a city or region distinctive. By dedicating a percentage of sales to a local charity or worthy cause in every community where the game is developed, Cityopoly also helps enrich the area

Starlight Foundation

name: Jackpot
description:
Jackpot is played on a 4x4 grid representing a slot machine. Players start each round by being dealt four cards each depicting one of four symbols. A turn consists of placing a tile with one of these symbols in an empty space on the board.

Once the board is full players reveal their cards and score for sets of four squares with symbols matching all their cards. They can score for orthogonal rows, diagonal rows, 2x2 groups, and the four corners of the board, with different payouts for each.

Rounds are played until someone gets to 500 points.

name: a game of gnome: the garden of seedin'
description: This page does not exist. You can edit this page to create it.

name: Dunjonworx
description:
Publisher's Blurb:
There is a dungeon in the kingdom and each of the players represents a party of adventurers who has stumbled upon one of its entrances. Players take turns exploring their dungeon or throwing obstacles in the paths of their rivals. It's a race to the treasure room, while managing the finite resources of adventurers in your party.
