A ground war with the aliens seems inevitable as the first waves of enemies approach. Players take the role of weapons development companies seeking a contract with the Earth Defense Force.

Defeating aliens gets you brownie points, but sloppy work will let the next player sweep up the wounded remains. Balance subterfuge and self-promotion while blowing up aliens to claim ultimate victory!



=========The game is comprised of multiple player rounds over the course of three waves of invading aliens, with the starting player rotating between each. At the start of each round, cards can be played to give an advantage or disadvantage to yourself or other players for the duration of the round. Most player-to-player sabotage happens at this time, so players go into their turns aware of what odds might be stacked against them.

Once a round has begun, players each do the following as a complete turn:

- Receive energy tokens and event cards;
- Commit energy tokens to their weapons;
- Use event cards for their action, or as currency for upgrading weapons or hiring employees;
- Fire charged weapons into a 3x3 grid of aliens.

Each weapon has its own targeting system and damage types, with stronger weapons needing more energy to fire. Each alien has their own Rock-Paper-Scissors style strengths and weaknesses against damage types.

Players keep alien corpses for end-game points, but can trade them for additional event cards on the Black Market. Weapon upgrades and employees also provide points at the end of the game, but on a handicap system - more points are awarded for weaker weapons or poor employees, awarding clever strategy over pure luck.

The game typically ends when the Wave III deck empties and the 3x3 grid can no longer be stocked, but there are a few conditions where all players lose if they can't coordinate their efforts well enough!

name: Alien Overlords
description:
In Alien Overlords, a sci-fi strategy game, players control fleets of starships and attempt to conquer or destroy the 24 planets on the game map. Players start with only one or two planets. Gobble up as many Neutral Planets as you can before enemy players' ships threaten your planets and Home World.

Before play begins, each player picks technologies and bonuses that influence their strategy for the game. The game features three classes of starships: Frigates, Cruisers and Battleships. Frigates are cheap to build, Cruisers move the fastest, and Battleships dish out the most damage. Planets are also of three sizes according to the resource value of that planet. Custom average dice are used for battles, allowing an element of chance while making it difficult to win or lose by luck alone.

Focusing on combat and strategic movement rather than resource management, Alien Overlords plays quickly. Technologies are chosen at the start of the game rather than researched during the game. If a ship is damaged it either explodes or repairs itself so that players do not have to keep track of damage. Over 50 unique, interesting, and sometimes funny Situation Cards give temporary bonuses or allow players to steal from, sabotage or destroy enemy forces.

Alien Overlords allows freedom of ship movement across the map rather than using "space lanes." There is only one type of Resource to manage, an income based on the planets under a player's control. Number and locations of planets on the game map can be adjusted to suit the number of players, the desired game length, and for variety.
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Dice Rolling, Simultaneous Action Selection, Variable Player Powers

name: Hurricane: The Game of Preparedness
description:
Hurricane: The Game of Preparedness is an update to the original Hurricane Game created in 1988. The new version features a more compact and redesigned box, additional resorts, and new Hurricane Trivia cards. In the original game a player would read the hurricane update on their turn, but in this version the hurricane updates are determined based on rolling the dice.

2-4 players brave the storm as they buy and sell exotic resorts in hurricane prone areas. They must buy insurance and take advantage of opportunities to prepare their resorts, or face the imminent threat of the hurricane!

As in the original, there is also an advanced play option, where players cruise their yachts through the inner game board from one resort to the next, while trying to avoid the inevitable hurricanes. But players must also beware of another threat... The Bermuda Triangle! The player with the most money at the end of the game is the winner, and therefore the best prepared player.
mechanics: Grid Movement, Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move, Stock Holding

name: Checkorete
description:
A Checkers variant for 2, 3, or 4 players. The game is played on a 14 x 14 grid of red and black squares, but with four squares in each corner taken out. The central 10 x 10 grid is the field of play and is marked by a thin white "Haven line." Player pieces are in four colors and begin in the four sections outside of the Haven line, called "King's Havens," on the black squares printed with checkers pieces. (Each player has 10 pieces.)

Rules are essentially the same as English draughts, but for the complication of having four players. Once players move their pieces into the field of play, they may not move back over the Haven line at any point on the board. Promotion is achieved at the furthest row in the field of play from each player. Rules are also provided for partnership play.

The central 8 x 8 square section of the board is highlighted so that it may be used for a standard game of Checkers.

name: ΔV: The Game of Spatial Combat
description:
Based on the elegance of chess, checkers, and go, and inspired by the beauty of deep space, DeltaV is the game of spatial combat.

Someday, humanity will harness enough energy to become a starfaring species. But what then? Will we explore the stars, united? Or will humanity fragment into the bubble of space around the Solar System? We're apparently alone in the galaxy, and if we turn inward, against each other, the war will be more frightening than any fought so far.

In the game of DeltaV, you can find out if you have what it takes to survive spatial combat. Fight against one to five other fleet commanders over a region of space. Deceivingly simple, the DeltaV board contains only as many positions as a standard checkerboard. But in three dimensions, those positions can have much greater significance.

One board supports up to six players, and multiple boards may be combined for even larger battles.
mechanics: Area Movement, Pattern Recognition, Point to Point Movement

name: North South Battle
description:
On July 16, 1861, the federal Army of the Republic was ordered to Richmond to capture the Confederate capitol. The two armies met at a railroad junction town called Manassas near a stream called Bull Run.

Now the commanders of the opposing forces can re-live and re-fight that famous battle. The board is stylized representation based on actual maps. The map is printed on vinyl coated paper with one inch hexes. There are 54 card stock printed pieces enclosed in clear hard plastic cases that stand upright. This is in essence plastic-cased minatures. The game has a hidden strength factor the effectively simulates the raw, unseasoned troops in the actual battle. There are also provisions for artillery fire, and terrain modifiers. Victory is obtained by eliminating the opposing player's 6 strength General, two 3 strength generals or all the enemy troops. Victory can also be obtained if the opposing player or team surrenders.

name: Bombsquad Battle
description:
It's an "every man for himself" bombfest on a battlefield of hexagon spaces. Have a blast running around the battlefield, collecting power-ups, and trying to trap your buddies with explosives before they can do the same to you!


Notes and features*



2 sided, interchangeable floor map pieces for a different battlefield each game.



Up to 4 players compete on either a Small Map using 7 of the above mentioned map pieces, or a Large Map using all 19 pieces.



Blow up Bricks to reveal Power-Ups and gain an edge. Just beware Misfortune and its random negative effects!



All of these features, packaged to fit in your pocket.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Roll / Spin and Move, Variable Player Powers

name: Chesimals I
description:
A "chesimal" is a chess animal, an autonomous multi-unit piece with its own "brain" unit, an activator that allows same-colored pieces that are directly connected to the activator to move. A chesimal that has lost its brain can no longer move, although the remaining units of the chesimal stay on the board, blocking friendly pieces and subject to capture by enemy pieces.

The game, an introduction to the idea of chesimals and activators, is played on a 16x24 board, with 32 units per side forming 4 chesimals. Each chesimal is a mix of 3 different short range chesslike units, each of which moves differently. Two of the chesimals are "royal" units, consisting of a royal brain, 2 knights, and 4 "men", pieces that move like a king but are not royal. The other 2 pieces contain a brain, 4 men, and 4 rooklike or 4 bishoplike pieces, which only move 1 or 2 squares/turn.

Players alternate turns, moving 1 chesimal/turn. The object of the game is to capture your opponent's 2 royal brain units before losing both of yours.

name: Mayhex!
description:
Mayhex! possibly the greatest and most addictive fantasy card game ever created - coming soon from Thornway Games.

Taken from the Celtic portmanteau of mayhe​m (a situation where there is little or no order or control) and hex (a wicked spell or curse which brings bad luck), Mayhex! basically means trouble!



Mayhex! is a fantasy based zombie survival card game (for 2 - 8 players (the more the better), aged 13+) which features a new game mechanic - you are able (amongst other actions) to Dice Duel or Coin Duel via the cards, so no real dice or coins are required to play the game.




The Objective:

The object of the game is to be the first to gain 100 points; only then will you be able to cure the zombie virus and save yourself.

Things are never quite that easy though, are they? Especially when there are Goblins stealing your equipment, Undead hunting in the catacombs and Mayhex! magic getting in the way.



Contents:

Each pack consists of a deck of 108 unique cards.

Every card has two dice (scores ranging from 2 to 12) and a coin (either a Head or Tails) printed on it (to enable you to Dice Duel or Coin Duel). You don't require anything else to play.

Mayhex!'s 108 unique playing cards consist of Positive Cards, Negative Cards, Action Cards, Mayhex! Cards, Infection Cards, and Uninfected Cards.



Like any good card game, Mayhex! requires both skill and a touch of luck to win.

At the start of your turn you must select a card from the Well. You must play one card from your Hand on either yourself, into the Pit or more enjoyably into another player's Lab.

How your friends will laugh when you make them Dice Duel to see if their entire Hand must be placed directly into the Pit or maybe you’ll give them minus 25 points or better yet, an Infected Card.



We'll be uploading how to play Mayhex! tutorial videos to the Thornway Games website in late February 2015. (Pro tip number 1 is: learn the cards!)

name: Klaas Vaak Zandloper Spel
description:
Join Klaas Vaak (the Sandman, who brings on dreams and sleep by sprinkling sand into the eyes of the children) and travel the world of the Efteling, the stars, and the moon, on the back of the owl Oehoe Houdoe. But beware! Klaas Vaak has to be back in his sandcastle before sunrise.

You get 20 minutes of playtime. Grab a die and for every player a pawn. Every player throws the die and moves his/her pawn the number of pips shown on the die. Will you make sure that every child is in Dreamland on time?

The first player to reach the sandcastle wins the game, but if no-one has one within 20 minutes, everybody loses.

name: American Checkers
description:
A variant of Checkers for up to four players, American Checkers was published in time for the USA's bicentennial year of 1976 and features the colors red, white, and blue prominently.

It is played on a 13x13 grid of checkered squares, with six squares in a triangular pattern removed from each corner. Occupying the center of the board are four large square safe zones where pieces may move and not be captured. Nine pieces per player are used, in red, white, blue and gold, with their starting positions marked on two rows of squares close to each side of the board. The game may be played individually or in partnership, and is essentially the same as Checkers but for the extra players and safe zones. Capture is compulsory when not in the safe zones. Promotion occurs by reaching the opposite end of the board. Last player with pieces remaining wins the game.

name: Up and Down
description:
Up and Down is a dice game played with one dice with the letters U P D O W N on the faces.

The players roll the dice during a turn until either "UP" or "DOWN" has been spelled out in full. "UP" counts one point, "DOWN" nothing, after 10 turns the player with the most points wins.

Copyright from the back of the dice blister 1967 by F.F.G.

name: MathMind
description:
MathMind® is a game of simple math and fast hands. Each player has a set of cards with the numbers from 0 to 9. First player places a card (by choice or randomly) on the left side of the game board, next player (clockwise) places a card (also by choice or randomly) on the right side of the game board. Now the first player rolls the MathDice.

As soon as the dice cup is lifted an equation is revealed. All players calculate the result and then try to find it among all of the answer cards spread over the table. He or she who finds the answer first grabs the card and places it next to him/her in such a way that all players may reach it. The answer card now constitutes one point.

Once the answer card has been found the dice cup is passed on to the next player (still clockwise), the played cards are removed from the game board and a new turn begins.

Should an answer that has already been taken by a player come out again, everyone may try to steal that answer. Again fastest hand wins. If a player grabs an answer card that he or she has already has by his/her side, a special card is given to remember that extra point.

The game is over when all cards have been played. The winner is the one with the most answer cards. In case of equality the digits on the answering cards are counted, higher number wins (i.e. "2" is one digit and "1.25" is three digits).

To sum up the idea of the game:
Finding the answer was easy - but where is it?

name: Vino Tinto
description:
In this tactical game, each player takes on the role of a Spanish wine merchant and try to achieve the highest income with excellent wine.

But the competition and many a storm complicate the business. Since it is important to see how the market develops and when the growing areas receive the "mark of the season." In addition, any player can get through clever recommendations to the commission of wine tourists.

The player can trade with 3 different varieties: Tempranillo (purple), Garnacha (blue) and Mencia (light blue). The player who has achieved the highest earnings after 4 votes, winning this card game.

name: Activation Petteia
description:
This game was created for a design contest as documented here:

http://boardgamegeek.com/article/13809424#13809424

The game is played on an uncheckered board of 8 rows and 12 files; the game does scale though to boards of smaller size. Each player starts the game (sitting across the board from one another facing a long side of the board) with 12 stones placed in the nearest row, 10 identical pieces starting one each on all spaces except the two corners each of which is occupied by an activator. A supply of neutral colored stones and of additional pieces in the player's own color (designated white and black) are also needed.

All stones move like rooks in chess, i.e., vertically or horizontally in an unobstructed line.

The object is to create a situation where one has at least twice as many pieces on the board as one's opponent or where the opponent has no legal move. Draws are not possible.

What's notable here is the use of two activator pieces based on an a notion created by designer Joe Joyce, as per the contest mentioned above. This allows captured pieces to be removed from play, converted to immobile neutral pieces or replaced by a piece of one's own color, depending on how they are captured.

name: Mountain Mayhem
description:
Mountain Mayhem is the ski-based cross sport of racing and bludgeoning set in a fantasy universe.

Players choose skilled skiers to tackle the particular mountain course (and the competition), grab some equipment and muster their courage to face the obstacles laid before them...including the other skiers. Choose your skier and your equipment wisely, avoid the pit traps and skier attacks, deal some damage yourself, and plan the smartest course. Do this, and you may just win the game.

Players score points for speed and points for pain. Do one. Do the other. DO BOTH! Players score 1 point for each point of damage dealt and 1 point for each space they are ahead of the last place skier at the end of the game when a skier crosses the finish line.
mechanics: Action Points, Action Queue, Dice Rolling, Hand Management, Modular Board, Point to Point Movement, Variable Player Powers

name: Bobo Rijmspel: Uitbreiding Grabbelboom
description:
Bobo and his friends are fond of rhyme. Bobo says 'book' and Tjerk immediately replied 'cook'! So they can go on for hours!

This upgrade kit for the Bobo Lucky Dip Tree teaches young children about playful rhymes and reading. Choose a word map and bulletin words from the Bobo Lucky Dip Tree. Look for words that rhyme with the words in your word map. Be the first player to fill the whole map to win!
categories: Children's Game, Educational, Expansion for Base-game, Word Game

name: Perspective of Mirrors
description:
In Perspective of Mirrors, players take on the roles of intelligence directors utilizing various assets to complete espionage operations and score Information Points. Players use the Espionage cards to alter the landscape and achieve goals. Assets are utilized in the field to seek clues and information vital to success. Operations are the missions handed to you from above that need to be completed.

Being in the right place at the right time can make the difference between success and failure. When states spy on states, not only are the proper assets required to be in the right place at the right time, but also with the right support. It takes a skillful mastermind to direct your nation’s assets in a manner that is beneficial to your missions but also confounding to others.
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Area Movement, Pattern Recognition

name: Capt'n Sharky: Abenteuer auf der kleinen Schatzinsel
description:
Capt'n Sharky and his mates are looking for the treasure of Pirate Bill. But not every hiding place actually contains loot so the players help Capt'n Sharky to find out where the gems are.

Players move their pirate pawns along the row of island tiles by playing one of six movement cards. The card hand is repleneished only after all cards have been played. Whenever a pirate lands on an empty tile he gets to place the treasure chest on the tile and opens it to checks whether he's found something. When all gems have been found, the player with the most gems is the winner.

A variant requires players to catapult the gems into the ship's hold in order to score them.

The island tiles and the treasure chest use magnets to make the chest display different symbols when it is placed on a tile.

This game is basically a smaller carry-along version of Capt'n Sharky: Abenteuer auf der Schatzinsel with a few differences in implementation.

name: Euro-Express
description:
In Euro-Express, players can create or expand nine speed rail connections with a total of 28 sections that are primarily links between the capitals of the European Community. Important regional sub-centers of some countries are also connected to the network. Existing train connections are shown on the schedule as rails.

The goal is to create a train through Europe, and only through team work can players hope to achieve this challenge. Each player takes the role of the Minister of Transport of the EC countries. In the EC, the ministers meet regularly in the Council of Ministers of Transport. The Common Community Commission proposes the construction of a particular route. The European Parliament may accept this proposal or reject it. This also applies to the Transport Ministers Council, which will decide after discussing the planning and financing of the track.

Any Minister of Transport can try to fund the project through national budgetary resources, which he can invest in the construction of the Euro-train. In addition, the Transport Ministers Council may fall back in the game on loans from the European Investment Bank (EIB) and funds from the EC transport budget.

Until all the capitals of the community are linked by the Euro-Express, the Council has to overcome many hurdles and crack many hard nuts.
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Network and Route Building

name: Bajsboule!
description:
Bajsboule! (literally "poop boule") is a dexterity-based Swedish children's game implementation of the sport "Boule". The object of the game is to toss balls as close to the poop as possible.

Plastic turd included.

name: TeamWords
description:
Players are trying to build a letter grid: either they succeed each round, and win at the end, or they fail, and lose immediately. Players set the timer then draw letters. Within the time limit, they endeavor to place the letters they drew.

The game requires a electronic timer, which is not included; it is recommended that each round be allowed one minute each, but it can be changed to reflect players' skill levels.

Players must work together to use consonants as they are drawn, within the time limit. Players can plan ahead so that they will be ready for certain letters.

This game is ideal for environments where players are extremely unmatched; instead of one player having to cheat to lose, all players work together and the timer can be adjusted to reflect the skill of the group.

name: The Outboard Motor Race
description: Typical spin and move game published in 1930's by Milton Bradley. The first player, who cross finish line - wins the game.

name: Farmer Jones' Pigs
description: This is a Roll and Move game. On some spaces, players may lose turns or move back a few space. The first player to move from start to finish wins. Players must spin the exact number needed to win.

name: The Game Of Robin Hood
description:
In merry England, in the time of King John and at the same time that the Crusaders were waging war in Palestine, there lived in Sherwood Forest a young and dauntless robber named Robin Hood.

His two lieutenants were Little John and Friar Tuck. This bold robber was hotly pursued at various times by the Sheriff of Nottingham, but was very successful in evading capture, in fact, it became unsafe for the Sheriff to pass through Sherwood Forest, although he was supposed to be in control of it. This game represents the attempt of the Sheriff to pass from the town of Nottingham to one of the King's Castles at the right hand of the board.

This is a Roll and Move game. On some spaces, players may lose turns or move back a few space. The first player to move from start to finish wins. Players must spin the exact number needed to win.

name: Intelligensspillet Investor
description:
Intelligensspillet Investor is an intelligence game with endless possibilities. It has to work formåk entertaining and educational. The rules and procedures of the game are broadly the same as those used in everyday life when you place (invisterer) money in real estate or mortgages.

The purpose of the game is to buy properties (there are 12 houses to choose from), pay out your mortgage - and avoid bankrupcy and foreclosure!
The game mechanism is a roulette with 12 (six large and six small) tiles - divided into five options;
- H: The six large green ones where you have to pay the rent for your house(s)
- D: One red where you pay taxes for roads and sewers
- S: Two reds where you pay Property Tax
- T: Two reds where you have to pay mortgage
- ?: Black where you have to pay out the last loan of the house.
Every player spin the wheel for EVERY property (s)he owns - if (s) owns more than one it is needed to state which house there is on spin.

If a player can't pay up and can't get money by other means the house will be set on auction.
The profit will go to the bankrupt seller.

The game is over after an agreed time, where every player sells there propertied back to the bank (they will get the price in the deed MINUS the eventually debt). The winner will be the one with most profit - or least loss.

Designed by real estate broker Aage Eliasen, Copenhagen

name: Merry Christmas Game
description:
Typical race spin and move game. First player, who cross 77 stations (24 of them are numbered) wins the game.
Game board is on the bottom of the box.

name: Just For Kicks New Frontier
description:
J.F.K.'s "Just For Kicks New Frontier Game" is based on President John F. Kennedy, his family and his politics.

Game play: roll the dice, move exact spaces, take a card and follow the instructions written on them.

The object of the game is to reach the White House before your opponents. The first player to enter the White House wins and is President; 2nd - Attorney General; 3rd - Secretary of State and the last one becomes Vice President.

Games pieces include:
1 die
4 tokens (white token is the PT-109, red token is a bottle of scotch, blue token is a football and the silver token is a cracked spaceship)
20 Brownies Ye Olde Apple Polish cards
20 Boner cards
1 game board 18 7/8" X 18 7/8".

name: El Gran Escape
description:
It's a roll and move game about fowarding pawns across a 50 boxes path with many traps and short-cuts. Its theme is about a persecution of a dangerous gangster, called "Mr. Kill" and his exotic gang.

The game was a board made with collectible stickers as a promotional resource of a Chilean Gas Station Company (COPEC) in year 1988.
mechanics: Action/Event, Roll / Spin and Move, Track Movement

name: The Coon Hunt Game
description:
This is a simple spin and move game where you begin your adventure from Uncle Hastus, follow the directions on the stops and should come back to Uncle first to win the game.

Complete game: 6 wooden game pieces, spinner, & box. The bottom of the box is the game board.

name: The Cadet Game
description:
The object of the game is to reach West Point, the first player to do so wins the game. Players spin the dial and advance their counter as many spaces as the number spun.

If the counter rests upon a space with the picture of cannon on it, players follow the instructions: lose next turn, start over again, move up to next player, all players move one space forward, etc.

If it rests upon a space with a star, the player reads the meaning, which does not affect the game, such as: You will marry young and happy; You will become a great general etc.

name: The Little Soldier Boy
description: Typical race spin and move game. The first player who travel from "Home" to "Commander in Chief" wins the game.

name: VludKin ClaNz
description:
VludKin ClaNz is a card game for two players about the struggle of the VludKin for control over the Vlud, the energy upon which their world is built. Each player starts with two VludKin cards from different ClaNz, and their goal is to not have the lowest influence VludKin when the game ends, and therefore be the player controlling the Vlud.

This is an original "stack-building" card game for two players, with a set of rules that are quick and simple to learn, but offering numerous strategic options and dirty tricks on the path to victory.

Each player receives two random VludKin cards from different ClaNz, and during the game they draw a card from the central deck which they then try to win with one of their VludKin, rolling over that VludKin's Influence modified by the card. If this card is an Influence card, they can then place it under one of the VludKin, altering their Influence value based on the Clan type shown on the card. If it's a Power card, then they can carry out the special action on that card before it is discarded.

Failing to win a card will earn the VludKin a -1 Influence token to their total, and they can get rid of these only through trading an Influence card matching their Clan or the use of certain power cards, which might actually move all the tokens to an enemy instead. If an Influence card is failed, then the other player gets a chance to win it. If a Power card is failed, then the power is automatically played by the enemy VludKin opposite; sometimes it's in your advantage to fail a Power card...

During the game, the stacks of cards under each VludKin are built, changing their Influence up and down over turns until the game ends and the player with the lowest VludKin loses. With the ability to play Influence cards on the other player's VludKin and with the use of Power cards to move Influence cards around the stacks, a level of strategy is added to the simple core rules.

The game ends when either a VludKin reaches ten Influence or the central deck is empty, so through the use of Influence and Power cards a tense game builds in which the balance of Influence can change right up to the end on the asymmetrical board game playfield. There is little down time for the players and no hidden hands of cards, so this provides an exciting head-to-head experience.

VludKin ClaNz comes with eight VludKin from four ClaNz, two copies of each of the twelve different power cards, and forty Influence cards. Adding extra sets of the Power and Influence cards gives you the option to customize the central deck to how you want to play, and also gives the option for a longer game.

Can you gain influence over the VludKin in this original card game?

name: Hunt and Seek Young Xpert
description:
Hunt and Seek™ Young Xpert is for youngsters who love challenges. Like the other games in the series, this game develops a child’s reactions, sense of observation, visual acuity and concentration. Numbers written in French and English allow children to learn the basics of reading a second language. Different levels in the game add to the challenge.

The aim of the game is to find 50 objects hidden in the beautifully illustrated game boards. Other challenges face players who may try to locate the little mouse found in different locations on the game boards or find the six mystery characters.

name: Battle Market
description: Battle Market is one part financial management game and one part fight to the death. You go around the board buying property and paying rent. Along the way, each property you control grants you a special power. Most of these special powers are useful for attacking your rivals. Unlike most games in this genre, the ultimate goal isn't to bankrupt the other players, but to kill them.
mechanics: Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Trading

name: Pooch
description:
POOCH: "A New Exciting Game of Dogs That Try To Outsmart The Ever Watchful Dog Catcher"

Dogs have wandered far from their homes and kennels, and now try to get back without being caught by the dog catcher.

Game includes a blow-molded plastic base, four plastic dog tokens, a dog catcher truck, and a spinner.

name: Grid-Hammer
description:
Grid-Hammer is a tabletop game for 2 to 4 players that's played on a 9x9 square board called the "Grid". The object of the game is to move any one of your ten pieces across the Grid and past your opponents' defenses, then exit with this piece off the opposite side of the board.

Pieces move, climb, rotate, capture, transform, and combine into new hybrid pieces as they surge across the board and off the Grid.

Grid-Hammer is themed on the Grid itself. What would an ecosystem populated by grid creatures look like?

name: Battle Mice
description:
Battle Mice is a near-perfect information card game for two players.

The deck consists of three identical sets of mice numbered 1–8. Each player receives one deck, then the last "neutral" deck is shuffled, two of those cards are put aside, and the rest dealt three to each player. Each player then places his first eight mice in a 3x3 grid with the middle square left empty. The neutral mice are kept as a hand of cards.

On a player's turn, he can move one mouse one step. A mouse that moves into the middle empty square has escaped, and the opponent's mouse with the same number is defeated (turned over). Each mouse has a special ability that affects only the two adjacent mice; for example, the fighter mouse protects the adjacent mice from being defeated, the nurse mouse heals a defeated mouse, the speed mouse allows adjacent mice to move twice, and so on. Each time a mouse exits, the active player can place a neutral mouse from his hand on one of the corner squares, if available.

At the end of the game, players receive one point per escaped mouse, but some of the mice give an extra bonus depending on the order in which they escaped. This order is determined by the two neutral mice set aside at the start of the game.

name: Fisherman's Profit
description:
Fisherman's Profit is a simple bluffing "outsmart the others" card game based on the Japanese proverb "If snipe and seashell fight, the fisherman profits", meaning that if two struggle, a third party wins.

From a deck of either blue or red seashells of different values, three cards are placed face down on the play area, and in turn, players peek at the unoccupied seashells, then place either a fisherman or a snipe on one of them. When all have placed, the seashells are turned up and resolved: Blue seashells can be taken only by snipes, and red only by the fishermen. If two have placed on the same, the latter will steal a previously claimed seashell from the former — but if both fisherman and snipe are on the same seashell, the fisherman profits according to the old proverb and both gets the seashell and catches the bird.

name: D.D. Dogma
description:
D.D. Dogma is a party-style card game simulating the back-and-forth dialogue between roleplayers and the game master in an RPG session.

Each player selects a team of heroes from the available line-up, then receives six quest cards and a number of play cards that signify dice numbers.

Taking turns, players ask an opponent for a quest; that player unveils one of his quests, then the asking player tries to solve the quest by rolling as many dice as he has heroes, activating their abilities to generate resources such as "battle", "magic", "thievery" and so on. Each quest has its own clear requirements, and if the player manages to generate the correct resources, he gains the victory points the quest generates; if not, these points go to the quest owner.

After the dice roll, players can adjust the values of the dice by playing cards from their hands, either elevating, lowering or re-rolling the dice rolled. After this is done, the dice are applied to the lineup of heroes, activating different abilities.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hand Management, Role Playing

name: Rune Crash
description:
Rune Crash is an abstract board game from 1 to 4 players where the goal is to have the most knowledge points at the end of the game.

Combine 3 or more runes in a line and get the knowledge points. Explore the power of the special runes and be careful with the bombs that will sabotage your discoveries.

In the Solitary rules your objective is to get as many Dolmens as possible before the 40 round.

•••

Rune Crash es un juego abstracto jugable de 1 a 4 jugadores donde la meta es obtener la mayor cantidad de puntos al final del juego.

Combina 3 o mas runas en linea para obtener los puntos de conocimiento. Explora el poder de las runas especiales y ten cuidado con las bombas que sabotearan tus descubrimientos.

En el modo solitario el objetivo es obtener la mayor cantidad de dolmenes antes del round 40.
mechanics: Pattern Building, Pattern Recognition, Set Collection, Take That

name: Los Señores del Mal
description:
Its not easy to be a Master of Evil. The working hours suck... Finding efficient minions is a pain... and keeping your well-earned treasure safe from the hands of the so called "Heroes" ends up being a full-time job. But... this is YOUR JOB and fame in the Inner Circle of Evil is everything to you so why not show the other Masters how a demonic job is really done! Masters of Evil is a game for 1 to 6 players where each player takes the role of an Evil Master that is repelling the attack of a variety of heroes trying to gain as much reputation as possible by imprisoning the heroes when defeated.

At the beginning of the game 5 hero cards are dealt to each player so 3 can be chosen. Those heroes will be attacking your Den. Each turn a Monster is Summoned and you will have to place one of your minion tokens on one of your heroes that have that monster symbol. If you complete a card by filling all the monster, traps, and spells symbols you defeat that hero and can claim it as a reward by imprisoning him/her into your dungeon cell. Some heroes provide a special reward when defeated... from adding an extra monster to getting a special Overlord ability.

After placing minions a die is rolled to determine if a type of hero attacks. To repel an attack you can remove monsters from that hero card for a value equal, bigger or lower than the hero attack (defined by the roll of 1D6). If you repel the complete attack you are undamaged. If you repel a portion you can get the rest of the damage by reducing your life (which begins with 10). Also you can simply nullify the attack of a hero by distracting them with one of your treasures. Spells can be used to change the summoned monster type and Traps can nullify any attack (even if they are not in the card of an attacking hero).

When the 6th hero is collected by any player the game is over and the scoring phase begins. Players get the points in the hero cards but also get points for the most types of each monster and if they collect at least 3 cards of a Hero Type.


No es facil ser un Señor del Mal. Las horas a las que hay que levantarse apestan... Encontrar sirvientes eficientes es un dolor de medula... Y conservar tu "bien merecido" tesoro de las garras de los heroes termina siendo un trabajo full-time. Pero es tu OFICIO y la fama adquirida en el circulo Interno de la Maldad lo es todo para ti... asi que porque no mostrar a los demas Señores como se hace un buen trabajo demoniaco! En los Señores del Mal los jugadores toman el rol de Señores Oscuros que estan repeliendo el ataque de audaces heroes aprisionandolos cuando son derrotados para asi ganar la tan preciada fama.

Al comienzo del juego se entregaran 5 cartas de heroe a cada jugador de las que seran elegidas 3. Esos heroes atacaran tu Guarida. Cada turno sera Invocado un Monstruo y tendras que colocar un token de minion en uno de los heroes que tenga en su carta a dicho monstruo disponible. Si completas todos los slots de la carta derrotas al heroe y puedes reclamar la recompensa aprisionandolo en una celda. Algunos heroes proveen recompensas especiales cuando son derrotados... desde otorgar un monstruo extra a darle al Overlord una habilidad permanente.

Luego de colocar los minions se tira un dado para determinar el tipo de heroe que atacara. Para repeler un ataque se pueden remover monstruos de la carta de dicho heroe por un valor igual, superior o inferior que el ataque del heroe (definido por un D6). Si repeles completamente el ataque no eres dañado. Si solo se repele una porcion recibes el resto del daño reduciendo tu vida (que comienza en 10). Tambien puedes anular un ataque entregandole uno de tus tesoros. Los hechizos pueden ser usados para invocar un monstruo diferente del que se ha invocado y las Trampas anulan cualquier ataque (incluso si no estan en la carta del heroe atacante)

Cuando un jugador aprisiona a su sexto heroe el juego termina y comienza la ronda de puntaje. Los jugadores obtienen puntos por cada heroe capturado, pero tambien por mayoria de determinado tipo de monstruo y variedad de heroes.
mechanics: Open Drafting, Pattern Recognition, Set Collection

name: Portholes
description:
Portholes is a space strategy game set in the LUNA-2 space prison.

Plot: A digital voice: "auto-destruct sequence initiated"... The doors of the prison cells open automatically. Four convicts: thieves, assassins, tax evaders and politicians, have to find a way to ignite the safety pod engines and flee LUNA-2 space station.

Gameplay: miniature tactical game with cards, equip items, custom dice combat system and tile portals.

One of the players controls the guards, and the other player(s) control the convicts.

GOAL: Find the the RED key needed to reach the safety pod, place the "Power cell", re-activate KAL 9000, ignite the engines and flee LUNA-2 space prison.

If the convicts' HP reach zero, the guards win.
mechanics: Action Queue, Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling

name: Deductio
description:
Deductio is a French card game for 2-8 players.

The rules of the game

Beginner

Choose the number of cards you want to play with. To start, 3 cards per player are dealt.

Example : you have 3 players and you decide to play with 3 cards. Take the numbered cards from 1 to 10. Mix them up, and distribute them face down. The last card is placed onto the table.

The oldest player begins. He multiplies a couple of his cards and then announces the result.

Example : the first player has cards 2, 5 and 8. Consequently he can associate 3 couples of cards : 2 and 5, 2 and 8, 5 and 8. He chose the first and declares : "10".

His opponents have to deduce which couple it is.

Example : to obtain 10, you can either have the 2 and the 5, or the 1 and the 10. In that case, the second player has the 1 : thus he validates the first hypothesis.

Players take turns in a clockwise direction declaring a multiple, until one player has identified which card is on the table. He says "Deductio" and declares the number of the hidden card without showing the card to the others. If he is right, he scores a point. If he can identify the cards in each player's hand without any mistake, he scores a bonus point, and the hand is over. If he is wrong, he loses 1 point and the hand goes on.

The first player to score 10 points wins the game.

Experienced

Play with 4 cards or more following the same rules. The number of possible couples (for example, 6 couples for 4 cards) and the multiples related to each value increase.

In turns, each player can play the joker card. He puts it in front of him and turns it face down once used. It will allow him to pass his turn once without declaring any number. It can be played at any time.

name: Eat Lead, Undead!
description:
The world has come to an end, and zombies, vampires and other horrors run rampant in the street. You and your group of survivors have one chance to get out alive. You've got to mow down hordes of oncoming undead and gather enough supplies to escape the city. Of course some of you might not make it out alive...

Eat Lead, Undead! is a frantic game of dart gun mayhem! Each turn, players move their survivors amidst hordes of swarming undead, which lurk behind stand-up scenery. Players then all fire their dart guns as much as they can for thirty seconds to protect their survivor — or perhaps wound a rival. Any survivor in a clear sector may gather equipment, while those who are wounded return home empty-handed. The first person to get the right combination of equipment escapes the city and wins!

Eat Lead, Undead! combines elements of Run, Fight or Die and City of Horror with the unique dexterity mechanism of dart guns for a riotous and unique co-op/competitive experience.

name: Shoot'n' Hoops
description:
The Exciting Mini BasketBall Game. (From the Box)

The players take turns to flip mini basketballs into a multi hoop stand each hoop scoring different points, 4 balls per player with 9 hoops to target, highest score wins. An Alternative / Solo game option of 'three in a row / Tic-Tac-Toe' challenge is also suggested in the how to play guide.

name: Not A Step Backwards (Ne Shaga Nazad) 1941-1942
description:
Easy to play Strategic/operational wargame Series covering the entire Eastern Front. This first game covers 1941-42. 10 Miles to the hex. 5-10 day turns depending on weather and time of the year. Divisional/Brigade/Regimental-level for Germans and Allies and Corps/Divisions/Brigades for Soviets. Logistics, air and naval effects. Two campaign games are included: June 1941 and 1942. And, includes several one and two map scenarios.

Command and variable movement system that includes cards that add random events and historical flavor, but do not drive the game. Political rules and both sides have their own unique way of play to show their historical capabilities and tendencies. New unit production and reinforcements.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hexagon Grid, Secret Unit Deployment
publishers: (Looking for a publisher), Heritage Game Studios

name: ZULU!! Battles of Rorke's Drift and Isandlhwana 1879
description:
Never published.

Zulu!! is Richard Berg’s game series (Great Battles for Empire). It is unlike anything you’ve seen or played before. (Yes, that’s marketing hyperbole, but go along with us on this.) Zulu!! has no hexes, no squares, and is not point-to-point. It also has counters with no ratings. In some ways, it’s like cardboard miniatures … with fewer rules. In that sense, it will be something new for many boardgamers.

Using a slight variation of Ye Olde Igo-Hugo play sequence, the game system highlights the firepower of the British Martini Henry rifle, the value of a solid defensive position, and the greatly superior numbers of the three Zulu Amibutho (divisions) that gave them something like 40-1 numerical superiority at times. And all of this without having to move hundreds of counters around, another innovation. The map scale is 1” = 4 yards. All of which plays in a couple of hours.

name: Walker Wars
description:
Each player controls a number of characters. Each character receives a rating in each of the following attributes: strength, mobility, senility, and vigor. The player divides twelve points among these four attributes but no attribute may have a rating greater than six. The gameboard is a 17 x 11 hex grid devoid of obstacles.

A player’s turn consists of three phases wherein a player may try to move any or all of his/her units: Senility check (roll a D6, if the die roll is greater than the unit’s senility rating, then the unit may not move this turn), Movement (any unit that can move may do so), and Combat (units in the same hex as an opponent’s hex may duke it out).

A player is eliminated from play when all of his/her units are eliminated. The sole survivor is the winner.

This game takes up the last 4 1/2 pages of the Macho Women with Guns: The Final Chapter (Part One) rules supplement.
mechanics: Action Queue, Point to Point Movement, Take That

name: New York, New York, August-September, 1776
description:
New York, New York... is a game covering the invasion of this key American colonial city by what was the largest invasion force - men and ships - ever assembled by the British in 1776.

The game can be played by one or two players, or more, if they like to argue about who gets to do what. Which would provide an interesting piece of Reality. The heart of the game is the Activation system, which requires the players to purchase (with a constantly varying number of Initiative Points). The game-map uses a scale of ca.650 yards per hex. Each game-turn (there are ten) represents a day of real time. Most units are regiments or battalions.

The game includes: •• 1 33”x 22” game map •• 1 Sheet of 280 counters •• 20 Op Cards (10 British, 10 American) •• 12 Pages of rather Revolutionary rules.
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Hexagon Grid

name: The Notre Dame Trivia Game
description: Players must obtain six different colored headquarters chips by correctly answering trivia questions about the University of Notre Dame. Question order is determined based on where a player lands on the board using a die roll. Once all six chips have been obtained, the player moves to a leprechaun space in the center of the board and answers a question in the category of their opponent's choosing. Once this is answered correctly, the player must return to their start space and answer another question of the category that matches the start space color. If incorrect, the player loses that color chip and must move around the board to correctly answer a question of that category and retrieve the missing chip. If correct, the game is won.

name: Yamato 2199 Game: Chapter 7 – The Plot to Assassinate Desler
description:
Political conflict game based on Japanese animation series Space Battleship Yamato 2199. The name and cover art is inspired from The Plot to Assassinate Hitler, but the game mechanics are totally different.

Players control one of the political factions in the Gamilas Empire. Each faction has a different goal and special action.

Each turn, players take three actions from any combination of Draw new chit, Special actions, and Recruit a character.

The drawn chit represent a character or a event. An event is resolved by using the characters. The result affects the victory points of the faction and the stability of the Empire. Most events need cooperation to achieve.

The winner is determined by victory points.

The game includes a rulebook, a game map, and 50 die-cut counters.
categories: Movies / TV / Radio theme, Political, Science Fiction
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Cooperative Game, Variable Player Powers

name: Kanoshita
description:
This is a party game based on guessing what type of panties a person might wear if they were to go on a date. 5 situation cards are laid on the table. These cards ask "What kind of girl is she," "What kind of guy is he," "How did they meet," "When is their date," and "Where will they go on their date?" Each player fills out the back of the situation card in dry-erase marker.

The answers to the situation are shown, and one designated player has to decide what style and color of panties a person in the presented situation would wear. They also lay out 3 pairs of underwear that they do not think would be appropriate for this situation. To denote this, 4 point tokens are placed face down, marking which style they think is best, ok, neutral, and inappropriate.

The remaining players then have to vote on which pair they think is the best. The face down point tokens are shown, and points for correct guesses are accumulated.

This process repeats as the players rotate, so that each player has the chance to try every role.
categories: Bluffing, Deduction, Humor, Mature / Adult, Party Game

name: Kokkuri Jinro
description:
Kokkuri Jinro is a simple and quick Werewolf-game using the mechanism from the Japanese traditional "boogie board" fortune-telling method in which people sitting around a table keep their index finger on a coin that glides around a piece of paper with letters on it.

In this take on the traditional Werewolf game — with villagers trying not to be eaten while the secret werewolf player tries to do snack on the villagers — no one ever closes their eyes; instead only the Werewolf player is allowed to steer the coin, and the other players try to find out who that guy is.

If the coin reaches a player, that player loses a life; each player has two lives to start, and if they lose both lives, they're out of the game. After someone loses a life from the coin, the players discuss and vote on who to string up, and that player also loses one life.

Players out of the game reveal who they were. The game continues until either the Werewolf dies (in which case the villagers win) or only two players remain, with the Werewolf being one of them (in which case the Werewolf wins).
mechanics: Team-Based Game, Variable Player Powers, Voting

name: Jinro Gaiden
description:
User summary:

A Werewolf-type game where there is no hidden killing during the night phase, but instead all killed players vote on who to curse to death.

Each player also has an open character that has a special power.
mechanics: Team-Based Game, Variable Player Powers, Voting

name: Naked Formular
description:
User summary:

Naked Formular (sic!) is a Formula 1-themed hand management card game.

During setup, the race track is decided by placing a set number of track cards face down in a circle. During the game, one card at a time will be turned face up, and for each track card, players will play cards from hand, competing for being in first place for that specific card. What cards are good to play depends on the number and type (straight, chicane or corner) of the track card.

When a player plays a card, if another player has 2 cards of that number in his hand, he can nullify the card played, steal it and put in in front of him. This protects him a while from getting overtaken.

name: Bustar Wars
description:
User summary:

A cooperative game based on various SF-themed anime TV shows. Players are pilots of various space craft and try to destroy the Dead Star before the enemy invades their base.

The game is played on a 12x3 square gridded board. All players line up their crafts to the left, and the enemy crafts are lined up on the board's right. Players are dealt 5 cards each of which they choose 3 to play face down. When all have chosen, players turn their cards face up and the players execute their cards in order of speed on the cards. Players who end up having the same speed are blocked and their turns are skipped.

After all players have done, dice are rolled to determine what the enemy crafts do (attack or move). If the players manage to reach the far end of the game board, they win. If all players are killed, or the enemy reaches the left of the game board, the players lose.

The game also comes with optional difficulity rules, and one of them include a traitor mechanism.
categories: Movies / TV / Radio theme, Science Fiction
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Hand Management, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Soramimi Fantasy
description:
User summary:

An cooperative adventure game where players explore a map, trying to empower themselves as much as possible before the time runs out and they have to battle the Demon Lord.

The game is played with a music player playing instructions, randomized from a play list – the voice of the captive princess that guides the players (in the right or wrong direction). Instructions include "go west" or "don't go north" or "gain a life" and so on.

The game includes a possible traitor mechanism: One of the players might be the demon lord in disguise, which is why players also have to be wary.

The game ends when a player decides to fight the Demon Lord, or the random player has selected "place a token on the Demon Castle" three times, at which point the Demon Lord is revealed and the players compare their strengths with the enemy. Most powerful side wins.

The princess's voice is done by Kurumi Miru.
mechanics: Area Movement, Cooperative Game, Variable Player Powers

name: Marches of Mists
description:
Marches of Mists is a fantasy board/card game using the exclusive DCSP (Dynamic Card Placement System) mechanic, created by Bruno Gaia and co-designed by Youri Faja.

Using the mechanics of deck building, popular since Dominion, Marches of Mists widely differs from its ancestor due to the DCPS, a mechanic that allows and favours direct interaction while adding various notions to the placement of cards (like variation of speed in the player's progress on the board, disruption of the player's orders, targeting the opponent's positions, etc.) The DCPS is the result of years of research conducted by Bruno Gaia to find a brand new way of using cards in board games.

In Marches of Mists, players battle to slay enemy hero tokens and destroy the opponent's population. The game ends -and the counting of victory points starts- whenever a player's population reaches zero, four recruitment piles are empty or a player has lost his last hero token.

The game is played by two players or any multiple of two, using an extra copy of the game for each extra pair of players. When more than two players are around the table, Marches of Mists is played as a team battle with phases of interaction between allies known as Councils; it is an epic experience that needs perfect knowledge of the game's cards and strategies, especially when more than four players are involved.

Set in a singular fantasy world, Marches of Mists is currently illustrated by Camille Mazauric and it is the first game developed by Bruno Gaia with the help of Youri Faja, the designer of "Requiem".
mechanics: Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Hand Management, Pattern Building

name: Reversi Barbacan
description:
This box combines Reversi and Barbacan.

Barbacan can be played by two to six players. They try to be the first to get their men from the board's circumference into the castle by moving the pieces along the defined lines. An edition published in the 1920s also permitted to move them around the two circles outside the castle, which were omitted from later designs.

In Reversi, players must trap other pieces between their own to capture them (flip them to their color). Pieces will change sides (colors) dozens of times. The winner is the one with the most pieces of their color when no more pieces can be played on the board.

name: Il Gioco di Robinson
description:
Exciting adventures await you with the game of super secret agents between cities, deserts, wetlands and glaciers. Find maps for credentials or the Top Secret Papers. There are two ways to win the game: passing the skills tests 5 or dial the name ROBINSON using the Top Secret papers.
Roll the die and move your secret agent around the Board. On the box where you stop get the info you need to win the game.
Along the way on board take TOP SECRET papers or CREDENTIALS cards or confronts evidence that are required.

name: Happy Hoppers
description:
Each player's force consists of ten pieces. The object of the game is for each player to try to get two of his pieces on to the squares of his opponent. That is, if he starts from the Starred squares, his object is to get two of his pieces on any two of the Crescent squares.

The game is won when one of the players succeeds in getting any Two of his pieces upon the squares from which his opponent's pieces started, or it is won if one of the players entirely destroys the other player's forces.

name: Athletic Sports
description:
Athletic Sports is a typical spin and move board game: move the indicator and move down the track as many spaces as spun. First player to cross the finish space wins the game.

Contents: Instructions on the inside of the box top, 4 Wood pegs (2 are larger), 2 spinners, and the game board, which is on the bottom of the box.

name: Stöngin inn: íslenska fótboltaspilið
description: A soccer simulation for 2 players. Each player is dealt 5 cards which are used to move the ball around the field. The field is divided into squares and on each card there are numbers that indicate the direction the ball can move and how long. When the cards can be used to move the ball into the goal the player scores. When the deck of cards runs out it's half time, the deck is shuffled and the second half is played in the same way as the first one.

name: Myron Cope's Official Triple Yoi! Game
description:
This game is a trivia game bearing the name of Myron Cope, former color commentator for the Pittsburgh Steelers.

The instructions say this game is to be played while watching football, and when "your favorite team" does good things listed in the instructions (touchdown, interception of other team, first down, etc) to spin the spinner and contribute a chip of the color of the region to a kitty. There are 6 regions, 2 of each color red, yellow or blue. However, on half of the six regions, one for each color, the spinning player is supposed to also take trivia cards, and save them until a commercial break or a penalty in which that player will be asked the questions by the player to his left. For each question the player answers he gets chips from the other players if correct, gives chips if incorrect. The color of the chips exchanged are based on the difficulty of the trivia question, with yellow being the easiest , red in the middle, and blue the hardest. Once the questions are asked, play rotates to the next player to be in charge of the spinner during the next bit of football action. Chips are given and gotten, but no one is ever eliminated, just the balance of chips sways. Player in charge of the spinner when time expires also gets the contents of the kitty being collected through the game. Chips won from the various rounds of trivia, as well as the kitty are totaled. The chips yellow, red and blue are worth 1,2,and 3 point respectively. Player with the most chips is the winner.

Having heard sports commentators, including Myron, I believe this game is supposed to feel like being a color commentator, where during the football game you do not say much, but then when nothing is happening, the color commentator sweeps in with his trivia, stories, or other banter.

name: Robot Combat
description:
A game of robot combat for 2 – 4 players

Robot Combat is a game of arena-style robot combat.

In Robot Combat you randomly pick a combat style robot, which you will maintain, upgrade and fight within the Robot Combat arena. You start with a basic level 1 combat robot and your goal is to improve upon your robot design by upgrading to the strongest level 3 robot and winning the championship. You can do this by winning auctions for new or used robot parts or winning a robot combat match!
You are given a chassis type, an initial drive train, armor, a weapon systems, a motor system, and 12 voltage batteries for each system; everything! During phases of the game you can either bid on new types of Robot Parts for a better deal OR bid on used parts directly from players.

You begin with a small amount of funds to help you upgrade your robot. When you are ready and your robot is fully functional, you can place your robot on the competition circuit and fight against other robots for prizes or money! In the end there can only be one combat champion robot!

During combat you will use movement cards to control your robot's drive system within the combat arena to help maneuver your robot into the best fighting position with your weapon. Watch out though, as you move or get knocked around the arena, the combat arena has offensive and defensive weapon systems of its own such as; spikes, ramps, saws, lifters, hammers, etc... these systems try to destroy or inhibit your robot! If your robot becomes immobile, you lose and the match is over!

The combat arena is a hex style attack grid.

As you move your robot around the arena you will try to make contact with your opponent which will cause either LIGHT, MEDIUM, OR HEAVY damage. The damage to your opponent’s robot will depend on the level of your weapon or the level of the robot! Also, when you make contact you can cause different issues with the robots such as; power failure, loss of control, loss of maneuverability, electronic failure, motor failure, battery failure, etc... These different issues will cause robot part to breakdown. When a breakdown occurs, you can repair the part or replace it with another part. Each part has a life span and can only be repaired once, the second time the part breaks down it’s destroyed!

Robot Combat is a turn-based system with rounds and phases. In between matches you will be able to sell or buy new or used parts for your robot to help fix or repair the broken parts before the next match; if you can't fix your robot before the next match, you will have to sit out of the competition until your robot is fully functional.

Winning each match earns you a trophy and money or parts, if you can upgrade your robot to the highest level and win the most matches; you will earn glory and prestige to become the Robot Combat Champion!
categories: Card Game, Dice, Fighting, Industry / Manufacturing, Miniatures, Print & Play
mechanics: Action Queue, Grid Movement, Hand Management, Hexagon Grid

name: Tomb of the Mummies
description: Tomb of the Mummies is kind of like an Indiana Jones or Mummy film. Each player is an archeologist searching a tomb for treasures. Players move along the maze like paths built by tile laying. Attempting follow hieroglyphic clues they find on each tile that they stop on, the players use deduction to find relics, which can protect them from mummies. They search for treasure which they must take out of the tomb to win, but which slows them down so that the mummies may catch up with them. Each player controls 1 archeologist and 1 mummy. Each player hides treasure, relics, mummy and various traps. The fun is in searching for treasure while attempting to avoid mummies and traps.
mechanics: Memory, Modular Board, Point to Point Movement

name: Bustar Wars: The Fleet of Führer Besler
description:
User summary:

An expansion that includes tons of special enemy tiles of an extra fleet that you use instead of the standard Zafs. This makes the game quite more taxing.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Science Fiction
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Hand Management, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Pocket Paddles
description:
Pocket Paddles is a free print and play game for two players that fits in your wallet. All you need to play is the credit card-sized gameboard and 7 coins per player.

In Pocket Paddles players compete in a furious paddle boat race. Whoever lands three ships on the sandy shores of Victor Island first, is declared winner, and is rewarded the platinum-power-paddle. The coins act as currency in a blind-bidding and bluffing round, in which the movement of your ships is determined. However, these coins also act as ships. Therefore, placing ships on the board drains your bidding resources.

Tactics, wits and some winds of fate will carry the winner to Victor Island.

name: Spurt að leikslokum: Fjölskyldupakkinn
description: This is a compilation of four expansions to the Spurt að leikslokum trivia game. The expansions are Úr ýmsum áttum, Popp - dægurmál - afþreying, HM í fótbolta and Fyrir 7-12 ára. Each contains 540 new questions.

name: Quirkative Joker Poker
description:
Game time is variable based on number of players and rounds you chose to play. Each round has 5 simple stages. You have 2 early decisions to make, then sit back and watch the round unfold. Each round has 1 winner and 1 loser.

Each player starts the game with 3 Heart Tiles, 2 QJP Tiles and 1 Joker Tile. Each player gets dealt 2 cards (as in poker).

The first choice is do you use a QJP tile? This will change 1 or both of your starting cards. You can then choose to use your Joker. If you play your Joker and you end the round with the best hand you win an extra Heart Tile. If you have the worst hand, then you don't lose a heart tile.

The hand then plays out, as it would in poker, however, hands are all revealed so everybody can see what people have. There is no gambling. You all see how everybody gets on. Then the player with the worst hand, loses a heart. If you lose all your hearts then you are out. Last player standing wins.

Although the game uses a poker mechanic, it differs as all players show their hand, so there is no gambling. It turns it into a co-operative game style with lots of players hoping one will do badly. It also differs from poker with the use of the QJP, Joker and Heart based structure, which are tokens/tiles and not gambling chips.

name: Behind the Lines
description:
Game in the Hotspur Book for Boys, a 1980 children's Annual. Three different routes lead to the general's HQ. Players dice for starting route. Those starting from routes A or B are Allied Agents. Those starting from Route C are the Gestapo.

The game is a simple roll and move game where you must follow instructions on special squares. Unusually for these type of games, if you land on the same space as another player, you must "fight to the death". Each player rolls one die repeatedly until one player rolls a six. That player 'kills' the other player. A "Dead Man" is out of the game. First to reach the HQ wins.
categories: Children's Game, Spies/Secret Agents, World War II

name: Carter's Quest
description:
Venture deep into the hidden, subterranean passages of Tutankhamen's tomb to locate the four temples devoted to the deities that protect the pharaoh in the Netherworld. Upon entering each of the four temples, the player must defeat the Temple Guardian and return the funerary jars to the King's Treasury — all before Khepri raises the new sun.

Carter's Quest is solitaire tile-laying adventure game set in the 1920s. Portraying the world-famous archaeologist Howard Carter, the player lays tiles beginning at the King's Treasury and must find the four funerary jars and return them to the Treasury before the sun rises. Along the way, the player will collect weapons and provisions to help defend himself from the wrath of the deadly, sometimes poisonous, creatures inhabiting Tutankhamen's tomb. Find the jars, return them to the Treasury and save the world. Otherwise, you're devoured by the Pharaoh's curse.

Carter's Quest is a variant of Zombie in my Pocket, but this game employs a unique, dice-rolling combat system in which the items a player finds are used to modify the combat roll. Players are also at risk of being poisoned by some of the creatures in the game and will need to find the antidote or rest in the Priest's Temple; otherwise they will be consumed by the toxins and lose the game.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Modular Board, Open Drafting, Tile Placement

name: Kinetic
description:
From the Museum of Modern Art, NY.

Each piece has two sides, yellow and blue, each with a white edge. The nine pieces go in the 9 squares. Each player can choose to turn or twist one piece on their move in an attempt to get three with the white lines at the top.

name: Ric Rak Roll
description:
Ric Rak Roll is a spin off of Tic Tac Toe, but with dice. This gives the game more strategy and a longer play time.

The goal of the game is to get three dice of the same number in a row, with at least two of those in your own color.

Each player takes turns rolling one die at a time and placing it on the board. Once the board is full players will roll a die of their color and swap it out for one already on the board (either theirs or their opponents'). Winner of three numbers in a row with their color being the most wins.

name: Cache Hunt
description:
Cache Hunt is a geocaching themed game, where (teams of) players are trying to be the first to find the Ultimate Cache. Cache is somewhere in the forest - but should the players take the paths or go offroad? - and to where exactly is the cache hidden? Cache Hunt has simple rules and plays in 15-20 minutes.

For playing Cache Hunt you'll need:

- player tokens
- 1 token for time track ("time token")
- 1 token for representing the geocache (some smaller geocoin, for example :)
- game tiles (36 pcs)
- rules
mechanics: Action Points, Grid Movement, Modular Board

name: Slimes: The Battle for the Boss Medallion
description:
The Boss Medallion is a relic awarded to various dungeon trash mobs and underlings that grants them the title of "Boss Monster". and Once there was a cave in which dwelled a dragon whelp who possessed such a Medallion. One day, the whelp came to this realization: if he is destined to grow up to become a mighty Dragon, a force powerful enough to threaten possibly even the world's existence, what use does he have for such trinkets?

And so begins the Battle for the Boss Medallion: a contest/game in which the dragon whelp has granted the opportunity to earn a Boss Title to one of the dungeon world's lowest inhabitants, the Slime!

(The competing Slime lieutenants (the players) each have 10 health and take turns playing their Slime minions (cards) onto the Play Pile following rules similar to the card game B.S. Whenever a lieutenant's Bluff is called, a duel follows, with the loser taking damage from the recently played Slime Minions. These tactics and blows are exchanged until only one lieutenant is left standing to claim the whelp's Medallion!)

Summary and Additional Notes:


Bluffing card game with Slime Combat!



Each deck features a different color mix of slimes.



Jokers and Slime abilities add even more strategy to the game.

name: Ucrónika
description:
Ucrónika is a card game which helps to develop imagination, creativity and improvisation.

The players turn into narrators of histories who take as a starting point a historical event from which they must create an alternative reality, besides the historical fact they will have to include in their history a series of narrative elements that will depend on the cabin in which they are in the gameboard, the other players may add new elements to the narration.

The object of the game is to earn more points than the others players. Each player can earn points as the narrator telling the story and as a player adding elements and asking the narrator.

name: Championship Speedway Racing StockCar Game
description:
A roll and move StockCar Racing game.

Roll 2 d6, move the number of spaces on higher of the d6. If doubles are rolled, you check the chart for lane changes and spaces moved.

Various spaces on the board may cause you to lose turn(s), drop back spaces, move forward spaces, go to Pit Row (causes you to restart lap) or lose the race.

First player to complete 5 laps wins.

Components: board, 6 pawns, 2d6, 2 1/64 scale die cast cars, instructions.

name: Hauler
description:
America has been fascinated by the big rig truck for decades. Kids make signals out the back window, just hoping to hear that horn blast away as the trucker goes by and we benefit everyday from these massive machines moving goods and materials from coast to coast over the maze of our highways. Hauler is a game dedicated to the Big Rig Trucker in all of us!

Hauler is a game for 2-5 players where the goal is to build a deck of resources that will give you the most victory points. VPs are earned on cards or by running routes off of route cards purchased with Green Stamps (Money in Trucker Lingo). Green Stamps are earned playing cards out of your hand each turn. Green stamps can be used on your turn to purchase route cards, truck cards, fuel cards or action cards.

The rules of the game are complex. Think of Hauler as part deck builder and part strategy board game. Each turn a player can drive up to 12 hours each turn per truck or you draw 5 cards from their deck and purchase additional cards based on the green stamp value of the cards in play. Of course, there are complications and strategy to be had, as other players may be eyeing the same route you just passed on picking up, or may get to a hitchhiker before you if you take an extra deckbuilding turn. The decision is yours, and makes for great strategic conundrums in this 90-120 minute game.
mechanics: Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Network and Route Building, Pick-up and Deliver

name: Mikawa Monogatari
description:
Issue game of Wargame Japanese History #17.

Campaign level wargame for the Ikko-shu uprising in the Mikawa province during the Japanese Sengoku Period. Mikawa is the home province of Tokugawa Ieyasu, the first Tokugawa shogun.
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_Azukizaka_(1564)

Story of the Mikawa Province, the Rioting record of Mikawa Province is a game using the basic engine of Taiheiki. Players control either the Tokugawa clan or the Uprising force of Ikko-shu. In each turn, players determine initiative, and then players move their own force alternately. Finally, after all movement is done, they resolve combat.

Winner determined by victory points, mostly earned from control of areas.

name: End of the World Card Game
description:
A zombie themed Cards Against Humanity. Each round, a player reads a survival scenario from a red "Survival" card, and all the other players answer with their best white "Provision" card(s).

The leader for each round then re-reads the red survival card and each of the provision cards, and selects their favorite to keep the group moving forward through the apocalypse. The winning survivor holds onto the red apocalyptic scenario card which equals one point.
Continue in clockwise fashion with a new leader reading in each round. Be sure to have 10 provision cards in your hand each round (unless increased or decreased by trump cards).

The provision deck includes 8 reanimation cards that players can keep and use to get a new hand, and 2 CDC cards that forces everyone to get new hands. The scenario deck includes 5 double tap cards where two 1-fer scenario cards are drawn and the played provision cards must apply to both.

name: Los Cazadores del Rey
description:
The King's Hunter is a fast game for 2-11 players, based on games of Family Werewolf, One Night Werewolf and One Night Ultimate Werewolf, and the basic system is based on the game Win, Lose, or Banana.

It's a micro-game of 16 cards.

This game is played in several rounds, determined at the beginning of the game.

The winner will be the player with the most points, or most money with the betting game.

A role card is dealt to each player. King, Queen, and Hunters show their role card, Werewolves and Vampires don´t show it. First the King will draw one of the two cards of Gods (Favour of the gods or No Favour of the gods). Afterwards the King will order hunt Werewolves or Vampires. Hunters will think first to retire or not to retire. If they decide to hunt, they must fight with the beast orders by the King. Queen will be a partnership of the King.
categories: Bluffing, Card Game, Deduction, Economic, Fantasy, Murder/Mystery, Print & Play, Real-time
mechanics: Betting and Bluffing, Player Elimination, Team-Based Game, Voting

name: Moscow vs. Barbarossa, 1941
description:
A small-scale (9 hexes from Smolensk to Moscow, 27mis/43kms per hex) Battle of Moscow game, MvB41 has 32 Russian and 22 German corps-to-army-level units, and takes 2-3 hours to play 8 half-month turns (or less, if Moscow is taken).

MvB41 draws on many design concepts and much research from my other games, including and especially from my new division level Battle of Moscow game, Barbarossa's Climax: Moscow 1941

As for most of my other games, the game's system uses Disruption to simulate momentum of advance/retreat and inertia. A powerful German panzerkorps has a combat power of 4, and German units have step reduction. The airwar is abstracted as in BC, and there is a Katyushas (rocket) unit.

The combat odds round-off (including UP) and expansion rule is retained from Barbarossa's Climax, as are other rules, but much more playably in the smaller - more introductory level - format.

The game is free to print off, assemble, and play.
categories: Print & Play, Wargame, World War II

name: Black Friday: The Card Game
