description:
"All the fun of beating up your fellow holiday shoppers and stealing stuff from their cart on Black Friday - without the risk of facing criminal charges for your bad behavior."

It's Black Friday, the first "official" shopping day for Christmas, all the sales, all the hype, all the bad behavior of fellow shoppers as 25 people vie for the 10 items available.

There's a limited number of Christmas Gifts available to the "shoppers", and some are more valuable (victory points) than others. There are opportunities to get a couple low value toys which compliment each other and give a score boost!

Then there are the Dirty Tactics that shoppers use to try to snatch Items from other shoppers' carts, and the Defensive Maneuvers that will keep your stuff safe!

As the shopping day progresses, Events will happen, where some circumstances may change, or they may only affect one shopper.

The shopping event ends when the "Check Out" card is drawn, which is randomly shuffled into the bottom of the draw deck. So get all your Items, try to snatch other shoppers' Items, and attempt to keep your Items safe until the sale is over!

name: F5
description:
"It's Construction vs. Destruction." "The game that throws strategy to the wind"

You all work for a construction company that builds trailer parks -sorry, "Luxury Manufactured Housing Gated Communities" in Tornado Alley. Construction picks up as the wind dies down. It's a race to cooperatively, yet strategically, build trailer parks to a minimum required size, get the gates installed and get the Construction Invoice in-hand, before a surprise tornado rips thru and erases all your hard work.

Tornado's range from F1 to F5, with appropriate varied damage. Tornadoes not only affect the trailer parks, but they can also force players to move positions at the table, make them trade hands, or even Invoices, with other players!

You'll never know what's coming down the line regarding tornadoes. During Set-up, you randomly and secretly select tornadoes to remove, and as you cycle thru the draw deck, you randomly and secretly remove additional tornadoes, so the tempo builds, the tension grows, and the game comes to a quick victory.

name: Talvisota
description:
Talvisota (Winter War) is a cooperative game for 2-4 players.

The players are finnish commanders in one of the four frontlines, and they have to cooperate together in order to stop the Soviet advance. They gain points by eliminating the attacking forces or by assisting other commanders. The game ends after 8 rounds, and then the person with the most points is the winner.

The game contains lots of cards, which feature historical persons, troops and equipment.
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Open Drafting

name: Ant Attack
description:
After the Great nuclear war... People are gone, Ants are Smart and the Backyard is at war!

Ant Attack is an exciting new 2 player card game of strategy requiring the correct amount of boldness, cunning and deception. As overall commander, you deploy your units and leaders onto the battlefield into well-tuned squads in attempt to destroy your enemy. Deploy snipers at the correct moment to wreak havoc on the less defended support units. Send your scouts out to discover the enemy’s true makeup. Know when to rally the troops and when to call for a truce.

Each game comes complete with 2 identical decks to begin your 6-legged struggle for control of the back yard.
publishers: HS3 Games, The Game Crafter, LLC

name: Dungeon Doors
description:
Be The Dungeon Hero or The Dungeon Boss! Devious Deceptions Galore!

THE DUNGEON HERO


You're a dangerous fool armed with a random Deathball!
Bash down doors with hate!
Imbibe mysterious potions!
Sleep in an inn--FTW!
Control giant Green Slimes with fire!
Destroy three Beholders and win the game!


THE DUNGEON BOSS


Shoot down your enemy's fireballs with the latest in Beholder Eye Beam technology!
Watch your pet Phoenix *EXPLODE* on its own!
Deploy your minions behind Red Doors of Doom!
Throw the Dungeon Zero's fireballs back at him!
Mentally push around your enemy through Secret Doors of your choice!
Your enemy only has 5HP? ...Cake!


Contents:

1 - Cuttable card of '1HP' tokens
2 - Rules cards
1 - Cuttable card of three 'Fireballs', two 'Lovely Fireballs', and one 'Deathball
3 - Secret Door cards
1 - Monster Manual card
10 - Red Door cards

5 - Pink Life crystals



Now included at no additional cost! Track your Dungeon Hero's life with 1HP tokens or easy to pick up Pink Life crystals!

name: Fenrir
description:
2 to 4 players

36 Fetter cards in 3 suits

1 Pawn

1 Movement track

Objective

Players are Norse gods trying to stop Fenrir from reaching and devouring Odin.

Setup

Place the pawn on the first wolf spot of the track board.

3 or 4 player game

The Deal

The dealer thoroughly shuffles the deck and deals out all 36 cards one at a time to each player.

The player to the left of the dealer goes first by asking one of the other players for a card by rank and suit. The player asking for a card must already hold at least one card of the same suit.

If the player that was asked has the requested card he plays the card to the table face up starting a discard pile (the cards should be fanned so that the rank and suit are showing). Then move the pawn along the track backwards the number of spaces indicated on that discarded card. Now the asking player continues his turn and may ask the same player or another player for a card.

If the player that was asked does not have the requested card then the asking player must discard face up onto the discard pile a card of the same suit asked and moves the pawn along the track forwards the number of spaces indicated on that discarded card and now the turn to ask passes to the next player to the left.

The gods win if they discard all their fetter cards before Fenrir reaches Odin, otherwise they lose.

A 2 player game

Each player is dealt a hand of 10 cards and the remaining 16 cards are stacked face down on the table. A player who does not have the requested card draws one card from the stock before asking the opponent for another card. The remaining rules are the same as in a 3 or 4 player game.
categories: Abstract Strategy, Mythology, Print & Play, Racing

name: Sõnadžungel
description:
Word jungle - there are 25 two-sided boards with letters.

Each player chooses one board and starts looking for the words which they can mark with the erasable marker until the sand timer stops the round. The player who has marked the most words after several rounds is the winner.

name: With Ketchup
description:
Dragons like Knights, and Knights like Dragons... With ketchup!

2 players face off, one as the Dragon, and one as the Knight.
Winner of 2 out of 3 battles between 3 (or 4) unique match-ups of a Dragon and a Knight. Is it the Plate armored Knight vs the Hatchling Dragon, or the peasant wearing Quilted armor vs the Ancient Dragon? You won't know until you flip your Armor Cards!

Each player has 4 levels of protection (Armor) as well as Effort cards and Weapon Cards.
The Knight can attack with a [Mighty] and [Good] Effort with his [Razor Sharp] [Halberd] for 11 points, or if his hand is full of weak cards, he'll be forced to make a [Pitiful] Effort to attack with his [Crossbow] for 2 points.
What to play, what to hang on to? Deceptively simple, with a deeper strategy.

Whoever defeats their opponent by reducing their Health to zero in combat will have dinner when they're done.
categories: Card Game, Fantasy, Fighting, Math, Medieval
mechanics: Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Hand Management, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Snow Ball Fight!!
description:
Snow Ball Fight!! pits 2 teams of kids (5 kids per team) in a snowball fight to the last man standing! Each team member has a number, and a color, so your little one can practice matching and identifying their colors and numbers.

Draw cards from the draw pile and see if you hit someone, miss, or miss by elimination (each kid can only be hit once), and be the first to decimate your opponent!
categories: Card Game, Children's Game, Educational, Fighting, Math

name: TP'd
description:
You and your friends have sneaked onto the Johnson's property, and now it's time to TP their trees!

Each player has a picture mat with a Tree on it, and a complete deck of TP/Hazard cards. Your goal is to TP as much of the tree as possible before the cops show up, while dealing with Hazards which will remove your TP.

A Deck contains 2 complete games; 2 Play mats and 2 complete decks of cards with different colored backs to help identify which deck they belong to.

The game can be played solitaire (using 1 deck and 1 Mat), or versus; each player using a mat, combining the decks into 1 big deck, and playing the Hazards on each other!

Three different color sets are available, allowing up to 6 miscreants to be TP'ing the Johnson's trees at once!
categories: Abstract Strategy, Card Game, Children's Game, Number, Puzzle

name: A Wolf in Sheep's Clothing
description:
Two players are prospective sheep farmers aiming to herd the most Sheep from a Flock.

Every turn, players will choose one card from their hand and play it face-down in a Flock, while saying "bah" for each Sheep on the card. Players can choose to tell the truth or lie about how many Sheep there actually are. Once there are seven or more "bah"s said between all players, a player can summon the Dog and say "bark, bark, bark!" If there's no Wolf, the player can pick up the Flock and check for the Wolf. If there's no Wolf, the player can harvest some Sheep, getting them closer to victory, or if there's a Wolf, it has eaten some Sheep! Players can also accuse one another for playing the Wolf, with game-altering consequences. Accumulate 9 sheep during the game and you win!
categories: Animals, Bluffing, Card Game, Children's Game

name: Abenteuer in Mexiko
description:
The players are miners, whose objective is to transport bags of silver from their mine to the harbor of Vera Cruz (end space).

It's a simple roll and move game. When the meeples land on a marked space, the players have to follow the instructions in the rules. While passing through the "Indian Gorge" the meeples are in danger from an Indian, who is moved, whenever an odd number is rolled. The player who is the first to reach the end space is the winner of the game.

name: Onmitsu
description:
Onmitsu is a Print-and-Play "small card" game. Besides the rules, the whole game is contained in one 54-card deck of cards.

In Onmitsu, you are a spy – an Onmitsu – a sort of spy slash messenger slash ninja slash espionage secret kind of sneak. Your job is to deliver a scroll with a message to your Lord’s boss, the Daimyo. You have a sealed scroll – but so does everyone else. Nobody knows how has which one, either.

Only one message is the “real” message. Others are decoys (which need to be delivered, but aren’t worth as much) and at least “Poison” scroll – a scroll with a hidden message to kill the bearer. Someone doesn’t trust you very much…

Your job is to not only deliver the scroll, but figure out which one you and the other players have. You can always crack yours open to find out, but if the Daimyo shows up before you repair it (or pass it off on some other spy) you are in trouble.

Game play is simple – you draw and discard to form a hand of cards, each of which can be Locations or People. All of them give you the ability to perform actions like steal cards, repair broken scrolls, gain intelligence, or other forms of intrigue.

You win by having the most points, earned by delivering the most important scroll, accumulating cards, and not being the messenger who gets killed.
categories: Ancient, Card Game, Deduction, Print & Play
mechanics: Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Simultaneous Action Selection, Take That

name: Kingdom Land
description:
The King of Kingdom Land has perished and left his subjects with no heir to rule their fair land. Enter the Barons who all vie for the crown despite their colorful quirks. Using their followers and keen sense of tactics, players will use their baron to jockey for position and finally take rule of the land.

In Kingdom Land players will take on the role of Baron's vying for the vacant throne. Players will roll custom dice in an effort to build up specific types of followers all while trying to gain majority over the regions that make up Kingdom Land. Players will also have the opportunity to learn specific tactics and build monuments which with further increase their chance of dominance. After six rounds Kingdom Land will be evaluated and the Baron with the most points will fill the empty throne of Kingdom Land and rule forever!
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Dice Rolling, Worker Placement

name: Rugrats Water Fun Park Adventure Game
description:
Race your favorite Rugrats character along the colored path and up the Super Slide steps. The first character to reach the top and slide down into the middle space is the winner!

On your turn, spin the color wheel and move your character forward to the first space that matches the color on the spinner. If you land on a ticket space, spin the wheel again except this time you will move along the path that matches the symbol that the wheel stops on. Once you reach the Super Slide and spin the red or blue color, drop your character down the chute. If you land in the middle window, you are the winner!
categories: Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Wunderteam
description:
Two or four player soccer game using metal miniatures; players each have 1 field player and 1 goalie, using a ball that position determines the possession/active player. On a board with checkerboard patterns different areas (dark & light) determine who's next to kick (dark or light team).

The player puts the field kicker next to the ball and releases its leg to kick the ball. The other player should try to block the kick with his/her goal keeper. After the kick the possession is once more decided and the same procedure starts all over again.

Goalies can be managed by two other players, game lasts 2 x 10 minutes.

Remarks: Game was produced during 1930's; 'Wunderteam' was a specific name for the Austrian national soccer team during the years 1931 up to 1933.
categories: Action / Dexterity, Miniatures, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Sports

name: Flipp und Flapp
description:
Objective: get familiar with additon/subtraction of small numbers
- collection of a few different math games for preschoolers -

1. Be the first to reach 10 exactly: put on appropriate math sheet, turn the spinner and add or subtract shown number.

2. Be the first to get rid of your 11 wooden slides with different numbers: put on appropriate math sheet, turn the spinner and solve the math formula by filling in the correct slide.
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Collision
description:
Collision is a super-hero deck building game, created by Magenic Technologies. In Collision, players play as software superheroes (The Automator, The Architect, The Oracle, Big Data, and The Mechanic) to build a deck utilizing additional heroes, super-powers, gear, and additional equipment to fight villains big and small, from small bugs all the way up to the evil Retrograde and Rain Cloud.

On each turn, the active player plays cards from their hands. Most cards in the game yield from 1 to 5 power, which is the main currency of the game. Other cards allow manipulation of the player's discard pile, drawing additional cards, ridding the deck of unwanted cards or additional bonuses. Having accumulated power during their turn, players finally use their power to purchase additional cards to increase their deck's strength. Each card purchased is worth victory points, and the person who has the most victory points at the end of the game is the winner!
mechanics: Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Variable Player Powers

name: Battle of the Alamo
description: This is a game about the Alamo with a military theme. Designed to be enjoyed by 2, 3, or 4 players ages 10 or older with different skill levels for each age group. One player represents the Alamo defenders. The other player or players represent the attacking Mexican army. The outer pathway is a square depicting the walls of the fort. The inner pathway is a circle depicting the interior of the fort. Players move along the outer pathway by throwing dice and drawing event cards. Once a breach has been created the action moves to the interior for a final showdown. Includes tournament rules for a five game series to create play balance for the beleaguered Texans.

name: Wintersport
description:
Objective: Be the first racing to position '100'

Typical 'Roll & Move' game from the 1910's in Germany. Roll the die by turns and step forward - until you end on a special field - follow instructions glued on lid inside.

Special rules: players are kicked out / must start again if touched or passed by others. Use 2 dice before passing space 84.

name: The Game of Merry Christmas Goose Chase
description:
Game manufacturers McLoughlin Brothers produced a group of several games, during the late 19th century, called "The Merry Christmas Series." It is likely that the firm marketed these games especially at holiday time, to take advantage of the gift-buying public.

The Game of Merry Christmas Goose Chase is a simple racing game where players try to catch a Christmas goose. This game is targeted toward young children.

name: "Klipp Klapp"
description:
Players take turns dropping their 5 marbles down the channels of the game, trying to get as many marbles as possible down to score at the bottom (hole with different values).

Winner is the first player to exceed 500 points.

Remark:
Published late 1950/early 60's.

name: Pit of Pillars
description:
Pit of Pillars is an elimination game of placement of men, and moving and capturing stacks. Every capture results in a pillar being erected on the square where the capture took place. Pillars belong to the captor and move as chess queens. They can neither capture nor move over pieces.

Stacks can be split or joined. Whether a stack is vulnerable to capture is determined by the number of adjacent squares. Pillars take away such squares and thus heighten vulnerability of adjacent stacks.

A player wins by eliminating all of the opponent's stacks from the board (regardless of any reserves either player might have in hand) or by leaving his opponent without a legal move. Cooperative cycles are inherently possible, but in regular play the game will seldom end in a draw.

The game can be played using simple generic material: a chess board, draughtsmen, and chess pawns to represent pillars.

name: Jaywalkers
description:
Jaywalkers is a two player game, played on the spaces of a 8x8 board.

2 pawns in two colors and 62 path tiles.

SETUP - Place board between players, pawns start on any space of each player’s respective first rows.

PLAY – A player on his turn must take two actions.

1.Place a tile onto an empty space.
2.Move your pawn in a series of one or more rook moves over any number of tiles following any one of three paths shown on a tile you're currently moving over and ending the move on an empty space.

RESTRICTIONS – The tile you placed on your turn must be part of the route your pawn takes. A pawn may not land on a tile. Your pawn may not jump over your opponent's pawn.

ENDGAME – You win if your opponent is unable to take his two actions.
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Enclosure, Grid Movement, Tile Placement

name: Leap Frog
description:
Simple game in the 18th Blue Peter Annual. In true Blue Peter tradition, you have to make the game first.

It is a Tiddlywinks type game. Each player gets five 'frogs' and must flip them on to the board. You add scores on to the Flowers and inside the Water-Lilies. Should you be unlucky and land on a fish or into the pond, lose 10 points and 5 points respectively.

Play for as long as you like. The highest score at the end is the winner.
categories: Action / Dexterity, Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: The Magic Journey
description:
The Magic Journey is a Goose-type game, with players moving via a die roll and obeying the instructions on the illustrated spaces. Whoever reaches HOME first wins.

The Magic Journey was published in a "Tufty" book for children. Tufty games are always about avoiding accidents, and this is no exemption.
publishers: The Royal Society for the Prevention of Accidents

name: Danger!
description:
Game featured in the British 1979 Charlie's Angels Annual.

Simple roll and move game for two players. One is the good player representing a member of Charlie's Angels I assume, and the other is the evil player, representing an Enemy Agent.

Players move according to their die roll not forgetting to obey the instructions on special squares, and the first to launch the Rescue Missile (Space 38), wins.

The rules say that the game can be played alone, by 'playing fairly' for the enemy agent's die rolls. It is the first time in a Goose-type game that I have seen a square that only applies to the Charlie's Angel player, who, if she lands on it, she is knocked out of the game. There is no such square for the Enemy Agent so he has a small advantage.
categories: Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Spies/Secret Agents

name: A Clear Round?
description:
Game featured in the 1978 Black Beauty Annual.

A simple die rolling game. Each player is a rider in a show-jumping competition. As usual with Goose-type games, there are special spaces (illustrated by a horseshoe). Each special space represents faults earned by the rider that round. These fault points have to be written down as they are earned. A slight twist with this game is that the order of finishing also generates time-faults; 1st to finish, none; second to finish, 5 time-faults, and so on.

After all the players have finished, the player with the fewest faults, wins.
categories: Animals, Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Novel-based, Sports

name: Blackberry Time
description:
A game that featured in the British 1975 Disneyland Annual.

A simple roll and move game. Players represent characters from the Disney animated film about Alice in Wonderland.

Roll a 5 to start. When you land on special square they will often tell you how many blackberries you have picked that turn. Record the number so that each player will have a total once all have finished. The player who picks the most, wins.
categories: Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Novel-based

name: Mickey Mouse's Waiting Game
description:
A game that featured in the British Disneyland Annual for 1977.

A simple Goose-type game. Mickey Mouse wants to go out in his car but his friends want to go with him. He has to wait until one friend arrives (and he looks very cross as he waits by his car). Players move by a die roll and must obey the special squares. The first player to reach square 30, wins.
categories: Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Stellar War
description:
Stellar War is based on an old Avalon Hill card game known as Naval War, but rather than simulate a war at sea during WWII, Stellar War simulates a war in space, in the distant future.

The object is to have the most points at the end of play, by destroying enemy spaceships and space stations and preserving your own. Each player begins with a fleet of ships and stations used to attack opponents, and plays cards from their hand that represent offensive and defensive actions and other special events. Ships and stations can acquire special defenses or abilities. Optional rules are included to allow different configurations of play.

name: Rugby Aotearoa
description:
A basic memory-style game with a NZ rugby theme. Collect pairs of cards to score points, play a tackle token to prevent a player from collecting a set.

Released to coincide with the [2013?] Rugby World Cup.

(n.b.: Aotearoa is the Maori name for New Zealand)
categories: Card Game, Children's Game, Memory, Sports

name: Rupert's School-Time Game
description:
Game featured in the 1976 Rupert Annual.

It is a simple roll and move game. Each player chooses a colour and will need 6 counters of that colour. Only one counter for each player will be in play at any time.

Players throw a die to move their way along a 50-space track. If a player lands on one of the six illustrated spaces, they must put their counter on the correct spot for that character. These spots are marked around the illustration in the centre of the board. That player then takes another counter of her colour and starts at square 1 again. Only one of her counters can be on any spot. The first player to have her 6 counters on the spots in the centre, wins.
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: An Invitation to the Mad Hatter's Tea-Party
description:
Game featured in the 1978 British Disneyland Annual. Various Disney characters are illustrated on the board.

This is a Goose-type game. Players move by throw of a die and must follow instructions should they land on one. The first player to reach square 64 by exact throw, wins the game and can enjoy a cup of tea with the Mad Hatter himself.
categories: Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: VW Fahrschule
description:
"VW Fahrschule. Ein geschicklichkeitsspiel fur junge und alte Autofahrer". Eng. - Volkswagen Driving school. A skill game for young and old car drivers". This game was published in 1950s.

Players roll the dice and move cars on the board along the separate from each other route (four different colors: red, blue, green and black as a VW Beetle car tokens too).

To win, you need to cross seven stations. Players begin from different sides of the board and end at parking (driving school).

Doubles change the traffic light (placed on the board) from red to green (or vice versa). Players cannot move through red lights, until they roll doubles again.

name: Old Father Goose
description:
The goal is to move the pawns around the board to the center section. Movement is controlled by dice. All players move around the same board, so they may capture each others pawns. Captured pawns are returned to their player's corner and must start their journey over. The winner is the first player to move all pawns to the center space.

Components: 8 red, 8 yellow, 8 pink, and 8 blue wood pieces, indicator and black Father Goose figure made of wood.

name: Kreuz und quer durch West: und Mitteldeutschland
description:
The goal is to be the first to get from the starting point in Garmisch-Partenkirchen to one of the 5 northern spaces at the top of the board. Moves are determined by the spinner on the upper left side of the board. The spinner shows numbers between 1 and 6 as well as the four directions (N, E, S, W).

Released in the '50s. A later Edition was called Kreuz und quer durch Deutsche Lande, probably in the '60s.

name: Cadi Golf
description: This is a golf game, moving around a board, trying to do it in as few moves as possible, per hole, just like in golf. As per the box "An indoor game for the family. No knowledge of golf is required. Any golf course score card may be used". The game has cards which are used as the stroke and putting of the game. There are also score cards, and each hole is played as you would play a real golf hole. There is a board, 90 stroke cards, 30 penalty cards, 30 putt cards and 4 move markers.

name: Fröhliches Pilzesuchen
description:
Object
Catch the most edible species of fungus on your trip through field & forest.

Game Play
Each player rolls the die and moves forward; ending on a marked space you make pick an edible fungus - if not already caught by another one.

If you have to pick an unedible one you lose one turn. Game ends after last edible fungus has been picked.
categories: Children's Game, Collectible Components, Dice, Educational

name: What Are You!?
description:
THE STORY:
You've awakened in an abandoned building with no idea of who you are. There are others with you, also missing their memory. Writings on the wall by those left here before you say that there is no way out, except by being the last. It also says no one here is entirely human, that your true natures will soon begin to reveal themselves. You're not sure about this whole "not human" thing. All you do know is that you plan on being the last one standing, whatever you are!

THE GAME:
What Are You!? is a combat and deduction game where players secretly assume the role of one of ten different monsters. They will then use cards and power up tokens to attack each other while also attempting to uncover their opponents' true natures, and thus their ultimate weaknesses. The player that can outlast the others wins the game and becomes King (or Queen) of all monsters.
categories: Deduction, Horror, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: 11 gegen 11
description: The goal of this football game is to score Goals (what else?). Who scores the most in an ageed upon time is the winner. There are 11 playing pieces for each Player, one ball and no dice. The different playing pieces move in different ways. Each player can move 1 playing piece and the ball (if the playing piece can reach it) per turn. If the ball reaches another playing piece of the same team, it can be shot again. If not, the other player gets his turn.

name: Vorsicht im Straßenverkehr: Verkehrszeichenspiel
description:
The goal is to be the first to get from a starting point to a destination point, several are possible. While under way the players have to observe the traffic rules, or pay penalities.

Before the game starts the players use the die to determinate who drives a car or a motorcycle or who must walk!

name: Naughty? or Nice?
description:
Naughty? Or Nice? is a Christmas themed version of classic party games like Mafia or Werewolf. Great for holiday and family parties.

You can play the game with naughty presents which remove the "elimination" typical of mafia and werewolf games. Or if you prefer the typical werewolf rules, you can use the Krampus cards and kidnap your fellow elves.

This is a social deduction game where players are on naughty and nice teams. At nights, naughty elves break a present. During the days, the nice elves vote on who they think is naughty.

The game ends when one of two conditions are met:
1.) All naughty elves are exiled and the nice elves win!
2.) All the nice presents are destroyed and the naughty elves
win.
mechanics: Memory, Team-Based Game, Variable Player Powers, Voting

name: Tasteless Creative
description:
Hilarious party game with just the right mix of creativity and creation.

Basic Rules
1. To start the game, each player draws a Challenge Card.
2. One randomly chosen player is elected Reader and pulls a Topic Card. The Reader picks a topic
of their choosing from the Topic Card and reads it aloud.
3. All of the other players answer the question on separate pieces of scratch paper abiding by their
Challenge Card and passes it face down to the Reader.
4. While answers are submitted, the Reader should check handwriting so answers have full effect
when read aloud.
5. The Reader shuffles all of the answers and shares each answer with the group, pausing in between
reading each one. The answer with the most laughs wins a point.
6. After the round, a new player becomes the Reader and everyone re­draws a Challenge Card.
7. The player who reaches 10 points first wins. You can alter the win condition to your game
environment.

Topic Cards:
Words...
Creatively define the word given, but don’t worry about coming anywhere close to the real definition!
Just give it whatever meaning strikes you.
Famous People...
Tell us what He or She is famous for...your version anyway. Create an elaborate back story to the
person or tell us a creative tale involving this person.
Movie Titles...
Come up with a terribly clever plot line for the film listed. Is it a documentary? Maybe a hushed noir
film of yesteryear?
Laws...
Fill in the blanks to complete these laws. Your answer can be as long or as short as necessary to
get your point across.
categories: Bluffing, Card Game, Humor, Mature / Adult, Party Game, Print & Play, Word Game

name: Rot und grün: Das kleine Verkehrsspiel
description: The players each have a car and a truck. They have to transport building materials and Permits from their starting space to a construction site, where they build houses. On their way, they have to observe the traffic rules. The moves are dertermined by a spinner. Several delivering tours are necessary. The player who finishes his house first, wins the game.

name: Bobi
description:
Bobi is a new fast paced and addictive game with one very simple goal, to get rid of all your cards before everyone else, because no one likes to lose.

Play in large groups and take it in turn to try and fire through a round with the same colour, but watch out because if you’ve played the highest card and someone else doesn’t have that colour you may be in for a very unpleasant surprise.

Play begins with the roll of a dice to decide the starting colour and after that the player holding the 'Bobi' card of that colour starts the game. Each player then takes it in turns to play a card of the same colour until each player has played one card to end the turn.

The next turn begins with the player who player the highest card on the last go and continues until players have no cards left in their hand. However if you don't have a card of the current colour you can play any card you want and force the player who has played the current highest to pick up all the cards in play.

name: Walt Disney's Donald Duck Game
description: This is a trick taking card game with a 40 card deck. The deck is made up of four suits: purple, green, red, and blue. In each suit, some of the cards have duck pictures (Daisy, Donald, Scrooge, etc.). These are the point cards, with their point values shown on each card. The point value is different from these cards' play value, however. By playing cards, players take tricks and try to collect 120 points of point cards to win.

name: Trap the Rat
description:
One player is the rat, trying to move across the board's yellow squares to one of the cheese squares. The other player is the trapper, trying to completely surround and trap the rat.

The rat player moves first, rolling the die and moving from the start square orthogonally that many squares. Then the trapper rolls the die and places that many fences on the board in the slots between squares. There are 5 total fences in the game. Once all fences have been placed, the trapper must use the already placed fences.

The game ends when either the rat cannot move, or the rat reaches a cheese square on the opposite end of the board.

The d6 is missing, so I'm unsure of its marks, but the instructions indicate that it has at least 1 blank spot, and it's reasonable to assume it goes no higher than 3, since a higher roll would be an automatic win for the trapper.

name: RIF (Resistance is Futile)
description:
Science fiction skirmish level miniatures rule set.

From the publisher's web site: "Ideal for use with 28mm or 15mm scale miniatures (so can use 40k armies with these if you like), the rules cover heroes, vehicles, individuals and units as well. They handle armoured vehicles, gunships, power armour, aliens, humanoids, bugs, robots…

A player shoots and/or moves a unit or individual/model, then rolls to see if he can activate another unit that round, and so on until a roll to get another unit to act fails, then the other player has a round. The chance of getting 2+ units to respond in a round depends on the motivation, communications and the like for the unit/individual/model involved... but it a case of shoot first, then move, then combat.

Morale includes a form of pinning/going prone as a voluntary action against incoming fire to reduce the risk of, erm, death, and the main element is that all units/individuals/models start to test once a certain level of casualties have been sustained by your army (not per unit). Level of losses at which you test is worse for militia-type units, better for regulars and much better for special forces.

A points system is included in the rules, as well as ideas for linking games from one to another."

name: IMBA
description:
Broken, busted, over-powered and imba; just some of the common phrases you hear when playing some of your favorite competitive video games. Are you tired of playing video games that release patch after patch but still never seem to get the character balance correct?

IMBA to the rescue!

IMBA is the board game where you take the role of lead game designer of a popular competitive video game. Your job is to make sure your video game has been thoroughly tested and that all the characters in your game are balanced.

IMBA is a card game for 2 to 4 players. Each player will be assigned a different character to balance and its up to you to stand out as the best designer by making sure the characters you're in charge of are not too strong, not too weak and free of exploits.
categories: Card Game, Humor, Video Game Theme

name: Stack Three
description:
Stack your blocks and get three in a row! Block your opponent by placing yours on top. Stack Three will challenge your spacial reasoning as you try to think through stacking. First player to get three blocks connected wins.

Objective: To lay three touching blocks in a row horizontally, diagonally, or vertical diagonally.

name: Check
description:
Can you tell when someone is bluffing? Roll your stones and up the ante until someone cracks and calls check. Did you bluff well enough or will you lose your stones? Keep your stones to win!

To play, you and your opponents start with six stones, three green, three blue. Each stone has two sides, flat and round. Players take turns guessing how many of one type of stone is existing collectively. If someone feels the guess is wrong they may call the player out. If they are right the active player loses a stone and the player who called it starts the next round. Last one standing wins.
mechanics: Hand Management, Memory, Player Elimination, Push Your Luck, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Ivy
description: Need a game that challenges your memory? Test out your math skills with Ivy! In Ivy player take turns trading, collecting, and stealing pogs from one another to get the winning number. Can you remember what number you have?
mechanics: Hand Management, Memory, Push Your Luck
publishers: Design Machine Games, Dream Machine Productions

name: FIVEs
description: Roll the die for your letter and make up a funny sentence using the words letters. The first player to guess your word will get the letter you rolled. Spell out the word FIVEs and win!

name: Tang
description:
Abstract strategy game on 8x8 board. 16 square pieces per player with pointers on them.

Pieces can slide. The less pointers on the piece, the less directions you can move in, although with high speed. The more pointers, the more directions you can move in, but at slower speed.
It is also possible to jump when pointers are aligned between pieces. If a jump ends on an opposing piece it is taken. A piece is also taken when all its pointers are blocked.

Pieces start at your own two back rows. The player who reaches the opposite end row first with two of his pieces in adjacent fields wins.

name: Nonstop
description: The players fly from Berlin to London to deliver a box and from there to Paris to deliver a sack. While doing this, the players earn points (play money). On many spaces on the game board, points are awarded or removed. When all available points at the bank and the airports have been earned, the game ends and the player with the highest score wins.

name: Erdös Latino
description:
In Erdös Latino, an abstract strategy game, two players face off, placing numbers (1–5) in a 5×5 square grid. There are five of each number. On your turn, simply place a number in a space on the grid, such that neither its row nor its column contains another instance of that number. There are two ways to win:

Block your opponent from making a play.
When the board is full, be the player who has claimed more columns.


You claim a column when you are the first player to form a sequence of three numbers, increasing away from you.

You can play with several different levels of information to the players:

Random — You blindly draw the tile you must play.
Perfect Information — The tiles form a face-up, shared pool; you take the tile you want.
Mixed — Shuffle the tiles face-down, then give thirteen to the start player, and twelve to the other player.

name: Palatine
description:
Palatine is a social strategy game that takes place during the decline of the ancient Roman Republic. Players take on the roles of noble families jockeying for power amidst increasing corruption and unrest.

Gameplay consists of players bidding against each other on a randomly ordered selection of cards, then playing those cards. Cards represent opportunities for advancement in Roman high society, such as the acquisition of government positions, the leading of military campaigns, or the construction of public works. Cards tend to grant players tokens — influence, denarii or legions — and those tokens are used in bidding for more cards.

Victory can be achieved either by acquiring a predetermined number of legion tokens and storming Rome or by having the most influence tokens of any player when the deck has been exhausted.

The game allows for strategy as confined by the luck of the deck's shuffle as well as trading, player cooperation and player competition.
mechanics: Action Points, Auction/Bidding, Hand Management, Open Drafting, Trading, Voting

name: Atom Raider
description:
In the not too distant future the hydrocarbons have run out! But not to worry, because nuclear power is here and it’s totally safe… honest. Sure there have been some mishaps along the way, but today’s super clean super efficient nuclear powerplants are a true wonder of modern science. The technology has come so far so fast that it has left a trail of obsolete and faulty industrial sites in its wake. Don’t worry though these relics of the nuclear revolution are nothing to be concerned about. They’re mostly away from the populated safe-zones, they’re guarded by very competent Securobot staff and in a lot of them rad-levels are approaching acceptable. It’s in these crumbling industripolis that we find our setting for Atom Raider.

Atom Raiders are the dregs of society, a kind of Atomic scavenger they trawl dead powerplants for the old unstable and yet very lucrative fissionable material. Mostly it’s locked away in huge old reactor stores and normally guarded by the stupid but formidable securobots. The only law force that can put up with those kind of rad-levels for more than a few shifts.

In Atom Raider misdirection is the name of the game. Infiltrating players guide their stealthy Raiders through the darkened maze of corridors using subterfuge, bluffs, feigns and cunning to be the first to reach the reactor doors. The Securobot player must use his memory and powers of deduction to uncover which of the abandoned facility’s many shadows conceal the nefarious Raiders.

The game play is very simple, but varies greatly with the number of players. The gaurds player has two guards under his control and may move them 1D6 each. If a guard managed to draw a line of sight to a shadow they can reveal it. If it contains a Raider then they are discovered and for them the game is up! The Raider players similarly have 2D6 which they get to use to move any shadow that they like. Could be the shadow with the Raider under, could be a bluff. If they make it to a vault with a Raider still undiscovered then they win.

name: Rodo
description:
Rodo is a race game that simulates a car competition.
The goal is to win a 5 laps race, to do so you have to define a good race strategy in order to take as much advantage as possible from each movement.

It is also very important to make a fast and clean entrance in boxes, and to know when an how to use you cards.

Overall Gameplay
- It's a race of 5 laps
- Every player has 5 chips numbered from 4 to 8 .
- For each lap the player must use a chip, the sum of the chip an the dice determines the number of squares that you move per turn. For example if you use the chip 4 and the dice says 2 you move 6 squares.
- When you begin the next lap you have to change the chip, which can not be reused. Just one chip per lap.
- Each competitor must pass through boxes 2 times, and roll a dice to see if you lose 1, 2 or 0 turns.
The movement of squares is forward and aside. The only thing that is not allowed is to return to the same box, move back, and pass over the other cars .
 - Each player receives 5 ​​cards to start the game the cards can be replaced when you finish the all, or whe you pass to another lap.
- When there is a situation of overtaking, cards are played to decide the outcome of the maneuver, which depends on the difference in number between the two players.
- There are wild cards that help you during the race to move more squares or to prevent overtaking

Card Game

There is a pack containing the following cards :
- 6 sets of cards, each set has the color of one of the cars, and are numbered from 1 to 6 , the total is 36 cards.
4 lots of 4 wild cards, giving a total of 16 cards
The total of the deck is 52 cards.

Dice
There are two types of dice:
Dice to move. Numbered from 1 to 3 and is together with the chip what determines how many squares you move per turn.
Boxes dice. Is numbered from 0 to 2 and determines how many turns you remain in boxes.

name: Familie Feuerstein
description: In Familie Feuerstein (The Flintstones), each player gets two meeples, which he has to get from his starting spaces to the finish on the rotating Center of the game board. If a player rolls a 1 or 6, he may rotate the Center instead of moving a meeple. The meeples can be thrown out by opposing meeples, if they don't stand on a safe space with a picture of a Flintstone character represented by the player. The player who is the first to get his two meeples to the center spaces, wins the game.
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: 13 Relics
description:
Hired by various sages, historians and merchants, the players must enter a newly unearthed, ancient underground stronghold,in search of 13 Relics. The Relics were broke apart and scattered through the dungeon's 5 chambers. Once inside, though no one can leave until all of the chambers are free of Relic Cards. The Players will need to find the two parts of each Rlic to make a match, allowing them to utilize it's magic (+1 Combat for instance). While exploring the Dungeon, the Players will come across a host of Monsters, trapped within the Dungeon with them. They must also evade devious Traps, evade diabolical Shadow Magic, find secret doors, and hunt for helpful potions to help them along the way. Will the Players help one another survive and escape, or will they attempt to match the most Relics? They may have to do both.

Players will have two different colored dice that they will roll at the start of their turn. One is for movement, the other, the Dungeon Dice, will determine whether a player will have to draw a card from the Dungeon Deck, based upon 2 numbers from 1 to 6 that each player must choose at the beginning of the game. When one of the five chambers is emptied of it's contents, it will collapse, never to hold a card again. Each time a collapse occurs, the players must add another chosen number, increasing their chance of drawing from the Dungeon Deck. Once all chambers are free from Relic Cards, the exits will open allowing Players to leave.

Players can decide the ultimate victory for their play. Simply escaping the dungeon, making the most matches, being the last one alive are all valid goals for which to strive. A standard win however, is to escape the dungeon with the most matches.

name: Classical Warfare the Second Book of Hosts
description: The second volume of Army Lists continued from the first publication "Chariot Warfare". this volume overlaps a little from the first volume and spans the classical period to the rise of the Roman Empire. These army list are formatted for use with 6th and 7th edition of "War Games Rules 3000 BC to 1485 AD" by Wargames Research Group. It also includes a conversion table for use with the Newbury Fast Play rules. With some thinking the lists can be adapted for use with other rules.

name: Finals Fever
description: Finals Fever is a simulation of Australian football played on a board measuring 68cm by 48cm, representative of a football oval with spectators, and including a set of "decision cards" to govern umpiring decisions, plus two dice and a counter representing the ball. The playing area is separated into squares, some with position names inscribed on them, some bearing the letter "D" (for decision card), and others blank. There is a space for the decision cards which are shuffled and placed face down in a pile. The ball is moved in accordance with dice rolls, with the aim being to maintain possession by ensuring that the ball lands on one of the dice roller's own position squares. If the ball lands on a "D" square play continues as per the instructions on the decision card at the top of the pile. If the ball lands on a blank square, possession goes to the other player. When playing from a position square both dice are rolled; when intercepting the ball from a blank square only a single die is used. The ultimate aim is to score goals (worth 6 points) and behinds (worth 1 point) by moving the ball through the appropriate posts at either end of the playing field.

name: Realm of Wizards
description:
Realm of Wizards is a game for 2-4 players. Each wizard is assigned an element, earth (green), air (yellow), fire (red) and water (blue). The wizards summon creatures to fight to the death. The winner is the last player left in the game.

A board section is supplied for each wizard that is partaking in the game and places it at the start of the game.

Each turn the wizards collect energy (magic crystals) from their current space, if it happens to be a space matching their own element type they will gain more crystals, next the wizards can move and select up to two creatures they may have summoned to move, landing on a strategic area of the board can make a big difference between success and failure. Once movement has been performed it’s time for any creatures of opposing wizards sharing a space to battle to the death, during the battle phase a creature can battle a wizard and if they win that wizard is eliminated and their part in the game is over. Once all the battles have been fought the wizards can summon a new creature to aid them in the conquest, if they happen to share a space matching their own element type they can summon two. Lastly new spells (creature counters) are collected and replenished, some are expired and returned to the counter pool ready for the next turn when each wizard left in the game must gather their thoughts and put their minds to their next strategy and prepare for the actions from the remaining wizards left in the game.

Each turn is broken down into steps which each wizard will perform before the next step begins. By placing their wizard and creatures in strategic positions the players can gain an important edge over their opponent that could be the difference between success and failure. A wizard in control of the elements will ultimately bring about the destruction of his enemy and rejoice in victory.
mechanics: Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Hand Management, Modular Board

name: War Fighters
description:
War Fighters is a unique, 2 player (3 player if you want to), traditional card game that incorporates aspects from 4 different card games, in a lightning-fast paced game. Players have 5 different game play styles to choose from and can play with different amounts of cards, in a half deck, full deck, or custom deck format. This is an “E-Rated” card game, sure to get your family involved, and easy enough for anyone to enjoy.

There are 10 decks to choose from: Ninja, Pirates, Aliens, Robots, Monsters, Undead, Ghosts, Vampires, Werewolves, and Zombies.

The game is designed to bridge the gap between games for really young children such as: "Uno," "Crazy 8's," and "Old Maid," and games for older children such as: "Magic the Gathering," "Pokemon," etc. It is designed to be an easy to pick up and play card game for children ages 6+, families, and casual players. There are multiple ways to play the game, multiple decks to build, and players can even make up rules once they get comfortable with the gameplay. The trading card and custom deck options are just that...options, and are not required to play the game, unless you want to, and that is always welcomed!

War Fighters can be played by anyone, of any age, at any time, in multiple ways, without having to spend hours on rules getting confusing.

Basic Game Play (#1):
-Divide one deck in half evenly and give each half to a player.
-Each player will receive: 5 square fighters (Paper), 5 circle fighters (Rock), 5 ex fighters (Scissors), 4 attacks, 2 blocks, 2 truces, and 2 star leader fighter cards for a total of 25 cards in the basic version of the game.
-Each player shuffles their half decks
-Each player puts their decks to the left as their "draw pile."
-Each player draws 5 cards.
-At the same time, each player plays a fighter card in the play area between them. A fighter card will have a symbol of a circle, square, ex, or star on it.
-To determine who wins, Square beats Circle, Circle beats Ex, Ex beats Square, Star beats all.
-If both players play the same cards (ex: circle vs. circle) then "war" is initiated and each player draws 3 cards from the draw pile and places it face down into the play area, and then plays another fighter card for the win. War continues until someone wins. Each time the same cards are played, war is initiated again.
-The winner of each round gets all the cards in the play area and puts them into their "discard pile" to their right.
-When the cards in the play area are the same, players must draw the 3 cards and lay them face down followed by another fighter card. However, when the cards are different (ex: circle vs. square) a player can then decide if they want to use an "attack" card, "block" card, or a "truce" card.
-An "attack" card is basically a "+1" or "one up" to the other player for the win.
-A "truce" card means you do not want to fight anymore and want your card back, so both players get their cards back.
-A player can choose to "block" an "attack" card as a defense to try and win the round. A "truce" card cannot be blocked in the basic version of the game.
-After each round, each player draws back up to 5 cards for the next round.
-Each player can use their full hand in each round as needed, but can only use one fighter card during a round, unless "war" has been initiated and the three face down cards need to be drawn.
-It takes one attack and one circle to beat a square, one attack and one square to beat an ex, and one attack and an ex to beat a circle card.
-If a star card is thrown, it takes two unblocked attacks plus any fighter card (square, circle, ex) to beat the star card
-The objective of the game, or how to win, is to collect all the leader cards from the other player.
-On a 5 card hand, if a player does not have any fighter cards, they must show the other player their hand to prove they are not cheating, hand over one of their cards, shuffle all their cards, and draw a new 5 card hand.
-During war, if a player does not have a fighter card to finish the round, that player must count the number of cards in their hand, shuffle all their cards, and draw another hand with that number of cards.

Game Play #2 - (War Strategies):
-During this game style, players can choose to use attack, defense, and truce cards in order raise the stakes before going to war and/or to cancel out the war. So, when players use the same cards (Ex: circle vs. circle), the attack, block, and truce cards can now be played.

Game Play #3 - (Aggressive Vs. Defensive):
-In this style of play, one person gets all the attack cards to start with, while the other gets all the blocks and truce cards.
-As an additional rule, one of the players can get the "power" card as well.
-The "power" card acts as 2 attack cards. When used as an attack card, if a player wins the round, the other player's fighter card is taken out of the game until it is over, making the game go even faster. Star Leader cards cannot be taken out of the game since they are needed in order to win the game.

Game Play #4 - (Power Cards):
-In this mode, the loser of the previous round gets to use the power card to help "even the odds."
-One power card comes in each box.

Game Play #5 - (Custom Deck Options):
-In this option, players can play half decks, full decks, or customs decks, and build their own decks to battle with.
-Players can choose if the cards are deck specific as well. For example, if one person uses ninjas and the other uses pirates, the you can assume that pirates do not know how to throw ninja attack darts or stricken, and therefore the cards are no good to pirates and only the ninja cards the player acquires can use those attacks. This option is a bit advanced so most players who play this tend to put the other players fighter cards to the side and use the attacks, blocks, truce, and power cards in a non-deck specific mode.

Extra Game Information:
-This game is very open so players who are comfortable with the rules tend to master it and then make up their own rules for added fun.
-All decks play the same, but have different artwork to cater to everyones passions.
-This game can also be used to play "matching games," where you lay cards face down and try to pair them up.
categories: Abstract Strategy, Card Game, Children's Game, Collectible Components, Pirates, Zombies
mechanics: Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Hand Management, Rock-Paper-Scissors, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Sea Lane
description:
One of the wargames made by Tsukuda Hobby.

The game covers the hypothetical situations in 1990 that was near future in those days.
The sea lane deffence was loudly discussed in those days in Japan. Prime minister Nakasone made an announcement of unsinkable carrier for Japanese islands.
The hypothetical enemy is Soviet union which was broken into pieces soon after the Nakasone's announcement.

The map covers Sakhalin to Taiwang. But the combatsystem is quite tactical. Unfortunately there are only 3 scenarios. And 2 of them are just drills between US force and Japanese self-defence force.

Very rare game even in Japan.

name: Rocky Crown
description:
Rocky Crown is a boardgame for 2-4 players in which dwarven clans build and fight over a newly established dwarven city. They must also explore the tunnels below the grand halls, hoping to find riches and treasures that will place them on the throne.

The game takes up to eleven turns or until the dwellers of the underground overrun the city. The winner, should the dwarves survive, is the clan holding the most prestige points.

Every turn players must bid to take up different positions which are entrusted with the diverse aspects of the daily life of the city. The clans must lead expeditions into the dark, assume responsability over the great works taking place and supervise the defence of the city both above and below ground. In doing so, they'll gain prestige that'll take them closer to their goal of becoming king of the new city
mechanics: Betting and Bluffing, Network and Route Building, Tile Placement, Worker Placement

name: Perhaps She'll Die
description:
There was an old Lady who swallowed a fly... This trick-taking game is themed on the popular children’s song. The object is to take tricks by playing the highest-ranked animal card. Problem is, when an animal card is played, its rank changes and usually for the worse.

Before each round, ranking cards are placed on the table in a row in order of rank: fly, spider, bird, cat, dog, goat, cow, horse. The fly is the lowest ranked at the start, and the horse is the highest. The animal cards are shuffled and dealt. The start player plays a card, and the corresponding card in the rank row is shifted down one space. If an animal is already the lowest ranked animal, it is moved to the furthest space on the right and becomes the highest ranked animal.

Play proceeds clockwise. In turn, each player plays a card. A player must follow suit if possible, otherwise he may play any card. Each played card causes the corresponding card in the rank row to shift down as described above.

After everyone has played, the player whose card matches the currently highest ranked animal wins the trick (regardless of suit). If two or more players have played the same ‘winning’ card, the player who played first wins the trick.

This is a 3-4 player game. Partnership rules are included as well.
categories: Animals, Card Game, Children's Game, Print & Play

name: Thorn & Rose
description:
In this two-player card game, one person takes on the role of the Hero while the other takes on the role of the Witch. The Hero and the Witch must memorize the layout of the "Cursed Wood" (a 4x4 grid of cards) and then flip over the cards so no one knows what they are. From there, the Hero (using only their memory), must traverse the "Cursed Wood" by flipping over cards one at a time. If the Hero finds 5 Blood Roses, they succeed in their quest! If they find 5 Frights, the Hero fails!

Magic and mayhem add complication to the Hero's quest! The Witch can shift the cards and change the layout of the "Cursed Wood" each time the Hero finds a Fright!

name: Snoopy wensdromen-spel
description:
In this game Snoopy has four different wishes: becoming a top pilot, top baseball player, top dog or famous writer. (Each of the cards is 4 times in the game.) All players (2-8) try to collect the five cards that are part of the same wish.

You can collect by walking around on the board or owing to a 'menu-card'. The first player who collects his 5 cards is the winner.

name: Orðabelgur
description:
Orðabelgur is intended for 2-6 participants and suits people of all ages. This game encourages players to listen and think, be merry and be informed. The game offers contemplation, consideration, word-play and jest, and participants play with the Icelandic language in new ways. The vocabulary in the game covers a great number of Icelandic words, both old and new. The aim of the game is to collect five words in a sack by answering questions from five categories according to certain rules.

The questions are on cards, each indicating which category it belongs to. Two questions of different difficulty levels are on each card, making the game a good fit for a family. A word-shark directs the game, and reads our questions and possible answers and awards players with words for their word-sack when they have been earned.
mechanics: Acting, Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement

name: The Apple Orchard Game
description:
Game found in the Postman Pat Annual for 1998.

A simple game for pre-school children.

Each player has a tree with 20 apples on it. In your turn, a coin is flipped and the following happens:
Heads - Pick 1 apple (cover an apple with a small piece of card or similar)
Tails - Pick 2 apples (and cover as before).

The winner is the first player to cover every apple on their tree.
categories: Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Novel-based

name: The Alphabet Game
description:
Game appeared in the Postman Pat Annual for 1995.

Children are encouraged to take a walk through Greendale village and meet some of their favourite characters.

Simple roll and move game for pre-school children. Players must obey instructions if they land on a pink space. The first to reach space Z, wins.
categories: Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Novel-based

name: On Patrol with PC Selby
description:
Game appeared in the Postman Pat Annual for 1994.

A simple roll and move game for pre-school children. The Greendale policeman is having a busy day. Each player rolls the die and moves, obeying instructions when they land on a beige space. The first to get to the end of PC Selby's day (space 49), wins.
categories: Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Novel-based

name: Cover the Picture
description:
Game featured in the Postman Pat Annual for 1994.

Simple game for pre-school children.

Each player uses one of the two pictures. The pictures are divided in to 10 oblong segments. These are numbered from one to four. In a turn, the player rolls the die and if he rolls a 1, 2, 3, or 4, he covers one segment with that number (use a piece of card or similar to mark that the segment has been rolled). If a 5 is rolled on the die, the player must uncover one of the segments. If a 6 is rolled, the player can cover two segments of his choice.

First player to cover all 10 segments, wins.
categories: Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Novel-based

name: Top of the Hill
description:
Game appeared in the Postman Pat Annual for 1994.

A simple game for pre-school children.

Players roll a die to move along the trach to the top of the hill, where they can have a picnic with Postman Pat. Should a player land on a rabbit hole, they go down to the other end of the hole. Should they land on a short-cut, they can move nearer the top of the hill. The first to get there, wins.
categories: Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Novel-based

name: Go with Sam
description:
Game appeared in the Postman Pat Annual for 1993.

A simple roll and move game for pre-school children.

Players must get from Sam Waldron's house to Pat's house for tea. Move according to your die roll and obey any light brown spaces you land on. First to get to the end of the route, wins.
categories: Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Novel-based

name: Cover the Squares
description:
Game appeared in the Postman Pat Annual for 1993.

Two players are required. Each gets a picture board featuring 6 characters from the Postman Pat stories. In your turn, roll a die. Using playing cards as 'markers', you cover the picture that matches your roll on the die. If you roll the same number twice, you miss a turn. First to cover all six characters on their picture board, wins.
categories: Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Novel-based

name: 12-21-12: Fire & Ice
description:
12-21-12 the game where you spend the last day of the earth however you like. Be it rape, pedophilia, murder, arson, whatever you want! Afterall, there aren't any consequences during the last day!

This micro-expansion gives you the ability to kill off the other players to make sure your final day is better than theirs!
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Humor, Mature / Adult, Party Game

name: Mickey Mouse Flip Chip
description: Mickey Mouse Flip Chip is an odd kind of connect 4 game, you use levers built into the base to launch chips up that randomly fall into the board. First player to 4 in a row wins.

name: Collect A Corpse
description:
Collect a Corpse is a tile laying, build your own royal corpse, game for two players. There is also some dice rolling.

You start the game with either the torso of the king or the queen of Sweden. The goal is to finish your corpse as complete as possible with your own limbs at the right places.

On your turn you draw a card that either shows a bodypart of either the king or the queen, a black dice or a white dice.
If it's a bodypart (it doesn't have to be your own) place it on your torso. You can later exchange them for parts matching your torso if you have the maximum number of that part (usually 2).
If it's a card roll a die and see the charts: The white die is usually constructive for you and the black die destructive for your opponent.

When the last card is drawn you score points. Parts matching your torso score double points if they are in the right place otherwise the score the number printed on them (inner parts give 2 the outer 3 points). You get no points for the opponents parts on your body.

name: Sons Of Liberty 1773
description:
Boston, December 16, 1773. The Sons of Liberty boarded the tea ships and threw the chests of tea into Boston Harbor. This is the key event to the birth of American Revolutionary war which leads to the United States of America birth. In this game you will relive this historical adventure.

The deck is composed of 57 cards: 24 American cards, 24 Great Britain cards and 9 special cards

In each turn, you launch an attack to the next player. He/she can defend it or ally to it. To ally, he/she needs to play a card with the same numeric value, without taking into account the faction. The joint attack passes to the next player. This third player can ally or defend too. To defend, he/she needs to play cards from the opposite faction and with a higher number value than the attacking ones. After defending, each player can add more cards to the attack. If the attack is defended properly the attacking and defending cards are discarded. If it is not, the defending player puts in his hand all attacking and defending cards. When the deck runs out, the first player who runs out of cards is the winner. Also, there are special cards which modify a little bit the game rules.
categories: American Revolutionary War, Card Game, Party Game, Print & Play

name: Zomtrak
description:
A diceless card driven Euro style board game about a Zombie Pandemic on the US Passenger Rail Network.

Description from the Kickstarter:

"In Zomtrack, the cards control the action.

You draw a hand of cards and use them to implement the strategy you have chosen. Back the survivors and spend your time destroying infestations and gaining victory points (VPs) and bonus cards. Did the horde you backed become dominant? Did the survivors’ strongholds hold out? End-of-game bonus cards score based on how well the strategy you backed ends up working."
mechanics: Action Points, Hand Management, Point to Point Movement, Set Collection

name: Päästa Jõulud
description:
"Save the Christmas" in English.
Roll and move on the board and who finishes first is the winner.

name: Inflation
description:
From the rules: "The object of the game is not only to afford amusement to the players but also to illustrate to them how proposed Share-the-Wealth Plans, Excessive Old Age Pension Plans, etc., will increase taxes and place a heavy burden on all citizens and, at the same time, make it possible for the shrewd manipulators to gain a dominating position in economical affairs of the country.

At the outset, let it be understood that before the Government can bring about a share-the-wealth program it must own all properties and all monies. Under a share-the-wealth scheme it is proposed that the Government shall make every man a king and give each person an equal share of the money, after which time each must take care of himself. If a man has good luck and is a shrewd manager, he may beat the game of "inflation." If he isn't, he will be no better off than theretofore and distribution of the wealth of the country will not have availed him anything".


This game is played like modern Monopoly. From Wikipedia: "Inflation board game came to the attention of Parker Brothers management in the 1930s, after they began sales of Monopoly. Copeland continued sales of the latter game after Parker Brothers attempted a patent lawsuit against him. Parker Brothers held the Magie and Darrow patents, but settled with Copeland rather than going to trial, since Copeland was prepared to have witnesses testify that they had played Monopoly before Darrow's "invention" of the game. The court settlement allowed Copeland to license Parker Brothers' patents".

name: Watermelon Patch Game
description:
The children's game in which players capture watermelons with a pole.

Watermelon Patch reinforced derogatory stereotypes with images of blacks stealing and eating melons.

Comes with two wooden fishing poles and many watermelon game pieces.

name: Napoleonic Scenarios
description:
Scenarios for Napoleonic Miniatures gaming with any rules systems (strategic, grand tactical, or tactical) and any size miniatures.

Each scenario features:
A description of the campaign leading up to the battle
Complete order of battle
A historical description of the battle itself
Complete GM notes that provide helpful hints on running the battle, not matter the rules system used
Both historical and balanced victory conditions
A full color map of the battlefield with initial dispositions of units at the start of the battle

The book also contains numerous photographs of the battles being played

name: Tricolor: Rules for Grand Tactical Level Miniature Wargames in 15mm
description: Introductory level set of rules designed with 15mm miniatures representing troops of the various armies of the Napoleonic Wars c. 1800-1815

name: Tattletales
description:
FROM THE ARTICLE:

Based on the Goodson-Todman TV Game, Tattletales...see on Prime time Daytime T.V. and at night once a week. To play, partners must match answers to given questions. Matching of points wins the game and the dubious honor of ending a great "Tattletale".

Contains: Scoreboard, Play Money, Question Booklet, Covers, Pads, Woden Makers, Couple Tokens, and Stands, Instructions.

(NOTE: Though no home game of Tattletales was ever released to the public, Hasbro promoted a home game version in a 1978 catalog sent to its dealers. However, The company reconsidered it when the show got cancelled around the same year.)
categories: Movies / TV / Radio theme, Party Game

name: The Chromatical Gambler
description: A game intended to teach music score reading skills and music scales. In a game similar to Parcheesi/Ludo, three pawns have to move around a board comprised of chromatical scales, only using the notes belonging to one specific musical key.

name: Witch Hunt: Ravenwicke
description:
From website:

Witch Hunt is a Tabletop card game for 1-8 players.

As a witch hunter, you make your way through the village of Ravenwicke discovering items, artifacts, and assistance in the most unexpected places. However, time is short. As ingredients are added to her cauldron, the witch gains power and tightens her grip on the village. Once all five of the ingredients have been added to the cauldron, the witch wins the game! So, it is of the utmost urgency that you find her before the last ingredient is added to her brew. Oh, and did we mention that one of you is actually the witch?

Set in the backdrop of the small village of Ravenwicke, Witch Hunt is a closed-deck (72+ cards) card game that features 3 modes of play. The Angry Mob mode for 3-8 players, a Player versus Player mode, and HERO mode for only the bravest of souls.

NOTE:

The First Edition Deck is delivered in a sealed 3.5"x5" Telescoping Box and is our core deck of 72+ cards for playing Witch Hunt. The box also contains 8 oversized character cards, 2 six-sided dice, and 100 resource tokens.

The Family Edition brings a new dimension to hunting witches. In addition to all the benefits of the Witch Hunt First Edition Deck, the Family Edition comes with a beautiful 18"x18" Village Game Board, delivered in a sealed 10"x10" Game Box. The Family Edition also includes all of the core cards, 8 oversized character cards, 2 six-sided dice, and 100 resource tokens

The Kickstarter Special Edition Bundle includes: The Pirate Expansion, The Witch Coven Expansion, 5 Special Edition Cards.
publishers: Goblin Rocket Games, The Game Crafter, LLC

name: Silly Situations
description:
You've found yourself in a bit of a pickle! Can you make the most of a silly situation with a bunch of random objects? Pick up, trade, and collect object cards to create a wild and wacky story. Use all the object cards in your hand to win!

On your turn you can draw a card, pass, trade cards or tell a story with a set of three Object cards. The first player to get rid of all your cards wins.

name: Chevy Chase
description:
The Deer Stalking Game.

The board shows a deer park divided into two Chases by a high wall which has gaps through it. If a huntsman moves on to the same straight line as the stag (providing there is no obstruction of wall or rock in between) the stag is counted as dead and is removed from the board. There are five stags to bag and the winner is the huntsman who bags the largest number of stags.

The huntsmen throw the dice in turn and move along the brown dots according to the number cast. They can only move from dot to dot along the straight lines. They cannot turn corners and they must move the exact number or not at all. If a huntsman moves on to the same straight line as the stag (providing there is no obstruction of a wall or rock in between) the stag is counted as dead and becomes their trophy.

The part of the stag is played by the two huntsmen in turn as follows: a huntsman moves his own piece first then if he wishes he can move the stag either one or two dots in a straight line.

Although the game is undated, Robert Ross & Co were based in Southampton from 1945 to 1952.

name: Going to the Fire
description: Typical spin and move board game. Object of the game is to reach the fire and return to the starting point.

name: Rundfunkspiel
description:
This is a simple roll-and-move game. Some spaces on the game board have special radio-themed meanings, which are explained in the game rules.

The first Player to reach space 70 wins the game.

name: Crypt Crashers
description:
Crypt Crashers:
Cooperative Board Game
1-5 players
45 minute play time

Crypt Crashers is a highly thematic cooperative board game. Players take turns exploring the crypt and collect clues. If they select the right clues, they will reveal the location of hidden treasure. As the game progresses, mummies and giant spiders begin to awaken. The players must work together and be quick. Time is running out.

Crypt Crashers has nine levels of difficulty and 8 different expeditions to keep the players challenged.

name: Katana Schoolgirls vs Zombie Furries
description:
The objective of this game is to hunt down and destroy the monsters and collect gear. Each opponent and gear has a point cost that is added at the end of the game to determine the winner. Objectives can shift during the game depending on the game scenario you are playing and your character’s Dark Secret motivation.

Minigame complete with full rules, game tiles and game cards. This is a layered PDF giving you four options of colours and a horde of zombies. There are 94 possible miniatures in this set!

You will need a colour printer, cutting tools, glue, foamcore and time. Assembly instructions are included.

Nominated for the 2012 Ennies Best Miniature Product Award
categories: Horror, Humor, Miniatures, Print & Play, Zombies

name: Heavy Gear Blitz! Blood Debt; Peace River Army List
description:
Blood Debt; Peace River Army List

Originally scheduled to be released at GenCon'13, the "army list" is a new format replacing the last two unpublished Field Guides prior to Dream Pod 9's announced rules revamp sometime in late 2014 or early 2015.

Unlike the full Field Guides for the New Coalition and Allied Southern Territories the army list formatting does not contain any fluff chapters or a full vehicle compendium.

This book is available only in an electronic format.

From the back cover;

TN 1951

Peace River Army List
