The object of the game is to be the only Tribe that is undiscovered at the end of a Round. The player with the most wins after three Rounds wins. Draws go to the player who has the most Sungems in total after those three rounds.

On average games/rounds take 10-15 minutes depending on the number of players. Games of Sungem Run! are tense and exciting as you try and find out who the other player’s Tribe is and then how to expose them without exposing yourself. A game of sneakiness, misdirection and deduction, Sungem Run! is a blast to play!

name: Terminus
description:
A Space Mining Game, that operates in a style similar to Monopoly. Instead of land and houses, a player buy mining rights, and ore.
The winner is the one with the most mining shares in the end.
mechanics: Events, Investment, Ownership, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Landkreisspiel Erlangen-Höchstadt
description:
2 different games:
objective 1: gain as many cards as possible delivering correct answers (trivia)
objective 2: gain as many cards as possible; Happy Families approach
1 & 2: learn more about the local region (Erlangen-Höchstadt - in the North of Nuremberg)
- acting simultaneously -
active player reads the question; first player with correct answer gets the card.

Notes:
Belongs to a series of games with a strong regional (rural) focused character (contrary to 'city games');
Usually each village of the administrative district is described.
Due to this point each game is equipped with a different no. of cards.

name: Landkreisspiel Roth
description:
2 different games:
objective 1: gain as many cards as possible delivering correct answers (trivia)
objective 2: gain as many cards as possible; Happy Families approach
1 & 2: learn more about the local region (Roth - in the South of Nuremberg)
- acting simultaneously -
active player reads the question; first player with correct answer gets the card.

Notes:
Belongs to a series of games with a strong regional (rural) focused character (contrary to 'city games');
Usually each village of the administrative district is described.
Due to this point each game is equipped with a different no. of cards.

name: Pfötchen zieht ein!
description:
Objective: be the first reaching home position after
having finished 4 tasks; learn the needs of a pet
- moving by turns -

Each player chooses a coloured meeple and moves according die (6d-coloured) role. Having finished 4 different tasks (brushing & feeding your pet, playing with and nurse it - illustrated by 4 symbols) turn back to home position.
categories: Animals, Children's Game, Dice, Educational, Racing

name: Astro-Dom
description: Players place the diamond shaped tiles in such a way as to form zodiacs which are hexagons of the six same astrological symbols. Moon tiles act as wilds. There is also a second game in which players are given an even set of tiles and simultaneously play to build structures as fast as they can to earn more tiles.

name: Adventures of Tom Sawyer and Huck Finn
description:
Simple race game based on the Mark Twain novel first published in the United States in 1885.
The first player, who cross the road, wins the game.
Came with 4 playing pieces, 15 cards, 3 dice.

name: Toxic Zombies
description:
Toxic Zombies looks and plays like Barrel of Monkeys — but with mutated, clawed zombies replacing the friendly monkeys of decades gone by.

On a turn, the active player picks a zombie out of the dice cup, then chooses to use it to hook another zombie, and another, and another, stopping at any time he wishes. Should he drop a zombie, his turn ends immediately; otherwise, another player rolls the color die, and he scores two points for each zombie of the color rolled and one point for each other zombie. Whoever reaches a total of 23 points first wins!

name: Anex-A-Gram
description:
Anex-A-Gram is a variant of Anagrams played on a 13x13 square grid of circular holes punched through the game board. The game pieces are black wooden tiles with a circular peg on the bottom (to fit in the board's holes) and a raised-relief white letter on top. (Or in the case of one tile, a red cross.) Tile racks are included for each player. The game is an early attempt to move Anagrams onto a game board, like the later Scrabble.

As with these other games, the goal in Anex-A-Gram is to be the first to use up all of your tiles and to score the most points.

name: Ghoulash: The Last Game on Earth Card Game
description:
The classic, 1982 pen and paper game, Ghoulash, reconfigured into an action-packed card game adventure for 2 to 4 players. Set in a world overrun by Ghouls, Ghoulash: The Card Game tasks players with defeating the green, deadly monsters before they can harm innocent bystanders.

In this multi-deck game, each player takes a 40-card Character Deck, assuming the identity of one of four highly skilled Ghoul Hunters. Each character has his or her own Specialties that give them advantages over the other players.

Players explore the dark corridors of an infested office building, represented by a 72-card Encounter Deck in the middle of the playing area. The Encounter Deck is separated into four stacks known as Corridors. Players take turns moving through the Corridors, flipping cards and facing the challenges that are revealed. They can fall into Holes or be struck by Debris. They can rescue Bystanders, with welcome benefits. They'll find Perks, special items that help them throughout the game. But they'll also encounter the deadly monsters known as Ghouls, giant, green creatures of destruction that can be defeated only by the mysterious substance known as Ghoo. The stronger the Ghoul, the more Victory Points are earned by its defeat. First person to 10 Victory Points wins the game!

name: Pew Pew, Die
description:
Pew Pew, Die is a Rock, Paper, Scissors-like game using two Looney Labs pyramid dice (called a pew-pew die for this game). The pew-pew die is marked on each side with one or two triangular symbols denoting attack and defense capabilities.

Each players starts with the pew-pew die in his or her hand and mixes it around in their palm before starting. Facing one another, the players open their hands revealing the die faces. Each player can then twist their die up to 90-degrees either clockwise or counter-clockwise to orient the faces into a desired attack and defense configuration. The players then determine the result of the initial round based on the attack, defense and orientation of the pew-pew die and then make moves from this initial position to conclude the game.

For each round thereafter a player's die can only be changed in the following ways:

1) A die can be rotated 90-degrees clockwise or counter-clockwise only after flipping

2) A pew-pew die can be flipped onto its front (the side closest the opponent), left or right sides

Play proceeds for as many rounds as the players desire, up to a pre-determined number of wins -- typically three works best.

This game is inspired by the dice jousting mechanism used by Bushi Shogi.

name: So ein Dusel
description:
Objective: be the first getting rid of all your meeples
- acting by turns -
all meeples are divided equally. Active player may roll the die up to three times;
On a board, numbered 1-5 (6 = hole to drop a meeple) you have to place one of your meeples appropiate to shown result - if the space is still empty; otherwise you must collect a meeple.

name: Pop the Question
description:
Pop the Question features thirty-two cards that can be grouped into eight different four-card "marriages." Each marriage is comprised of a ring, a minister, a man, and a woman card.

The cards are dealt out for three to six players, who must take turns calling out one of the three questions on one of their cards to one of the other players. If the called out player has the matching card, he must give it to the calling player, and play continues to the left. If the card is not there, nothing happens and play continues.

Whenever a player collects a marriage of four matching cards, they are set aside to be counted at game's end. When no cards are left, the player with the most marriages wins the game.

name: Manchuria Ablaze: A Solitaire Game of the Russo-Japanese War
description:
BACKGROUND: Manchuria Ablaze is semi-historical simulation of the Russo-Japanese War (1904-1905). The Game begins shortly after the Japanese surprise naval attack on Port Arthur. The Russians are now building up their forces and gathering their fleets to kick the Japanese out of Manchuria and Korea.

OBJECTIVE: As the Commander of the Japanese Naval and Land Forces, you must gather your forces and naval squadrons to capture as many Russian Controlled Settlements before the Russian’s Baltic Fleet reaches Vladivostok or President Theodore Roosevelt signs the Portsmouth Peace Accord.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Open Drafting, Point to Point Movement, Solo / Solitaire Game

name: Bricklebrit
description:
Objective: Be the first collecting 1000 gold ducat
- acting by turns -
move according die roll & draw appropiate card; each card describes a term/place (like wood, spring, king..) which has a connection to one or more (of 10) fairy tales or gives you an additional chance. As soon as you have gained 2, 3, 6 or more you can exchange these cards getting copper, silver or gold - but all of these dropped cards must match with one fairy tale only.

Notes:
'Bricklebrit' term out of a fairytale of the Grimm Brothers: The Wishing-Table, The Gold-Ass, and The Cudgel in the Sack.
Due to the region (North-Hessen) theme of this game is related to 10 fairy tales of Grimm Brothers
categories: Children's Game, Dice, Educational, Fantasy, Trivia
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hand Management, Open Drafting, Set Collection

name: Die Märchensammler
description:
Objective: Be the first getting 7 collective gems
- moving/acting by turns -
On a 10 x 10 grid players are moving by die; grids are covered by 84 coloured slides (7 x 12) randomly, each related to one of 7 fairy tales. Additional 16 slides show events/action gems.

Prior to the beginning each player draws one of the 7 fairy tales card. Roll the die and move into chosen direction: Ending on a space with the correspondent colour (your fairy tale) you gain a collective gem. Other spaces let you draw event cards or give you 'action gems'; these gems enable you to challenge an opponent - getting an appropiate gem, too.

Notes:
Due to the region (North-Hessen) theme of this game is related to (7) fairy tales of Grimm Brothers
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Hand Management, Open Drafting, Set Collection

name: Flieg Luftballon, Flieg!
description:
Objective: be the first completing your playerboard of coloured balloons; learn about colours
- acting byturns -
roll the 6d-coloured die; appropiate to the shown colour you may place one wooden chip upon a coloured balloon;
if the die shows black - skip on turn
if the die shows white - cover a balloon of your choice

name: Kreuz und quer mit Buck durch den Verkehr
description:
The players move their cars around the game board to win or lose play money. Each Player gets 6 black cards. If he gets on a space for which he has the corresponding black card, he draws a new one, if not he has to tell the other players the meaning of the pictured traffic sign on this space. If he can not do that, he has to pay 50 "Buck Mark". On some spaces the players have to draw red (bad luck) or green (good luck) cards. If a player wins money, he can buy more cars (not the game pieces, but virtual cars, which are documented on a piece of paper).
The game ends when all red or green cards are used up. The player with the most cars and most valuable cards (black and green)wins the game.
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Believe
description:
There's a lie in the believe.
You may heard of this before, but can you really guess are the players telling the truth or it's a lie?

Believe!? is a bluffing game for 2-7 players, while each cards will show 2 dice and every player will receive 3 cards.
Like the normal dice bluffing, you need to bluff more in terms of number of dice or a higher number.
Unlike the normal dice bluffing, every "1" in the game represent "3" and "5" and every "4" represent "2" and "6" in the game unless they are called. In addtion, if you think the other player is bluffing, you can call out " You Liar". All the other player must then decide to either think the call is correct or not.

The losing team will take negative points. When a player reach a certain number of points, the game ends. That player loses and the rest win the game.

The game will be themed in the same world as the game Gold Rush.

name: Super-Chex
description:
Super-Chex is a Checkers variant for three or four players. The game is played on an 11x11 checkerboard, though the published edition's board uses circles for the active squares, leaves out the unused squares, and has lines connecting the circles diagonally to show where pieces may move.

Each player has twelve stackable checkers of their own color, and begins the game by placing them on the five outer circles of each side of the board, with four pieces centered on the next inner row, and three centered on the row after that, leaving twelve open circles in the center of the board.

The rules are the same for ordinary Checkers, including movement, capture, promoting pieces by reaching the furthest row on the other side of the board, and compulsory capture. To this, Super-Chex adds the ability of pieces to move vertically along the outer rows of the board, essentially a double move, so long as the outermost circles are vacant.

The last player with pieces on the board wins the game.

name: BabeQuest: Viking-Con Special Edition
description:
An 8 card promo expansion for BabeQuest, given out for free at Viking-Con 22 in 2003.

The expansion consist of 8 cards:
Hunting Ground: Viking-Con
Move: Smuglervodka (Smuggler Booze)
H: Arrangør (Organizor)
Babe: Elverpigen (The Elven Chick)
Move: Scoresætning (Pick-up Line)
H/U: Indre Mission (Religious Group)
Countermove: Magic-nørder (Magic Nerds)
Gear: Guldterninger (Gold Dice)

Apart from adding more variety, these cards do not change the way the game is played.
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Humor, Mature / Adult

name: HoustonOpoly
description:
Adaptation of Monopoly as players travel through Houston, TX buying, selling, and trading local landmarks such as the Galleria, Pappadeaux, and the Houston Chronicle.

Objective: To become the wealthiest resident of Houston by buying, operating, and selling local businesses. Force all other players to go out of business and you are the winner!
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: Lass dich nicht foppen!
description:
Each player gets 3 meeples, which he has to get across the board to his finish spaces, which are also the starting spaces of another player. In his turn each player can move 1 meeple 1 space in any direction. No meeple can jump over another, so they get blocked a lot. The colored spaces on the game board may only be occupied by meeples of the same color. The first player to get all 3 meeples to the finish spaces, wins the game.

The game was likely published in the 1930s.

name: Mingle: Word Roulette
description:
Players spin the word roulette with 4 or 5 metal balls. Whatever letters the balls land become the letters the players must use to create their words.

All players are active at the same time seeking out the hidden words from the wheel. They must beat the clock. The object is to score the most points per word.

Points are awarded for using uncommon letters like "q" and "z" as well as for using all the letters available.

Each player spins for wild letters, bonus points, added score words and the chance to add a prefix or suffix for even more points.

Three levels with special features and options.

name: Welcome to Storm Crow Manor
description:
Your quiet trip to Storm Crow Manor just got cut abruptly short. A deceased host, a crude instructional letter and the raging storm outside are just the start of your problems.

Welcome to Storm Crow Manor is a bluffing game where players take it upon themselves to kill or be killed in this classic murder plot. Your gracious host is dead and a letter is found instructing that a game is about to unfold.

Players awake one by one each night to secretly attack or heal one another in the night to attempt to kill the hiding murderers amongst them, beset to kill the guests one by one. If the guests don't harm anyone in the night with their item cards the murderers may have a free pass to harm whoever they like, if the guests do attack they risk making the wrong the choice.

A game of deduction and lying this is sure to please any horror or mystery fan who likes a longer game where everyone has a choice and the majority doesn't always win.
categories: Bluffing, Card Game, Deduction, Murder/Mystery, Party Game
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Deduction, Memory, Player Elimination, Voting

name: Grand-Prix Elite
description:
Grand-Prix Elite is a game about Formula 1 races (11 pages of rules).

The first car to pass through the finish line after 2 or 3 laps is the winner.

Grand-Prix Elite is played on tracks (size of gameboard = 40 cm by 60 cm, roughly). Tracks contains two types of spaces : straight section, or curve. The average length of a lap is between 40 spaces (fast tracks) and 60 spaces (long tracks). For the moment, there are 9 tracks : Monaco, Canada, Belgium, Japan, Italy, Catalunya, Singapore, China, Le mans.

Grand-prix Elite uses plastic racing cars (dimension = 27 mm long).
Six-sided dice are used for Wear tests, Skid tests, etc...
Optional rules include weather variation and Event cards.

HOW TO PLAY : each player has a certain number of Speed cards. In order to move his car he plays 1 Speed card.
Then the Speed card goes to his dashboard : this is now the current speed of the car.
Each turn, the player can increase or decrease this speed by 1 level.
Also, extra movements are given by a Tyre-Setup card located in the dashboard. The Tyre-Setup card represents the strategy chosen for the car (soft, hard or rain tyres, aero grip, suspension, etc..)
Once moved, a car can engage another car in order to gain its position.

Each player faces 3 challenges in this game :
a) Damages. The number of Speed cards owned by the player is also the number of damages his car can absorb without consequences. Powerful Speed cards often leads to damages (due to engine wear or dangerous curve)...Some cars are fast but fragiles, so pit stops will be necessary in this case.
b) Curves. Each curve has an optimal speed. If a car's speed exceeds the optimal speed while taking the curve, the car can goes off track (and possibly taking damages).
However, a driver has 3 choices when his car is about to take a curve : short, medium, or long trajectory. With a short trajectory, you go faster, but it's risky. With a long trajectory, you take the curve more easily, but you become an easy prey if engaged by opponents...
Here, tyre and set-up strategies are very important things for purpose of taking a curve.
c) Ghost cars. In addition to his normal car, each player controls one or several Ghost cars. Ghost cars follow their own rules, and symbolize the bulk of lapped cars driven by anonymous drivers. Their purpose is to annoy other players.
mechanics: Open Drafting, Point to Point Movement, Simulation

name: Edakhar
description:
Family game for 2 to 8 players.

The aim of the game is to be the first who reaches the center of the board with one of your pawns.

Every player get 4 pawns in one color.
Put 3 pawns in the holes marked on the side of the board.

The starting player put 1 pawn in the first black or white hole.
Then he turns the black or the white disc one space to the left or the right.
If all the players puts there first pawn in play like this, the starting player can now move a pawn in play, one step ahead or back OR bring a new pawn in play in the first hole.
If you put a pawn in a black hole you have to move the black disc. And for the white hole you move the white disc.

If someone turns 1 of the 2 discs, it can happen that one or more pawns fall true the board. So you lose a pawn.

name: Ching Gong for Four
description:
Ching Gong for Four is a Halma variant for two, three or four players on a unique star-shaped board with eight points. The board is comprised of 133 dots connected by lines, with 11 dots on each corner and 45 in the center of the board. The eight star points are in four colors, each color matching the star point on the opposite side of the board. The players' pieces begin on a star point of the same color, and the objective is to be the first to move all of a player's pieces to the opposite star point and win the game.

Rules for movement are the same as for Halma and Chinese Checkers, meaning that players take turns moving one piece at a time in any direction, and that players may jump their own or other players' pieces. Pieces are not removed from the board. The pieces must move only along the lines connecting the dots on the board however, and Ching Gong for Four's board is unusual in this regard. Not only does it have eight points or corners instead of four or six, but not every dot is connected to the other. Half the dots are connected to eight surround dots, the other half only four surrounding dots.

This game is not to be confused with another game from the same publisher, Ching Gong for Two, which is played on a standard Chinese Checkers board and has three colors of pieces.

name: Dungeon Arena
description: Dungeon Arena is a frenetic dice-rolling arena battle for two to four players. Players construct a dungeon randomly from available tiles containing hidden bonuses, obstacles, and other features, and then select the class of their fighters. Each class receives a specific configuration of dice that contain some combination of movement, attacking, and turning that is unique to that class. Then, in real-time, players roll their dice as many times as they want to and "lock in" each of their desired dice and take the actions shown on the dice. After a time limit, whichever player has removed the most other players' pawns from the board while sacrificing the fewest of their own is the winner!
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Player Elimination

name: The Spider and The Flies
description:
The board represents a spider's web. The spider's den is in the center. 19 pieces are used: one spider, 13 common(yellow) flies and five blue(green) flies. Blue flies count three and common flies are one for a total of 28 points. One team is the flies the other team is the spider. Object of game is to score 15 points. Flies attempt to get into spider's den and score according to their values. Spider seeks to consume flies and keep them out of his den.

Moves are somewhat like checkers. Spider jumps the flies and removes them from the board. Flies do not jump. Common flies may only move forward or around the circle. Blue flies may move backwards as well.

Flies start first. The spider may move in a straight line on any of the lines running toward the center as far as he please. He cannot pass over the double circle either going out or coming in without stopping there one move. On all the circles except the double one the spider cannot move any further than the flies can (one space). On the double circle the spider may move 1/4 of the way around at one move. The spider may jump in any direction as many times as his moves entitle him to. He is requited to stop at the next crossing beyond each fly jumped. If several flies are in position with but one crossing between each fly he must jump all such flies (no matter what direction it takes him) stopping at the next crossing beyond the last fly.

The spider may jump from his den and take any fly on the double circle unless there is another fly in front of or behind it. It also enables him when on the double circle to take a fly standing on the crossing 1/4 the way around if there is no fly on the next crossing beyond and none between. The spider may move clear across the double circle passing through the center on his way and jump a fly on the opposite side of the double circle if there are no intervening flies and none beyond the fly to back him up. The spider may move from the double circle to the outside circle in one move (nothing intervening) but cannot return to the center when outside the double circle without stopping one move on the way at the double circle.

name: Ilmatsalu linnuretk: lisakaardid
description:
First expansion pack with 30 additional bird-species.

The game is played by moving around the forest (game board) and collecting information tokens for birds. Certain places ask questions and answering them, lets you keep the card. First one to collect certain number is the winner.
categories: Animals, Card Game, Educational, Expansion for Base-game

name: Chicken Draw: The Chicken Maker Card Game
description:
Two Player card game in which each player attempts to reduce the other player's Power to zero before their own is.

Each player selects a card from their hand as their leader, and plays additional cards to support it. The two sides compare their Attack and the loser's Power is reduced by the difference. After that each player loses Power for each card they have played and play proceeds.

The game's art is from postings on the Chicken Maker blog.

name: Tips!
description:
Tips! is a game of hot plates & cold revenge. Hustle for the biggest tips, sabotaging co-workers along the way.

~~~How does it play?~~~~

Serve your customers drinks, appetizers, main dishes and desserts in large quantities. The number of menu items you can serve of each type is constrained by the party size, also the menu items need to be served in a particular order (no dessert before the main meal in this place!). Minimize the number of times you get an order wrong, have customers run out the door without paying, and taking annoying restroom breaks (try to just hold it in!).

At the end of the game, each player counts up their tips - whoever has the most wins!

name: Was Großmütterchen erzählt
description:
Goal: Be the first racing to position '50'

Game Play:
Typical 'roll & move' game - Roll the die by turns and step forward - ending on a marked space follow instructions glued into the lid.

Notes:
Likely published late 1920's/early 30's

name: Im Märchen = und Wunderland
description:
Goal: Be the first to race to position '50' (back home);
learn more about fairy tales

Game Play:
Typical 'roll & move' game - Roll the die by turns and step forward - ending on a marked space follow instructions.
publishers: A. Anton & Co., Leipzig, Verlag von Auerbachs Deutschem Kinder Kalender

name: Halali
description:
Objective: Get as many bonus points as possible
- acting by turns -
Each player gets 3 x 3 cards; cards show animals (mostly herbivores and a few carnivores) and the hunter; each card has a special value, which adds up to a total sum of 220 points;

Active player plays a herbivore out of a given class eg. (4) birds, rated from 1-4 /the higher the number the stronger). Next player must play a card of this class; if he/she hasn't any there is a choice to play a matching carnivore or discard a random card. Trick is made by the carnivore player or highest rating within demanded class. Hunter card can be used as a joker, points can be doubled under certain circumstances (announcements).

Notes:
Different from 1966 published 'Halali' (Happy Families) card game (same publisher)

name: Binary
description:
The goal of the game is to get rid of all your card before anyone else does. However, it is easier said than done and players are limited in the ways they can play cards.

Players can only put down a card on a pile with the same design and color. Each card placed down needs to be higher then the previous one.

The game starts with three open piles. Each pile is played until no players can put down any more cards. At this point the first player who was unable to put down any cards opens up a new pile.

There are 8 special cards in the deck. 6 closing cards, and 2 switching cards. A closing card allows a player to close any pile of the same color, and open up a new one at any point. The switching cards allows a player to switch the color of a pile with the same background color, and the design of a pile to anything they would like. The next card played after a switch card must still be higher then the number under it.

name: Es geht um die Wurst
description:
There are two dogs and six cats. The cats try to steal the Wurst and escape. The dogs have to protect their Wurst. Cats and dogs may move in any direction as many spaces as they roll with one die. Cats can only jump over cats and dogs over dogs. If a dog gets on a space with a cat, he drives the cat from the game board. If the cat has the Wurst, the dog gets really mad and kills the cat. The cats even try to steal the wurst from each other. If a cat escapes with the Wurst, it wins the game. A dog has to kill three cats to win the game (nice doggy).

This game was published in the 1930s or 40s.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Age of Piracy
description:
It is the Caribbean in the 16th century. New lands have been discovered, and the stories about riches and influence on the new continent are abound in the old world. Resources aplenty cause the royal dynasties of Europe to secure huge chunks of
the new world. They send out brave captains and seamen to gather influence for their own country.

Set sail and head west, your monarch needs you.

name: Now You See It
description:
FROM THE BOX:

The game based on the popular TV Programme NOW YOU SEE IT. One of the players acts as the reader, reads out the clues and stars the timer. The first player to stop the timer and name the hidden word scores the points.

The board game itself was based on the 1985-1993 Seven Network (then later Nine Network from 1998-1999) kids game show which in turn was based on the short-lived 1974-75 and 1989 adult game show from America of the same name.
categories: Movies / TV / Radio theme, Trivia, Word Game

name: Lucky Shot
description:
The object of the game is to get your own tiddlywinks into three cups worth either 25 or 50 points. Players take turns flicking their winks onto the board, trying to land them in the cups. There are some free turn spaces on the board, and if players land their pieces there, they can take another turn.

If players miss the cups, they can place an additional piece on the board, and on additional turns, players can either flick their winks or roll a die to move their piece on the board. When they land their piece on a color that matches their pieces, they can make another attempt to flick a wink into a cup. If they manage to get their piece to the end of the trail, they place one of their winks into the cup at the end of their trail and take their piece back.

The cups at the end of the trails are worth 25 points each, while the one that can only be reached by the tiddlywinks is worth 50 points. The game ends when one player has all four of his winks in the cups, and players total up the points of all their winks. Whoever has the highest points wins the game.

name: World Eaters
description:
The Emperor is dead. Dragon Empire stands on the brink of destruction as four evil forces try to conquer the last place standing: the capitol — but then another threat looms, an alien invasion force that just wants to devour our world.

World Eaters gives players the chance to play as four main evils (Orcs, Demons, Undead, Cold ones) and to conquer as much terrain as they can by rolling dice, recruiting armies, then sending them to fight by collecting dice pools.

As much as evil will act brutally - that much Burn they collect and that much retaliation from Empire they will get. On Map 9x9 there will be cities to attack and either plunder them or conquer to gain resources bringing players closer to victory.

On their turn each player will throw dice depending on their logistic power to bring more troops, send them for quest, prepare the attack, build forts or sending spies to see the defense on city they wish to attack.

name: Kylim
description:
The game follows the tradition of trick-taking card games.

Kylim allows up to 10 players to enjoy a trick taking game with a twist. Several suites of cards are mixed, in an untraditional arrangement; some of the suits are present several times, others only once, and not all suits have all the numbers in them, bringing variability to the game.

The aim of the game is to predict one's own ability to gain tricks. Furthermore, players can bid on other player's ability to take tricks. And finally, there is a booster card ready to throw everybody's strategy overboard...

name: Animallum
description:
Animallum is an home-brewed card game where players must gather and trade resources both from Earth and a handful of other planets in order to save our alien-abducted wildlife. Use your skills as an agent of Earth to navigate galactic economies and become the first player to rescue every animal in your assigned, extraterrestrial zoo-bank!

- 306 poker-sized cards per box
- 40 exotic species of animals to rescue
- Over 10 different resources to gather and trade
- Independently designed and published

name: Hoppla jetzt komm ich
description:
Be the first bringing your meeples 'home'; get as many bonus points as possible.
- moving by turns -
Depending on no. of participants each player draws (movement) cards and gets 6 meeples; during your race you have to overcome obstacles, other meeples by drawing & playing 'appropiate' cards.

Each card offers 3 movement points, which have to be allocated on listed meeples (numbered 1-6). If you see a double or triple number you have to move this meeple, only. In front of an obstacle or another meeple you are forced to play such cards, otherwise you are blocked and your movement is forfeited.

Depending on your position your meeple entered the finish zone you gain bonus points. Player/team with most bonus points is the winner. Two teams are formed if more than 2 players participate.
Notes:
Likely published during 1930's

name: Lothar Matthäus: Meine fünfte Weltmeisterschaft
description:
Objective: Be the first moving all your meeples into opponent's home area
- moving by turns -
Throw the die and move according result one of your meeples into target direction: a space with identical (shirt) number. Jumping is not allowed, you may not hit opponent's meeples. A '6' moves you into a corner (captured) - you may escape with another '6'.

Notes:
Promotional game for Soccer World Championship 1998

name: Auf allen Wegen zum neuentdeckten Nordpol
description:
Objective: Be the first reaching target space
- moving by turns -
Simple 'Roll & Move' game; ending on a space check for instructions.

Note:
Was published Dec. 1909 as newspaper insert for Christmas.

name: Pet Trainer
description:
Pet Trainer puts you in the role of a trainer in search of animals worthy of their stable. Players battle it out over control of cat girls, pretty ponies, and a plethora of other adorable animals. Pet cards are placed in front of each player. 3 toy cards are drawn and 1 is used to tame the savage beast or befriend the adorable animals. With a role of the die, you try and match or roll higher than the number marked on the Toy card. Successful roles go toward taming a pet, while unsuccessful roles may run them off. Collecting pets gives you points toward victory. Successfully gather enough pets to reach 20 points and you win. Home grown rules make Pet Trainer the must-have game for pet play enthusiast looking for a “good time.” Train well and play nice!

Mature/Adult audiences:
- Designed for pet play, anamorphic, and Furry enthusiasts.
- Mild bondage and control themes.
categories: Animals, Card Game, Dice, Fantasy, Mature / Adult
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Open Drafting, Push Your Luck

name: Trivial Pursuit: Quiz-Mania
description:
There are many questions about nature and our world.
1200 of these and their answers are put into Quiz Mania - the game for more awareness of our world.

Migros and the WWF present a new version of the classic game Game: Trivial Pursuit for adults and children. Answer interesting questions to the 6 categories climate, forest & meadow, mountain, sea, people and food and fill your playing piece with the 6 category-wedges. The winner is who first earned all six knowledge wedges and has answered the master question correctly.

name: Dschungel Abenteuer
description:
Description taken from the box:
Your expedition into the jungle starts innocuous. But from start on it gets adventurous. Your adventurer teams boldly fight their way through the thicket. Your path leads over dangerous bridges over the 4 arms of the river. A few will lose balance and fall into the water.
Which adventurers will be the fastest and can return to the main camp?

Dschungel Abenteuer is a Snakes and Ladders style game.
On a player's turn you roll 2 dice, one for each of your adventurers.
During the course of the game you must place bridges to cross the rivers, but you just can move a built bridge to screw your opponents.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move, Take That

name: Burbank-Opoly: The Media City
description:
Monopoly-style board game based on the city of Burbank, California.

Contents: 14 elementary school cards, 14 providence cards, 28 deed cards, 6 metal tokens, 2 dice, 12 yellow houses, 28 red houses, assorted money, instructions.

Published after 2008.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Eglantine et les fourmis
description:
Eglantine et les fourmis was the first in a planned series of games titled "Nos amis les insectes" (our friends the insects). It is a simple wargame involving ants.

There are two scenarios provided. The scenario for two players has one controlling black ants and the other red ants. The black ant player sends workers out to find breadcrumbs and twigs and return them to the anthill, and sends soldiers out to protect the workers. The red and player has a small number of ants who invade the area and try to capture the workers.

The black ant player does not know where the breadcrumbs and twigs are, as they are among a bunch of pieces randomly placed face-down on the board at the start of the game. Other pieces are impassable obstacles and an antlion which immediately kills the ant finding it.

There is also a solitaire scenario in which the player controls the black ants and has to get a certain number of breadcrumbs back to the hill. Making this difficult is Eglantine the praying mantis, who moves around the board randomly and kills any ant it gets near.

name: Circusboy Corky
description:
Objective:
Be the first reaching space 133;
simple 'Roll and Move' game - moving by turns.
Stepping on a marked space follow instructions.
categories: Children's Game, Dice, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Racing

name: Cambio y Bolsa, Mercado, y Miau
description:
(SP)
Recopilación de tres juegos de cartas.
Que són: Cambio y Bolsa (Pit), Mercado (Going to market) y Miau (Spite & Malice).
Los componentes són 10 barajas de 15 cartas y dos especificas para Cambio y Bolsa.

(EN)
Compilation of three sets of cards.
They are: Cambio y Bolsa (Pit), Mercado (Going to Market) and Miau (Spite & Malice).
The components are 10 decks of 15 cards and two specific for Pit.

Link's to the referenced games:

Pit
Going to Market
Spite & Malice

name: Wir bauen ein Haus
description:
Objective: be the first reaching target space (100).
Simple 'Roll & Move' game, moving by turns.
Ending on a green/red coloured space follow instructions.

Likely published during 1950's

name: Lustige Bubenstreiche
description:
Objective: be the first, reaching space 40.

Simple 'Roll & Move' game, moving by turns.
Ending on a red marked space follow instructions (in rhyme).

Likely should had been published ~ 1920's.

name: Der Glücksvogel
description:
Objective: gain as much money as possible
- acting by turns -
push the spinner; perform the order.
(spend/win money)

Published before WWII

name: Rescue the King
description: Rescue the King is a dexterity-strategy game with a chess theme and a Capture-the-Flag style. Each piece moves in its own way, much like in the game of chess, but they must be flicked across the table. The goal is to get your king (who cannot be flicked) back to your own throne, which is a sticker you put on your side of the table.

name: Stampede
description:
Stampede is played on a 12x12 grid of circles, with a square of nine circles removed from each corner. There is a central “open range” area of thirty-six circles that separates four side areas, one for each player’s starting positions, where they will place nine Cattle pieces and nine Cowboy pieces in numerical order according to the markings on the board and on the pieces.

Players will take turns moving with the objective of being the first to move their Cattle and Cowboy pieces to the opponent’s starting position on the opposite side of the board. Pieces may move in any direction. Cattle pieces move to an open adjacent circle or by jumping a friendly or opponent piece to a vacant circle on the other side. Cowboys move this way, but also may jump over any number of pieces in a row to reach a vacant circle on the opposite side. Pieces are not removed from the board.

The first player to move all of his pieces to the opposite side and match the piece numbers to the board numbers wins the game. Variants are provided using a system of scoring.

name: Von Tor zu Tor / Wünsch dir was
description:
The box includes a two sided game board with two games.

"Von Tor zu Tor" is a soccer simulation, where the movement of the ball is determined by a die.

"Wünsch dir was" is a travel game, where up to 5 players travel the world and try to collect game markers, which represent merchandise (gold, butter, cheese, coffee, ...) If a player rolls a 6, he places a marker at a destination on the board. When a player reaches a destinatin with one or more markers on it, he gets to collect the markers. The player, who collects most of the markers, wins the game.

The game was most likely published in the 1930s or 40s.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Pick-up and Deliver, Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move, Simulation

name: Elektro-Brumm
description:
Objective: Be the first reaching space 61 precisely
- moving by turns -
Roll the die and move forward; if you hear a noise (brumm) move stepwise backwards until you hear - nothing.
Moving back you hit all other meeples (must start again). If you throw a '6' - and there is 'no noise', you may roll & move again.

name: Pilzsucherspiel
description:
Objective: be the first turning back home (forest cabin); learn wild mushrooms
- moving by turns -
simple 'Roll & Move' game; ending on a marked space follow instructions glued on lid inside
categories: Children's Game, Dice, Educational, Environmental, Racing

name: Reise durch die Schweiz nach den italienischen Seen
description:
Objective: Be the first traveling through Switzerland (space 80)
- moving by turns -
simple 'Roll & Move' game; ending on any space follow instructions.
as usual: pay money - get money back being 1st, 2nd, 3rd

notes:
very nice/cute pewter pawns - impressive drawings
likely published ~1900

name: Traumatosaures
description:
Traumatosaures takes place in the neurological ward of the Coeurs Brisés (Heartbreak) Hospital. The patients on the ward are dreaming of the traumatosaures, creatures from another dimension, who appear in the hospital and try to absorb the patients so they can return home.

The game takes place in hourly turns over the course of one night. One player takes the role of the nursing staff, who move around getting treatments (pills, injections, and electroshock devices), administering treatments, waking up sleeping patients, and moving patients from room to room. However, they do not have free choice when moving the nurses; for each one a die is rolled, giving two possible rooms they can go to.

The traumatosaure player moves the traumatosaures that have appeared in the hospital (because the matching patients fell asleep) and moves them, also using die rolls, which now determine how far to move (half speed if the patient is now awake). The traumatosaure player also has a certain number of "AARRGGHH" tokens which can be used on patients to make it harder to help them.

The advanced game adds fixed events which take place each turn.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move

name: King of Danger
description:
In the Land of Danger, there is nothing a King likes better than a gigantic, audacious castle. How else are you to flaunt your power and wealth?

King of Danger is a trick taking game where you are one of those Kings ... and the tricks you take will either build up your castle, or tear down the others.

Scoring is based on the size of your castle at the end of each hand. Whoever has the most points at the end of the game – the King who owned the biggest castle most often – must be the King of Danger!
categories: Card Game, Fantasy, Medieval, Print & Play

name: Jet Fighter
description: This cardgame simulates a dogfight between two or more aircraft, through the union of the cards forming the trajectory of fighters. When the player wants, can shoot a missile. The opponent then rolls the dice to see how many points of damage received.
categories: Aviation / Flight, Card Game, Modern Warfare
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hand Management, Network and Route Building

name: SOCK-O
description:
SOCK-O is a game of dexterity and chance. The game's chips are divided evenly between the players. One player will be the "Socker." The other players each take a wooden ball with a string attached and place it into the center of a ring on the table, holding on to the string. The Socker then holds a rubber cup in one hand and rolls a pair of six-sided dice.

Whenever the Socker rolls a seven or eleven (SOCK-O!) he must then slap the cup down and try to catch one or more of the balls in the ring. If he catches someone, they must give him a chip. If he fails to catch someone, he must give them a chip. Players who pull away prematurely are penalized a chip. If the Socker mistakenly slaps the cup down, he is penalized a chip for every player whose piece is still in the ring.

The Socker continues rolling the dice until he has had three SOCK-O's, at which point he trades with the player to his left and play continues with the new Socker. The player with the most chips when the game ends (by default or agreement) wins the game.

name: Steel Angels
description: Steel Angels depicts the final steps towards the passing of the 19th amendment to the U. S. Constitution. The Women's Suffrage Movement (1900-1920) is covered in a card-driven, partial co-op fashion. The fight is conducted by players using individual, matching decks of cards to fight the challenges of the status quo. Ratification of the amendment requires the acceptance of 36 states. While competing state-by-state individually, players must beat the time frame of history to secure a victory; failure to do so is a loss for all players.
mechanics: Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Chit-Pull System

name: Trio
description:
Trio is a game for three, played an a grid of 52 triangular cells (in two alternating colors) arranged in the shape of an equilateral triangle, but with its corners cut off and replaced with a curved line connecting the outer edges of the board, forming its own cell. Each of these additional cells is called a Fortress and belongs to a player.

Each player has three kinds of pieces in their own color: one General, four Officers, and seven Soldiers. To begin the game, the General pieces are placed in the middle triangle of the first row adjoining that player's Fortress. Filling out that row are the four Officers. The next row inward has seven triangles and each are occupied by Soldiers. These two rows are known as each player's Zone.

The object of the game is to move a General into an opponent's Fortress. A cell may be occupied by only one piece at a time; players capture each other's pieces by landing on the same cell and removing the opponent's piece from the board. Capture is not compulsory, and continuing moves after a capture is not permitted. Movement of the pieces is through the sides of the triangular cells, not the points.

A Soldier moves to one adjacent cell in any direction except backwards towards his home Fortress. An Officer moves across two adjacent cells, unless there is a piece he wishes to capture in one adjacent cell. After capturing, he must remain in that cell until the next turn. While in their own Zone, Officers may not move back towards their own Fortress. Once out of their Zone, Officers may move in any direction. Generals move across one or two adjacent cells in any combination of directions, so long as they do not return to the same cell on the same turn.

The first player to move his General into an opponent's Fortress wins the game. Since it is possible for any piece to capture any other piece, it is possible that all three Generals could be captured and no player would win.
publishers: (Public Domain), Amsterdamsche Houtwaren Fabriek, Homas Spelen, The Game Crafter, LLC

name: The Raccoon is at the Candy Shoppe
description:
You are an international Spymaster for a global power during the Cold War. Uses your influence and espionage skills to sway the greatest spies in the world to your cause.

The Raccoon, the greatest spy the Cold War has ever knewn, is up for grabs. As a overseer for one of the great superpowers try and recruit The Raccoon, and his fellow super-spies, to your cause. By peddling influence, sending agents on strategic missions and carefully timing your secret plots you can sway these critical soldiers in the shadows and declare victory without dropping a single bomb.

The Raccoon is at the Candy Shoppe challenges 3-6 players to deduce who is friend and who is foe. Use your table position to send your suspected enemies’ agents into danger or to control the outcome of an assignment. Will your carefully laid traps eliminate a dangerous spy or will your most trusted resource double cross you?

Each turn you will send a spy out to a hotspot in the Cold War. When they arrive all spymasters will secretly spend tokens to influence the spy toward their goal or to twist the outcome of the mission. After all available spies have been placed players take turns revealing the tokens at each location and choosing how the mission will resolve. If your ideology has the most spies on your side at the end of the game, you win the Cold War!
categories: Bluffing, Deduction, Memory, Political, Print & Play, Spies/Secret Agents
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Memory, Secret Unit Deployment, Team-Based Game, Variable Phase Order, Worker Placement

name: The Game of Circination or Swinging Round the Circle
description:
Circination is a puzzle and strategy game, resembling Chinese Checkers, but played with round pegs.

Circination is a game for two players. There are 36 white pieces and 36 black pieces. The object is to get these pieces around the circles on the board and off the board when home.

name: Train for Boston
description: Typical spin and move children's game. Each player selects a city and puts his piece upon the Railroad Station. Spin the indicator in turn, moving forward as many spaces as spin. The player who first reach the Station at Boston by exact spin wins the game.

name: Kastellet
description:
Kastellet is a game for two, played on a hexagonal board comprised of sixty-one smaller hexagons, five to each side. The central hex is referred to as the Point, and may not be played upon by either participant. There is a unique neutral piece called the “Roy” which is used to mark the Point. Each player has thirteen pieces in their own color, as follows: five Flag pieces, four Maces, three Lances, and one Bar. Only one piece may be on a hex at a time; landing on an occupied hex is a capture, and the opponent's piece is removed from the game. The object of the game is to continually “cover” the Point by always having at least one piece ready to move onto it. Should a player lose his pieces covering the Point and not be able to move another piece into covering position on the next turn, he loses the game.

The game begins with the players at opposite ends of the board, with a five hexagon side closest to them. Their five Flags are placed on those closest five hexes, the player's back line. Flags only move forward to one adjacent hex, toward the opponent's end of the board. Should a Flag reach the center hex of the opponent's back line, on the next turn (if it has not since been captured) it can be exchanged for that player's Bar piece, which is held in reserve at the start of the game. The Bar can be placed anywhere on the board, but will remain there for the rest of the game, unable to be moved or captured by either player. No further moves are allowed for that turn.

Maces begin the game two to a side on both ends of the players' Flags, extending around the rim of the board. Maces may move to any adjacent hex, in any direction.

Lances begin in the central three hexes of the third row of hexes inward from the players' back lines. The movement of a Lance is through the points and lines of the adjacent hexes to one of up to six hexes just beyond. The game's hexes may have three alternating colors so that the color-bound moves of the Lances are obvious. Because of its position on the board and its style of movement, the central of the three Lances begins the game covering the Roy.

name: Synergy
description:
In the first days of the grid's construction, power maximization was key. Designers were enlisted to establish the flow of energy and information across the digital landscape. Seeking the optimal data configurations for each cell was paramount, and soon, friendly competition arose. Who would create the greatest SYNERGY across the grid?

SYNERGY pits two to four digital designers against one another in a race to score the highest, playing to a single GRID of cards. Gain points for matching card edges to cards already on the table. Score extra points for making multiple matches with a single play, and earn bonuses for focusing on your own personal synergies!

name: Stop-Over Düsseldorf
description:
This game consists of two sub-games. In the first game players take the role of journalists and try to get to the sat-van as quick as possible in order to upload the three pictures they have to capture in this game. The pictures are all Düsseldorf-buildings or sites and have a UFO sighting on them.

This is a Malefiz kind of adaptation.

In the second part the game, journalists try to get the cover-story before the other players can by running up the stairs of the publisher trying to beat the others to his office.

name: Stop-Over Dortmund
description:
This game consists of two sub-games. In the first game players take the role of journalists and try to get to the sat-van as quick as possible in order to upload the three pictures they have to capture in this game. The pictures are all Dortmund-buildings or sites and have a UFO sighting on them.

This is a Malefiz kind of adaptation.

In the second part the game, journalists try to get the cover-story before the other players can by running up the stairs of the publisher trying to beat the others to his office.

name: Stop-Over Wien
description:
This game consists of two sub-games. In the first game players take the role of journalists and try to get to the sat-van as quick as possible in order to upload the three pictures they have to capture in this game. The pictures are all Vienna-buildings or sites and have a UFO sighting on them.

This is a Malefiz kind of adaptation.

In the second part the game, journalists try to get the cover-story before the other players can by running up the stairs of the publisher trying to beat the others to his office.

name: Heroes of Argos: A Game of Heroic Adventure in Ancient Greece
description:
Each player represents a Greek Hero in the Heroic Age of Ancient Greece. Heroes attempt to complete great quests and gain fame, treasures and glory. The Hero that has accumulated the most Glory Points (GP) at the end of the Game Turns is declared the most renowned Hero of Greece!

As a Hero, you must gather followers, equip yourselves with weapons and armor, obtain a ship and venture throughout the mediterranean to complete Quests, slay monsters, and gain Glory to last through the ages.

Heroes of Argos features colorful and graphic counters of Heroes, Champions, Monsters, Ships, Weapons, Armor and a variety of encounters.

If you enjoy Greek Mythology, The Iliad, The Odyssey, or Jason and the Argonauts, you will enjoy this game.
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Hexagon Grid

name: Dogs of War: A Solitaire Game of Modern Mercenary Actions and Adventure
description:
Dogs of War is a game of Modern Mercenary Actions and Adventure. The player assumes the role of a Commander of a special group of Mercenaries available for hire by corporations and governments to complete hazardous missions. As the Commander, you must accept dangerous missions and assemble your Mercenaries in order to successfully resolve the missions.

GAME OBJECTIVE
The objective of Dogs of War is to successfully complete a number of missions in order to gain the highest profit, as determined by Resource Points (RP), for your outfit. The player can choose to play a short game (4 Missions), an average game (6 Missions) or a long game (8 Missions). Once all Missions have been resolved (successfully or not) the Player totals his RP earned and compares this with the Commander’s Profit Table to determine the level of success.

Game features Units with stunning graphics that include MERC Teams, Militia, Government Troops, PBRs, Hueys, MI-17s, Alouette Helicopters, Hind Gunships, Leaders, Tanks, AFVs, Mortars, Artillery and Airstrikes.

Mission Actions and Combat are resolved on a tactical level.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hexagon Grid, Open Drafting

name: Pet-Opoly
description:
In this variation to Monopoly, young players move around a board based on pets.

From the publisher:

Pet-opoly is like a trip through the pet store of your dreams! While you play, flip over the deeds and learn fun facts about pets and how to care for them.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Open Drafting, Set Collection, Trading
publishers: Late for the Sky Production Company

name: Zoo-Opoly
description:
A Monopoly edition for the very young ones.

From the publisher:
Take a trip to see the animals without even getting in the car. Collect footprints and trade them in for animals. Soon you'll find yourself a zookeeper in charge of lions, zebras, rhinos, polar bears and other fascinating wild animals.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Open Drafting, Set Collection, Trading
publishers: Late for the Sky Production Company

name: Iron Horses:  The Board Game
description: Re-live the great age of steam. In Iron Horses: The Board Game, you are a captain of industry, seeking to expand your burgeoning railroad empire. Players carefully build trains with engine, car, and caboose cards to earn the greatest profits. Finished trains deliver goods to one of six regions in the country. Making deliveries allows you to collect stock and manipulate prices. Earn the most money by the end of the game to become the winner!
mechanics: Hand Management, Open Drafting, Stock Holding

name: Panchadevi
description:
In times of greed pervades the lives of the Goddesses, the war of no longer inevitable. Five Goddess consisting of earth, water, fire, air, and ether agreed to compete for "sixth element". Elements which can not only increase strength but also can make the Goddess of Life.

In Sanskrit, Panchadevi means five goddesses, this is a card game that uses dice were also in play. So the factor of luck and strategy, interplay to be a winner.

Each player will play one of the five goddesses and fight each other to gain victory points (VP) by collecting card of elements. Each card has a different VP and each player was released to collect cards of any type of element. However, if the player manages to collect cards of the same elements as his goddess then amount of VP of that card mentioned multiplied by two.

The game will be more challenging because if the player collects more than three cards of the same elements, then VP of a number of card mentioned has aborted and each card will only be worth 1VP. At the end of the game, the whole of VP will be totaled and the player with the highest VP is declared the winner.

name: Potty Ponies And Friends!
description:
Potty Ponies is a roll and move dice throwing game where players will land on illustrated squares depicting country life. Most of the squares incorporate childlike humour coming directly from the designer's rural experiences.

Players are represented by ponies. They collect apples, carrots and sugar lumps as they progress around the board and encounter other animals. At the end of the game children have to use a score pad to add up their points.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Venator Praeda
description:
Are you a hunter or prey?
In this game, the roles can be reversed, and that you are a hunter or a boar makes no difference: You have to survive!

Abstract strategy game where players move disc-shaped pieces across a functional and original board.

The Huntsmen can move forward diagonally and vertically for one or two space. the first move of every huntsmen pieces is only in forward vertically for one or two spaces.
The Wild Boars can move forward diagonally and vertically for one, two, or three space. the first move of every Boars pieces is only in forward vertically for one, two, or three spaces.
The huntsmen can attack the Wild Boars every time, with legit moves.
The Wild Boars can attack only if they made the TURNABOUT, and opponent pieces didn't, or if they didn't make the TURNABOUT, but the opponent pieces did, with legit moves.

When a piece reach a square occupied by an opponent piece, with legit moves and the right conditions, the attack is valid; if there is no right condition (Like TURNABOUT Boar and TURNABOUT Hunt) is not valid.

The piece attacked is removed from the board.

For Obtain the TURNABOUT a piece have to reach a start square of the opponent piece. Now, their moves are backwards.
For cancel the TURNABOUT, simply reach a start squre of your team.

wins the game who removes or blocks all opposing pieces.

name: Eine Fahrt aufs Land
description:
Objective: Be the first reaching space 130
- moving by turns -
Simple 'Roll & Move' game. Ending on a marked space follow instructions.

name: Lo-Hu
description:
Objective: Move one of your 3 'Double'-figures back home - or eliminate all opponent's 'Doubles'
- moving by turns/ forward or backwards/starting positions white & black -

Abstract strategy game where players move disc-shaped pieces across an 12 by 12 cross-hatched ("checker") board.

Pieces only move diagonally, and only one or two space(s) at a time.
If a player can move one of his/her pieces so that it jumps over adjacent pieces of their opponent (only foreward, laterally or backwards - NOT diagonally) into an empty space, that player captures the opponent's discs. Jumping moves must be taken when possible.
If one of your discs reaches opponent's home base it mutates to a 'Double' (max. 3 x, after that opponent's home base is blocked). The movement range of a 'Double' is limited down to one space.

Note:
Back of the board: 'Nine Men Morris'

name: Druids
description:
Druids is played on a six-sided board divided into 88 triangular cells. There are three long sides of the board, equivalent to six of the cell's sides in length, and three short sides, two cells in length. The overall shape is of a triangle with it's points cut off, and the game's pieces (Stones) share this shape. Half of the board's cells are recessed, and divided into three color groups: black for a triangular Field in the center of the board, and red, yellow, and green for each of the Camps in the corners of the board. In each of the recessed Camp cells are a number of dots in one of these quantities: one, three, six, ten, and fifteen, with the smaller quantities being closer to the center of the board.

Each player starts play with nine Stones of the same color as his Camp, placed in all the cells of his Camp. The game is played only in the recessed cells of the board. Players take turns moving their Stones one at a time in an attempt to move all the stones of their color into one or both of their opponents' Camps. Stones may move to any one vacant adjacent cell (there are up to six adjacent recessed areas) per turn, so long as they do not re-enter their own Camp. Stones may jump over one opponent's piece to an empty adjacent cell on the opposite side; stones are not removed from the board. Jumps over friendly Stones are not allowed.

The rules allow for final scores to be tallied based on the number of dots covered by each player in their opponent's Camps, and for alternate winning conditions.

name: Golfing
description:
An Edwardian board game with graphics based on Felixstowe's course and its famous Morrello Tower. Printed rules for the game pasted down to inside box top. Invented by Sir Frederick Frankland, Bart.

Typical spin and move game. The first player, who cross the road, wins the game.

name: Quer durch Asien
description:
Objective:
Be the first to reach Tokio (starting from Istanbul or St. Petersburg)
- moving by turns/simple 'Roll & Move' game -
Pay money to buy in - choose one of four different routes (dotted or drawn through) and matching pawn.

Roll the dice and move forward - ending on a marked space follow instructions. First, second and third player earn bonus.

Notes:
Likely published during 1910's
As usual - cute pewter pawns

name: Auf zur Fuchsjagd
description:
Objective - as a dog: block and catch the fox;
as fox: survive (for at least 10 min.) or escape
- moving by turns -

Three dogs try to catch a fox in a labyrinth; fox is placed into the centre, dogs (are split into players) move in from 3 exits.
Fourth exit is blocked by the hunter. Fox may use a double step once.

Note:
Likely published 1950's

name: Protocol 34
description:
The game is a turn based strategy game with economical macro game phase which includes:
- Politics
- Trade
- Tech development
- Building

and Micro game phase with tactical squad based combat which includes:
- Different soldier classes with skills trees
- Custom vehicle & troops loadout
- Deep damage system for vehicles and troops
- Meaningful troops moral and mental statuses
- Weather conditions which influence on stats of vehicles and troops
- Variety of mission types (Vip protection, convoy raids, hostage rescue, search and destroy etc .)
- Permadeath of soldiers

So here is a few words about game setting it's about post world war three, not very distant future with alternative history. World isn't in ruins (it's not a full post apocalypse but pretty messed up) but in a very bad state. Some terytories are in better shape, a rich ones of course live in a good cities with clean air water and ecologically clean food, poor people aren't so lucky they have to deal with desease, poor salaries raiders etc. Political map changed dramaticly some contries disappeared a new one emerged. The name of the game has a relation to the actual document of WWII between Germany and USSR the original text in ussr was kept in the special folder under number 34. The realtion is spiritual of course, it can give the mood of the uncertanty there is peace for now but for how long and at the same time war is continuing but on the different fronts in trade in politics and in actual "undercarpet" secret combat by mercenary pmc.

A few words about gameplay:

Players control a group of mercenaries,who is trying to survive in the world.After choosing a spawn region players start roam the world map in turn base manner, trading, finding themselves in different random events,building their base and of course taking missions . Countries autonomously act with each other,influencing the market and political situation(some political events can create a job oportunity with bigger challenge and at the same time with bigger profits and reputation points). As for missions-There are many types of them they are played on a smaller maps with terrain also in the turn based manner(One of the things that we want to make is a very tactical game play where diceroll isn't a decisive thing but human skill is). All in all the game has more of rouge like feel than a classical wargame with particular objectives. The process is the main fun part,but global goals also here(Player can get a citizenship of particular country and lead it to world domination,take hold of the entire PMC market and be the one who pull the strings,also there are some endings that are closely lore related).Also battle system can be used just for skirmishes.
categories: Economic, Industry / Manufacturing, Miniatures, Modern Warfare, Print & Play, Science Fiction, Wargame
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Area Movement, Dice Rolling, Modular Board, Role Playing, Secret Unit Deployment, Simulation, Team-Based Game, Trading

name: Helfer im Verkehr! Spiel mit Skala-Mobil
description:
The goal of the game is to drive 2 cars from the starting space to the parking lot in the center of the game board, while minding the traffic rules. The speed of the cars is determined by a toy car, the skala-mobil, instead of a die. By driving the skala-mobil while pushing a lever on the left side, a scale in the roof of the car is rotated and then stopped by releasing the lever.

This game has most likely been pubished in 1936 or 1937.
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: 4-Corners
description:
WIN THE JEWELS, WIN THE GAME!

Battle with wizards, monsters, goblins and and everything in between on your way to the four corners. Travel thru fields, rivers & dark forests to collect the 4 jewels before your opponents beat you to it!

name: Take Me Out
description:
FROM THE BOX:

Play your own version of Take Me out, ITV's hit dating game show!

Prove your single man is the perfect match by performing a series of fun tasks to win Fernandos vouchers.

Will the single girls guess "what you do" from your drawing? How will they react to your spare time activity and little known secret? Will you use the power wisely?

Remember, if they're turned off,
they'll turn off,

A game for everyone where, as Paddy says;
"NO LIKEY, NO LIGHTY!!

CONTENTS:
Electronic Take Me Out Light
and Buzzer Unit and "Paddyism"
generator
100 Single Men Cards
50 The Power Is In Your
Hands Cards
1 Single Girl Pad
12 Isle of Fernandos vouchers
Coloured Die
Rules

name: Redcap Manor
description:
For almost three hundred years no Coldrum set foot in Mossdown, a largely self-imposed exile recently ended by my acquisition of the ruins of our ancestral home. With the restoration of Coldrum Manor ongoing, there has never been a better time to document its history, and it seems apt that it should be a Coldrum to relate the tale.

Coldrum Manor, more commonly known as the derisory “Redcap Manor”, was built atop Mossdown Hill, a site long associated with spirits and faeries. Legend speaks of a series of standing stones that once stood near the hill, and Roman records of the area describe pagan rites involving human sacrifice. The strategic location of Mossdown Hill has long been recognised, and several strongholds have been constructed at this site over the last one thousand years.

'Redcap Manor' draws from the most traditional tales of haunting in the British Isles, in which it was faeries, not ghosts, that kept people awake at night. In 'Redcap Manor', each player represents one of four Edwardian investigators sent to the titular mansion, to gather as much evidence for the uncanny as they can over three nights. To this end, the protagonists will use the recently-harnessed power of electromagnetism against the Fae.

'Redcap Manor' is an auction/bluffing card game, divided into three turns representing the three nights of terror. Each turn, the players select a number of Haunt cards from their hand, to be secretly shuffled into the Haunt deck for the next night. Haunt cards are divided into three types: Fae, Presence, and Influence cards, each of which is countered by a different Ward card. Each player then places one of their three Ward cards face-down, and takes it in turns to uncover the top-most Haunt card. Eight cards are revealed per turn, representing eight hours before the dawn. After revealing a Haunt card, a player may choose to flee the Manor, but may not re-enter that night. The Haunt card remains face-up, and may be taken by subsequent players, together with any newly revealed cards. Alternatively, the player may take the Haunt card(s) - any Haunt cards countered by their Ward are taken as evidence (victory points); however, if the top-most card is not countered by their Ward, it is taken as a curse. Each Haunt card (24 unique cards, one for each hour of each night) has its own effect, influencing how the game is played. The player must determine whether taking a curse is worth the opportunity to acquire more evidence.

At the end of the third night, the player with the most evidence points is the victor.

name: Super 8
description:
Small Town, 1970’s, kids with Super 8 cameras, enough said!

Your goal is to film and assemble the highest scoring Super 8 movie in 1 day.

Super 8 is a medium weight, heavily thematic euro style game, for 2-5 players that plays in approx. 60 minutes.

It centers around card drafting (cast and crew), set collection (filming and assembling the best scenes possible), and worker placement (moving characters around town).
mechanics: Open Drafting, Set Collection, Worker Placement

name: Ninth Inning
description:
2 player quick card game.

Each game consists of players taking on the role of being the hitters vs the pitcher, in the 9th inning of a tied ball game. After three outs, players reverse roles and play the bottom of the ninth inning. Can you outscore your opponent?

Each at bat the pitcher tries to deceive the hitter to swing in the wrong area. However, the longer the at bat goes, the advantage swings into the hitters advantage. The longer the inning goes, so too will the hitting team get to know more what the pitcher is throwing.

name: Most Wanted
description:
Master burglars gather around a set of blueprints to plan an epic heist. As play escalates through the night, it’s a race to reach a specific dollar value, or survive with the most money.

This grid based strategy game for 2-4 players is all about movement and bartering. Walls, doorways and windows of structures all affect line of sight and movement, with security guards roaming everywhere trying to thwart your progress.

Mix this with a heavy dose of bartering, as co-operation with other players may be the only way to steal certain objects, and your are left with lots of satisfying take that moments.

name: Dog Refuge
description:
Take the role of a dog shelter in searching the perfect dog for each adoption situation. Every round, a new "Adoption Card" is drawn on the table.
Players must read what kind of dog the adopter is searching for, then try to find one dog that would best match the adoption,
looking at each dog’s statistics and needs: Space - Energy - Training - Grooming - Origin - Physical traits - Temperament.

The winner of the game is the first to empty his shelter (hands), finding a home for all dogs!

Dog Refuge is a mini-game that is easy to learn and play, mostly educational from learning about the different breeds of dog, and in which lifestyle each dog would fit best and be happier.

Deduction game : Each round, an "Adoption card" is drawn on the table. Players read what kind of dog the character is searching for.
Players have dogs cards in hand, and must try to match the ideal dog to each characters using statistics and information.
The winner of a round discards the dog, and the winner of the game is the one with no dogs left in hand.

name: Paladin Poker
description:
Nine Paladins have gathered for a fighting tournament and your entertainment. The Emperor wishes to use this tournament to find his next Great War General: you! As a War General candidate, you must consistently bet on the Victor Paladin of each fight to prove your strategic ability.

The Emperor has given each War General candidate one crossed-out picture of a Paladin that will NOT be victorious. Use your deduction and reasoning skills to find out which Paladin will be the Victor Paladin by closely following your opponent’s moves. At the end of each fight, Victory Points are awarded to bettors who have placed bets on the Victor Paladin.

name: War Elephant Racing
description:
What do you get when you mix Chaos, Cribbage, and Carnage?

War Elephant Racing (W.E.R.) is a fast paced game of chance and skill. War elephants will be bumping and crashing into each other on a tight course sending the others into a spin that will cost them crucial game points. Players must carefully balance a number of objectives, be quick with reactions, and recognize all of the scoring combinations to be able to beat their opponent. It is a game where experience counts for a great deal although a little bit of luck always helps. New and young players will be able to jump in fairly quickly and give the vets a run for their money.

War Elephant Racing uses Xhaos cards to spice up the race and increase the competitive action. Xhaos cards are special cards that call upon a special ability of an elephant of renown to give the players huge advantages to use against their competition. Special timing will provide the players with an edge over the other war elephant racers.

War Elephant Racing is played closely to Cribbage, each player is dealt war elephant racing cards and then must take turns laying one card at a time from their hand to attempt to get pairs, runs, and target numbers to score points. Each point allows the player to move their elephant an equal amount of points. Once each player has played all of the cards from their hand they then take turns adding up the different combinations of "points" in their hand to move their elephants. Players move around the tight track for six laps.

While players are moving their elephants if they land in a space that has another elephant they "bump" them. When a bump occurs the bump dice are rolled allowing the elephant to pass through, or send the bumped elephant in a spin, or send themselves in a spin costing valuable points.

War Elephant Racing also has "Xhaos" cards which allow them to make ranged attacks, powerful bumps, throw spectators in the path, and more. The xhaos cards are a great fun edge that each player will have to help them win the race. Almost all of the xhaos cards are named after famous elephants in history, and their effect in the game is related to their fame.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hand Management, Push Your Luck, Trick-taking
publishers: The Game Crafter, LLC, Xhaos Theory Games

name: Are you joking?
description:
"Are you joking?" is an educational game for English learners. It consists of two type of cards.
