One type has tongue twisters, jokes, quotes and such; the other type contains words (in English and German). One player reads one card of the first type, then counts from 10 to 0. The other players check whether they hold word cards with words that are included in the text. If so, they can discard them in front of themselves and draw new cards. Players who manage not to laugh during the countdown get an extra card; if everyone laughs, the reader gets it.
After a certain number of rounds, the player with most points on his/her cards is the winner.
There are some advanced rules included, for example demanding a certain reading style.

name: Cards of Candor
description:
An adult card game that will have you laughing all night. You will be amazed about what you will find out about your friends.

It's a simple and fun adult card game that is different every time you play, as different groups will respond in different ways. You will find out more about your friends or new people at a party. You will be amazed and surprised about the answers you get to intimate, probing questions. We are sure you will be surprised about what you learn about your friends.

In its simplistic form, a dealer reads a question from the deck and you anonymously answer 'Yes' or 'No'. The dealer tries to guess how many answered 'Yes' or 'No', and if they guess correctly, they keep the question card. If not the dealer decides which stories they want to hear why people answered 'Yes' or 'No'. If the dealer wants to hear the 'Yes' stories and you as a player answered yes, you can choose to tell the story to win the card, or keep quiet and remain anonymous. If there are more than one 'Yes' cards, then multiple people can tell their stories and the dealer decides which story wins. At the end of the game, the player who has gathered the most cards wins the game.

The great thing about this game is that you have the freedom to choose to remain anonymous or to share the stories behind your answer - so you decide on what to divulge to the group you’re playing with, it allows you to freely express something in public without the repercussions.

The game provides the environment to share stories and situations and engage in conversations that you would not normally engage in. You will be amazed what you find out about your friends. Is an adult game(18+), so as you can imagine there are some pretty risque questions.

Here are a couple of 'tame' sample questions in the deck:

Have you ever had a DUI?
Have you ever been arrested?
Have you ever lied on a tax return?
categories: Card Game, Mature / Adult, Party Game

name: Buntes Allerlei
description:
"Buntes Allerlei" - translated it means something like "colourful sundries" or "colourful assortment" is a learning game by Clementino in their "Sapientino - the small bright guy" series. It consists of a bag, a sand timer, a colour die and 4 cards with seven different figures/shapes, which also differ between the player cards. The shapes fit into holes in the cards and have different shapes and colours, e.g. the helicopter, the woman, the man, the moon...
Its a collection of games die rolling, grabbing the shape blind from the bag etc.

The objective of the game is to be the first player having a completed board - by having rolled all colours and thus having gotten all missing objects containing these colours, or by grabbing the right items blind from the bag.

name: Wer will verreisen?
description:
The Players travel from a predetermined starting point to a predetermined destination city. The players get to choose their own route. When they get to city with a red number, the players get a game marker. Most of the rules are left open to agreement by the players before the start of the game. To win the game, the player either has to be the first to reach the Destination, or get the most game markers. Which goal is used has to be agreed upon before the game starts.

The game was published in the 1930s/1940s, so the game board shows the German borders of this time. The goal was to teach children the geography and borders of the 3rd Reich.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: The Zone
description:
You are the commander of a small squad of tanks. Your tank, marked by a unique color, carries a special payload that must be fired from "The Zone" to disable the enemies communications base. Reach The Zone with your commander, and you win. Capture the enemy commander, and you win.

So how do you do it? To reach The Zone, you must navigate the terrain and capture or circumvent enemy tanks. To capture a tank, move your tank into the space it occupies.

Each space on the board features one of four types of terrain, either dirt, grass, hill, or mud. Each space gives you a different combination of attack and movement range when you move from that space. You can get stuck in the mud with a movement of zero, or blast down a hill with a movement of 2! Your attack range is consistently 1, except for when you have the high vantage point of the hill space.

This has the feel of a classic strategy game like Othello or Stratego. It's very simple to learn but hard to master. Understanding the terrain and effectively positioning your forces will be the key to your success. Pretty simple, right? Then get moving, Commander!
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Grid Movement, Player Elimination

name: Pirate Masters
description:
Ahoy me Hearties, now listen up, them pesky landlubbers have taken me treasure and i need you to help me get me loot back. You'll have to get some things together in order to get me treasure back: a first mate, a bunch of scoundrels for a crew, a ship, all the parts of a treasure map, and, of course, the jewels and gold coins that make up me treasure. Good luck!! But remember, beware The Kraken.

The object is to be the first player to collect 1 full set of Captain cards, 1 full set of Treasure map cards, 1 full set of Jewel Cards (which is 1 of each type of jewel, there are 6 different types of jewels in total), and the value of at least 30 gold coins in your Treasure Chest, all the while using action cards to build up your sets and thwart your opponents.

On a player's turn they take two cards and play up to three cards.

name: BabeQuest: Fastaval Special Edition
description:
A 7 card promo expansion for BabeQuest, given out for free at Fastaval in 2003.

The expansion consist of 7 cards:
Hunting Ground: Banketten (The Banquet)
H: Eliten (The Elite)
Countermove: Fupintelektuel diskussion (Phony intellectual discussion)
Babe: Ottoline
Move: Scoresætning (Pick-up Line)
H/U: Fastaval TV
Move: Elite-namedropping

Apart from adding more variety, these cards do not change the way the game is played.
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Humor, Mature / Adult

name: Das Kreuzworträtselspiel
description: This is a crossword puzzle. There are 50 white tiles (consonants) and 30 red tiles (vowels). Each set has a joker (star). The players start with a certain number of tiles and have to add words to the crossword. If a player can't do that, he has to draw a new tile. The first player to use up all his tiles, wins the game.

name: Nostromo
description:
Nostromo is a game of search and escape on a dynamic board that resembles a spaceship.

Players must escape from the ship, but before they must getting the items needed for this, preventing xenomorfos. One player, whose identity is hidden from the rest, has a mission to thwart the escape of their peers. Throughout the entire game no player is eliminated, but change its goals according to their role

The board consists of 30 circular sectors. Players move around the board according to the result of a dice roll . The primary mission of the players is to get the items needed for to escape and bring them to the escape ship (one of the sectors). These objects are hidden in 7 different rooms (each room is also a sector). Players must arrive these rooms through corridors (which are also sectors).

During the game, each player can move between sectors and even rotate them to get into them.

During setup, a number of threats (dice) equal to the number of players are placed on the board. These threats are eliminated by the players when the reach their position. If a threat reaches a value of six, it becomes a xenomorf.

At the end of each work shift and before the start of the next, each threat is increased, an event card is read and moves the xenomorfs towards the nearest player.

When a player succeeds in bringing the third neccassary item to the escape ship, the player in the escape ship with the most points is winner.
mechanics: Area Movement, Cooperative Game, Modular Board

name: Jackpot Travel Game
description: This game is based on a gaming show aired in South Africa on TV1 in the late 80's. The idea of the game has is to be the first to 1 million Rand (the currency of South Africa). This is done by moving round the board, drawing cards and sometimes having to answer questions related to different countries. The card also has an amount on it in the thousands which is then converted to Rands using the exchange rate of the land you just moved onto. There is also then a multiplier done based on the colour of the square you landed on. There are also Action and Bonus squares giving you a 2 & 3 times bounces. You keep doing this and the first person to 1 million Rand wins.

name: Family Golf
description:
Family Golf is a board game for up to 4 players. The board is an overview of an 18 hole golf course. Each hole has a different yardage. Along the way, sand traps and water hazards pose problems.

Roll dice to determine yardage of each stroke, and use single die (numbered 1-3) to determine how many putts on green to sink putt.
Total score for each hole then place score on scoresheet (provided). Scoresheet has all 18 holes listed, when all 18 holes completed, tally score, low score wins.

Stroke counters and ball marker provided. Ball marker is used showing where golfball is located on course, and moved in accordance with yardage determined by each roll of dice (or stroke).

name: Kismet
description:
Kismet is a gambling game. The object of the game is guess which poker hands will be shown on the next throw of the dice. The players contribute to form a bank, then make bets at the odds specified on the board.

The dice are made of wood, the one and six are marked in red, there are special markings on the 1, 3, and 6. The game uses five dice to create poker hands, but it is otherwise unrelated to the well known game Kismet which Spare-Time published in 1963.

Not to be confused with:
Kismet (1963, Spare-Time)
Kismet (1997, Abacus)

name: Right Connections
description:
Right Connections was one of Springbok's line of "Adult Puzzle-Games." Like some of the others it can be played as a solitaire puzzle or a two-player game.

The pieces are nine plastic disks which each have eight lines radiating from the center, two each in four colors, with the arrangement different on each disk. These are placed on a board with recesses for the disks and lines connecting various spots on the recess edges.

As a puzzle, the object is to connect all the lines of any given color, starting with a random arrangement of disks.

As a game, players take turns starting with a designated disk and line (the lines are designed by black dots on the disks) and turning other disks one by one to make as long a line of the given color as possible. Making a loop scores triple. The player getting to 100 points first wins.

name: TouchMoney Game
description: TouchMoney Game is an educational game designed to teach young children how to count coins. It is a roll-and-move game where students land on spaces that challenge them to count coins correctly, either from pictures on a card or from coins randomly drawn from a tray of plastic coins on the board. Players get five points each time they count correctly. Play ends when a player reaches a certain predetermined number of points or players have circled the board a number of times. The winner is the player who has earned the most points.

name: Das Irrgartenspiel
description:
The goal of the game is to move 4 meeples from the center of the labyrinth the finish spaces at the outer rim. The first player to accomplish this wins the game.

The game is played with one die. The meeples may only move in the direction indicated by the arrows on the game board. If a meeple lands on a white dot, it follows the arrow outwards into the next roundcourse at its next turn. Whenever a meeple lands on an occupied space, it kicks the other meeple back to a starting (a) space of it's color. If a player rolls a 6 he gets an extra roll.

The game was most likely published in the 1930s or early 40s.
mechanics: Area Movement, Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Where Chickens Dare
description: Tired of doing everything for chicken feed, the brave chickens leave the coop in search of sweet corn. Along the way they encounter fury beasts like foxes, skunks, and dogs that must be defeated in order to reach their goal. Finding useful weapons like bowling pins and ski poles can help. The support crew lends aid as well. The fryer can heal them, the gizzard can magically find items, and the Kung Pow Chicken can train the poultry brigade into a stealthy fighting machine.

name: Wer reist mit nach Afrika? Ein Unterhaltungs und Belehrungsspiel
description: Players start in Germany. They follow routes through Africa, to numbered circles, and end back on Germany. The board is a map of Europe and Africa, with plants and trees along the bottom. Players roll and move to travel around the board, and then do what the field is saying.
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: MLTG: Maritopian Life The Game
description:
Maritopian Life brings you the first game of its kind; a collectible Trading Card Cannabis Game.

Be a grower. Build your grow room. Create obstacles for your opponents.
Protect your room from other growers. Be the first to score 420 points for the win. For Adults only.

Each deck must have at least 40 cards. Points are accumulated by harvesting plants after the number of turns on a strain card.
categories: Card Game, Collectible Components, Mature / Adult, Party Game

name: Yin-Yang
description:
Yin-Yang is a brief abstrat game for two players, each player takes both of the white and the black stones for playing. They take turns placing stones on the 5x5 game board, for the purpose of making a square by four stones in the same color.
In the game, each player belongs to Yin or Yang side. So does the square been made on the board. The player who’s Yin-Yang is the same as the square wins the game.

On which the Yin-Yang of a square depends:
White stone is Yang;
Black stone is Yin;
Odd number of lines of gribs the square covered is Yang;
Even number of lines of gribs the square covered is Yin;

Combining Yin-Yang of the stones with the size of the square just as multiplication rules of plus and minus, the result is the Yin-Yang of the square:
White stone x Odd number = Yang
White stone x Even number = Yin
Black stone x Odd number = Yin
Black stone x Even number =Yang

name: MazeScrolls
description:
MazeScrolls are a series of maze puzzles games in the form of scrolls. They are a new kind of game genre: the pen and paper maze puzzle dice games for multiple players.

There are 8 different MazeScroll designs and each one uses different graphics and offers different game-play. The eight MazeScrolls are the following:

- Galaxy Far, Faar, Faaar Away
- Perimeter Perplexity
- De Stijl Mile
- Daedalus Treasure
- Lovers Duel
- Daedalus Palace
- Crossing
- Skritches, Skretches and Skrutches

MazeScrolls are a game of meandering journey that can be played by a single player or multiple players. Players can race from one end to the opposite end or they can start at opposite ends and attempt to find each other. Players can also "duel" by first collecting power points so that when they meet-up the one with the most power wins.

Players play the MazeScroll games using a pen, pencil or colored pencils. When the game is done, the finished MazeScroll becomes a piece of artwork that is also a record of their play.

name: MYOB
description:
MYOB is a Rogue-like, Dungeon Crawler Card Game playable with a standard deck of cards and 5 six-sided Dice.

Single or Multiplayer, MYOB brings the RPG experience in a way that tributes Classic games like Solitaire and Yahtzee.

Players explore a dungeon by drawing cards and placing them on the field to build monsters, and defeating monsters by rolling dice against their Bounty to collect them and their Loot. Loot comprises of Weapon, Armour, and Magic cards. Weapon and Armour cards increase attack and defense, and Magic cards are used to negate combat damage. Defeat both BOSS monsters to win and collect the highest Bounty.
mechanics: Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Dice Rolling, Open Drafting, Role Playing

name: Bird Whiz
description: Bird Whiz is a card-run-making game, published in South Africa in the 1990s (likely 1993 or 1997). It uses colours or you can match them up by type of bird. Once you get a run you put it down, but to keep it in play, you have to answer a question related to the birds in the run. You could skip this part for younger players. With the questions, it makes it an educational game. It is easy to teach and learn. There are also joker cards counting as any card. You score points for the amount of runs you have down. You also score negative points for the cards in your hand once the game ends. The worst card to end up with in your hand is a joker, losing you 50 points. The winner is the one with the most points.

name: Leben in Kassel
description:
Published about the German City of Kassel.

By playing the players get to know a little bit about the city and its shops.

During each player's turn they roll a six-sided dice to move along a game-board depicting a map of Hannover. At certain spaces players can acquire cards of the shops or they can go sightseeing by following the instructions on the back of the card. Sometimes there is only information written, sometimes you have to pay an amount of money or at other times you may earn some cash.

The game ends when the last player reaches the finish space with his playing piece. The winner is the person who has acquired the most sightseeing and/or shop cards.

name: Reit-Turnier
description:
Objective:
finish the circuit with less penalties than others
1. build an obstacle course upon a table cloth
2. choose a coloured chip
3. during your turn you must flip a small chip through the circuit
earning penalties for each try (-1), for each damaged obstacle (-2),...

likely published mid. 1950's

name: Kennst Du Sie? ... die Daten der deutschen Geschichte
description:
Objective:
get as many bonus (bright) chips as possible; learn more about history of the German nation and become familiar with the ideology of Nazi Germany
- acting by turns -
Game master draws a card and ask a player answering the question;
correct? Get a bright chip - Wrong? Get a dark chip.
Game ends after each player has collected 10 chips. Winner is the one with most bright chips.
Note:
Questions are indoctrinated by Nazi ideology.

name: The Crossroads
description:
The Crossroads is a classic play of Chinese operas. Ren Tanghui was ordered to protect the banished general Jiao Zan in secret. He stayed overnight at Liu Lihua’s inn. Late at night, they confronted each other in a sudden darkness and dangerous hand-to-hand combat.

The Crossroads is a brief paper-and-pencil game for two players. In a room of 3x3 grids, players take actions concurrently each round and record them on sheets, then make an announcement required to settle their acts.

The basic acts include:

Move: Move to an adjacent grid.

Research: Get the last entry and left directions and round numbers in your position in 8 rounds from the opponent. You have to take a Move act next round.

Attack: Attack the opponent in your position, if he ends round here and doesn’t take an attack action, you win. You have to take a Move act next round.

Pursuit: Move and attack the opponent. You have to stay in the new grid without any actions next round.(3 uses only for each player)

For each Move round a player may also take a Challenge, declare his current position and earn points. In a series of consecutive challenges, it’s 1 point for the first challenge, 2 points for the second, 4 points for the third, 8 points for the fourth and later ones. After 20 rounds without a successful attack, the player has the most points win the game.

name: Dino-Land
description:
It's a game you can wear! Both tee-shirt and board game, where you try to get your dinosaur to the end before the other players.

(You must provide the die and player markers.)

name: Ronda
description:
Objective: Gain as much money as possible
- acting by turns -
Players determine a wager; active player throws 2 dice:
On a board - numbered from 3 - 11 (7 in the centre) you have to pay money if the appropiate space/number is empty - collect money - if not. If you throw a 7 you have to pay anyway.
Throwing a 2 you collect all the money without '7', a '12' let you take all.
note: published before WWII

name: Replicate
description:
After scanning many galaxies, many stars, and many planets, you have arrived and found the perfect host to take over humanity. However, you are not the only one. Your probe must compete against others to release virus and take over your host.

Players take on the role of an alien species, controlling a probe that moves around a human's body and releases virus. But, the virus must overcome the body's natural defenses as well as competing for dominance with the other viruses.

Probes arrive in any of the six origin spaces and begin to take over the host's body. As the body's defenses break down, taking over becomes easier until it is taken over completely. The virus that takes over enough body parts, wins the game.

Players must manage a hand of cards, a board position with its virion pieces, and a probe that requires actions to use. Cards synergize well with each other when used in the right configuration and can allow a player to maximize advantages. Also, cards have a different effect when used against the body and when used against other viruses.
mechanics: Action Points, Area Majority / Influence, Hand Management, Point to Point Movement

name: Ringwurfspiel "Treff sicher!"
description:
Simple indoor ring toss game
- acting by turns -

Players choose a colour and throw plastic rings, hoping to catch one fn the targets and score some points.

The one who scores the most points after a pre-determined time limit runs out, wins.

Note:
Published before WWII

name: Xhaos Theory: The Miniature Game
description:
Your Minions serve you without question. You are their Gawd. Their souls feed you in your quest toward the power to realize XHAOS THEORY. As you carefully wager their souls in bloody battles against other Gawds you risk losing those precious souls. A Gawd without worship ceases to exist.
Command and guide your minions carefully or all hope is lost.

Xhaos Theory is for those that have always asked “What if?” Young and old, experienced or not. Play with a massive miniature collection, or just a handful of models or toys.

Xhaos Theory allows you to create virtually any miniature unit you want, from any time frame, and fantasy or Sci-Fi book you have ever read and take that force up against another player that has created their own force. That force could be a one miniature force of a giant city eating lizard, or a squad of super heroes, or perhaps a legion of undead! Scenarios, settings, number of models? That's all up to you!

Xhaos Theory is a scalable miniature wargame allowing players total control over size and setting. You can play a full out large scale battle, or a small skirmish with Xhaos Theory. Many battles have been fought with 7 miniatures on one side, and 20+ on the other.

Xhaos Theory is a turn based miniature war game simplified for younger gamers also for quick play. Complete customization of your own army and campaign system to advance your army.
categories: Adventure, Children's Game, Dice, Fantasy, Miniatures, Wargame
mechanics: Action Queue, Area Movement, Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Player Elimination, Role Playing, Simulation, Storytelling, Team-Based Game

name: Der Weg zum Igelhaus
description:
Objective:
be the first reaching space 90 - simple 'Roll&Move'-game.
Each player moves forward according die roll; ending on a marked/larger space follow instructions.

note:
cute drawings on a 23" x 15.3" map,
likely published 1950's

name: 7 Card Stud
description:
This is a Poker variant with a novel twist. Each player gets two cards and then tries to 'shoot' a ball into the spinner (rather like a Roulette wheel). You have four balls to shoot but you can stop if you think you have a card that improves your hand. Of course, there is a lot of scope for bluffing.

Game contains:
Board
Spinner
Playing Cards
Poker Chips
16 Plastic balls in four colours
Rules

name: Knuckle Busters
description:
Action boxing game similar to Rock 'Em Sock 'Em Robots. Each player controls a boxer. The boxers face each other and start throwing punches. A clean punch to the nose will knock down that boxer. Play as long as you like, the one with the most knock-downs is the winner.

Included is a 45 rpm record of ring-side sound effects, which you can play in the background to build up the atmosphere.

name: Fireball Forward: Britain's Lost Opportunity – Villers Bocage
description: Villers-Bocage, Britain's Lost Opportunity is a book of tactical scenarios for the Fireball Forward! game system. It is centered around the British attack on the town of Villers-Bocage and the larger Operation Perch against German positions west of Caen, in Normandy, on 12-14 June 1944. It features engagements between the British 7th Armoured Division-the famed 'Desert Rats' - and the 50th Infantry Division against the elite German Panzer Lehr Division, the 2nd Panzer Division, and the 101 st 55 Heavy Panzer Battalion. 15 Scenarios cover the desperate struggle for the town of Villers-Bocage, 50th Infantry Division's attempt to drive Panzer Lehr out of its positions west of Caen, and panzer ace Michael Wittmann's daring, single-handed counterattack against a column of British armor that changed the course of the battle. A Campaign Game, an Historical Summary, Orders of Battle, and Designer's Notes are included to help put the scenarios in the larger context of operations in Normandy and allow players to design their own scenarios.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II

name: Sunda
description:
The goal of the game ist to get points by enclosing opponent playing pieces. The players can set their pieces (with their faces down) on any free space on the game board. When all pieces are set, the players beginn to move their pieces one space per turn. If a piece is enclosed, so that it can't move, its face is revealed. It's eliminated from the game and the encloser gets the indicated number of points, but only if a black inscripted piece is caught on a space with a black center or a white inscripted one on a space with a white center. If this is not the case, the enclosed piece is put on any other free space of it's players choice. When a 6-eyed piece is eliminated, it's player too is eliminated from the game.

This game was published in the 1930s or 1940s.

name: Am Knobelbrett
description: The players set their playing pieces face down on the spaces of their color on the game board. Only the spaces with the number 10 are left free. When all pieces are set, the faces are revealed. Now the players have to move their pieces to get them on the spaces of the same number. Spaces of other colors can't be moved on. Neutral spaces can be used to block the opponents. The first player to get all his pieces on the right spaces wins the game.

name: Das lustige Affenspiel
description:
Objective: be the first reaching space 70 (catching Tom, an orang-outan)
- smple 'Roll&Move' game -
acting by turns
Tom (an orang-outan, kept as prisoner/domestic animal in a palace) has escaped. Rolling two dice (with special symbols) 5 pawns (players) have to catch the break-away; depending on dice combinations pawns/orang outan have to be moved; ending on marked spaces follow instructions.

notes:
likely published before WWI;
cute pewter pawns, funky story behind

name: Jungs
description:
Objective: Collect as many bonus points as possible by crossing a 11 x 11 board (+ start/target positions) like Halma by
1. capturing other meeples 2. fast finishing
- acting by turns -

Players (2 or 4) move their meeples (vertical/horizontal/diagonal) out of starting position upon a 11 x 11 grid board. The board is divided into 4 areas, pictured with Skat-cards; starting from such a place you may move or jump trying to come closer to your finish positions; if you jump over opponent's meeple(s) you will capture them - but this isn't allowed if your starting position has a lower or equal value (according Skat). You may jump in all directions ('chain-jump') starting from a Jack-(=Jungs)space. Transition spaces between the 4 areas have additional restrictions/advantages. The earlier you finish the higher the bonus points. Game ends after last player reaches target positions.

Note:
Likely published during 1930's

name: Marquette-opoly
description:
Own it all as a high-flying trader in the fast-paced world of real estate. Tour the city for the hottest properties: sites, stations and utilities are all up for grabs. Invest in houses and hotels, then watch the rent come pouring in. Make deals with other players and look out for bargains at auction—there are many ways to get what you want. And for really speedy dealers, use the speed die for a quick and intense game of Marquette-opoly. So get on Go and trade your way to success.

Players move around the gameboard buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels, and collecting rent from their opponents, the ultimate goal being to drive them into bankruptcy. The winner is the remaining player left after all the others have gone bankrupt.
mechanics: Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: "GOAL"
description:
Objective: score most goals (450 points or more) during a 2 x 6 matches lasting game
- acting by turns -
2 or 4 players (in this case you need two sets/games with 4 different colours) are dealt 5 cards each (from their own 32 cards deck); trying to score most points in a trick-taking procedure you earn bonus points regarding the values of the cards (within their won tricks); special card combinations (center-forward & goal & Joker) give additional points. After each trick you must refill your hand.

notes: likely published mid/end 1930's due to Joker card 'Sindelar': Team captain of the Austrian Wunderteam - died Jan. 1939 under mysterious circumstances

name: Collectors Battlefield Wargaming System: D-Day – Battle of Carentan
description:
This is the first module of the Collector's Battlefield Wargaming System, a 'turn key' quick play set of rules with a full line of 28mm prepainted figures and vehicle.

CB: Carentan is a skirmish level miniatures wargame- that is, it represents combat at its most basic level of fighting: man to man.

CB:Carentan puts the player in the role of an infantry squad or platoon leader. Firefights break out in 'mad minutes', followed by lulls where the player exercises leadership by rallying troops, bringing in reserves, and maneuvering his troops to set up for the next firefight. Firefights center on the machine gun- placement of your MG42's and .30cals are crucial to glorious success or ignominious defeat!

Scale:
1 figure = 1 soldier or vehicle
1 inch = 2 yards
1 turn = approximately 30 seconds
Combat Lull = 2 to 10 minutes.

Keeping track of units stats is made easy with quick reference cards included with every pack, detailing the capabilities of every squad, leader, heavy weapon and vehicle. Squad level games are fast and furious, taking about 60 minutes to an hour and half.

name: Blumenzüchter
description:
Card game in which each player is a gardener who tries to get the best variety of flowers to grow in his garden.

There are flower cards and accessory cards, such as seeds, sunshine, water etc. Different kinds of flowers need different combinations of accessories and yield different point values.

The active player can draw cards, trade cards with open cards on the table, plant flowers and trade with the other players. The first player to plant ten points worth of flowers is the winner.

name: Turnier der Magier
description:
The forces of light and dark are running a tournament, with the winner ruling the earth for the next 100 years.

The game consists of cards showing magicians, spells, items and missions. Each player has a magician card with a special ability, and a mission card with another special activity. The active player can play cards with spells or items and use the abilities of his/her magician/mission cards. Other players can interfere with counterspells or special items. The goal is to gain three tokens, either individually (in a 2 or 3 player game) or as a team (in a 4 player game). The first player or team who gets the 3 tokens is the winner.

name: Aztec Conquest
description:
The game is played on a board 10 squares by 9. Each player has 9 pieces which being placed side by side in two lines along one diagonal. The objective is to be the first player to move their 9 pieces into a 3 by 3 square in their corner of the game board.

From the game box: Slide carefully along the ground to the sacred Aztec temple ... Keep and eye on your enemy, overcome obstacles, and make sure all the members of your tribe reach the safety of the temple.

1. Assemble the Aztec warriors in diagonal formation along the center of the board according to tribal colors.
2. Slide a warrior along a row or column until he encounters a boundary or another warrior.
3. Plan the best route, slide the warriors forward and help them enter the sacred temple.
4. Be the first player to slide his/her entire tribe of nine Aztec warriors into the temple ... and WIN!

Similar to Outwit, which introduces power chips that can move diagonally, and can stop whenever they want (but must still stop for the required reasons). Outwit also has a rule about not leaving your corner once you enter it.
publishers: (Unknown), Miro Company, Orda Industries Ltd., Parker Spiele, W. Nostheide Verlag GmbH

name: Rola In The Magic Forest
description:
YOU are an apprentice witch. You can procure magic from a variety of forest resources. You can create magic called "mug", and use it to carry out the extraction of "Mana" - the energy of nature. Who can hold the most excellent performance?! Please be careful so as not to get in the way of resource procurement earnestly. It is a card game that anyone can play easily!

- From the Magic Forest and Black Cat Rola

This card game uses trick taking mechanics. The suit color of the card winning each trick becomes the trump suit of the next trick. Cards earned become magical resources and can be combined to score bonus points.

name: Squarit
description:
Squarit is a played on a board containing 16 squares each surrounded by four spaces for tiles, with each pair of adjacent squares sharing one tile space. Each tile space has a specific tile that can be placed on it. The squares are numbered from 4-64 by fours. The edges of the board are also numbered, from 1-4.

The game can be played in two ways. In the aptly-named "Game of Chance" two to five players take turns drawing a tile and placing it on its designated space. The player placing the fourth tile around a square scores the value of the square multiplied by the value of the edge of the board corresponding to the played tile.

The "Game of Skill" is for two players. The scoring rule is the same, but here each player starts with half the blocks and can choose which one to play, generally speaking. If three sides of a block have been played this forces the fourth side to be played as soon as possible, and if that is the third tile for another square it forces that fourth tile immediately, etc.

The designer patented the game some years before publishing it.

Note that the board shown in the patent is not exactly the same as the published version, as the rules state the squares in each quarter of the board sum to 136.

name: Game of Defense: Pacific
description:
Game of Defense: Pacific is a light wargame. It is for two sides (U.S. and "Asiatic"), each of whom has five ships each of three types (battleships, cruisers, and submarines). The ships are deployed on a map of the Pacific with a grid divided into red and white squares.

On a turn a player moves one piece (or possibly more than one, as the rules are a bit unclear). Battleships and cruisers can move several squares on a turn but are restricted to squares of a particular color. Submarines only move one square a turn but can use either color. Submarines capture enemy ships by landing on them, but the larger ships capture by jumping.

Each side starts the game by mining ten squares on their shores; when an enemy ship crosses such a square a card is drawn which may have a bad effect.

Each side has four objective cards which they randomly select one of at the start of the game, keeping it hidden from the opponent(s). The game is won by the side achieving its objective first.

The game can be played by more than two players by dividing one or both sides between players.
categories: Abstract Strategy, Nautical, Wargame, World War II

name: SeaDogs
description:
SeaDogs is a fast paced family game for 2-6 players, ages 10 and up. Players take on the rolls of Pirate captains taking part in a competition to gather the most Gold and Treasure. The Captain with the most Gold after all is said and done is the victor.

Sail into a port, and get gold by selling any cargo you have earned from your acts of piracy. Pillage ports to gain cargo, but once a pirate pillages a port they must move to another Port to take any more actions.

There is no honor among Pirates, and it's every Captain for themselves on the high seas. Players may attack each other and steal Cargo, Gold, or even Treasure that has been found on mysterious islands in the area. Pirates who take plunder from other players get a Bounty on their heads that goes to the next Pirate to take them down a peg or two.

Sea Dogs has a whimsical style. The world it takes place in is populated by animals. The base game focuses on dogs, but who knows what other animals are out there.

SeaDogs is a quick playing game that is fun for kids and adults. And it is designed to be kid friendly so everyone has a chance of winning, while still having enough depth that adults can play together and enjoy it as well.
mechanics: Chit-Pull System, Dice Rolling, Modular Board, Pick-up and Deliver

name: Das Baden-Baden Spiel
description:
Commercial game, related to Monopoly, for the purpose of promoting the city of "Baden-Baden", in the Southwest of Germany.

The players move around a board, which consists of 40 squares. On most of the squares are parts of companies, which can be bought. The companies have values between 1000 and 8000. Three companies are combined by a color. Whenever a player lands on a win&loss-square, he must draw a card and the wins and losses of the business year are settled. According to the outcome the players gain money or have to pay money for their companies.
As soon as one player goes bankrupt, the game ends, all company cards are sold for their original price. Player with most money is the winner.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Open Drafting, Player Elimination, Set Collection, Stock Holding, Trading

name: Das Münster-Spiel
description:
Commercial game, related to Monopoly, for the purpose of promoting the city of "Münster", in the West of Germany.

The players move around a board, which consists of 40 squares. On most of the squares are parts of companies, which can be bought. The companies have values between 1000 and 8000. Three companies are combined by a color. Whenever a player lands on a win&loss-square, he must draw a card and the wins and losses of the business year are settled. According to the outcome the players gain money or have to pay money for their companies.
As soon as one player goes bankrupt, the game ends, all company cards are sold for their original price. Player with most money is the winner.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Open Drafting, Player Elimination, Set Collection, Stock Holding, Trading

description:

mechanics: Dice Rolling, Open Drafting, Player Elimination, Set Collection, Stock Holding, Trading
