name: Das Nürnberg-Spiel
description:
Commercial game, related to Monopoly, for the purpose of promoting the city of "Nuremberg", in the South of Germany.

The players move around a board, which consists of 40 squares. On most of the squares are parts of companies, which can be bought. The companies have values between 1000 and 8000. Three companies are combined by a color. Whenever a player lands on a win&loss-square, he must draw a card and the wins and losses of the business year are settled. According to the outcome the players gain money or have to pay money for their companies.
As soon as one player goes bankrupt, the game ends, all company cards are sold for their original price. Player with most money is the winner.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Open Drafting, Player Elimination, Set Collection, Stock Holding, Trading

name: Amor und die Herzen
description:
The goal of the game is to shoot the heart of the opponent with Amor's arrow. The game pieces are the heart, Amor, the devil, 3 male guardian hearts, 7 female guardian hearts and 2 impetuous hearts. They are used to protect the player's heart and impede the opponent's Amor. To do this, the pieces can move in specific ways (like in Chess) and can block or eliminate one another. The devil is the only piece, that can eliminate Amor. When Amor gets in a straight line with another's heart, he can shoot it and wins the game. The game can be played by 2 or 4 players. In the game for 4 players, the players at the opposite sides of the game board play against one another.

The Game was most likely published in the 1920s.

name: Weine nicht! Scherz-Roulette
description:
A thrilling race between a skilled motorist, a jealous pedestrian and a beautiful girl: Each player has 3 meeples: a car, a girl and a man. The goal is to get all 3 meeples around the game board and back into their own garage. The opposite players move in opposite directions. The moves of the meeples are determined by a spinner. Whenever the different kinds of meeples meet, different things happen. The girl enters every car it meets and may change cars if the oportunity arrives. The man gets every girl to leave the car. If a car with a girl of another color enters its garage, the girl has to begin anew. The spinner can send the car or the girl back to its starting point too, if it shows "Weine nicht" (= don't cry).

This game was published in the 1920s or 1930s.
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Race, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Phileas Fogg & Co
description:
In Phileas Fogg & Co up to four players bet on Fogg's attempt to travel around the world in 80 days. All players determine the speed of the journey by plaing cards. You win, if Fogg and his companions move according to your role. The own role is kept secret and can be changed. There are four different roles: Phileas Fogg wants to arrive exactly in time, Passepartout wants to arrive as soon as possible, detective Fix wants to arrive as late as possible, Jules Vernes is interested in an exciting race.

The game is part of a scientific publication about Jules Verne's Around the World in 80 Days. The box contains the game and a book with 80 essays on Verne's novel. The name of the whole box is: Weltnetzwerke – Weltspiele. Ein Buch und ein Spiel zu Jules Vernes 'In 80 Tagen um die Welt, edited by Passepartout, Konstanz 2013.

name: Salmon Migration Game
description:
Players use dice to navigate around the board to the finish line. Along the way, Fact Cards or questions regarding the Salmon Life Cycle educate the players.

Targeted for children in Grades K-5, this game takes players through the salmon life cycle, from egg-laying to spawning. A fun way to learn salmon biology, including the dangers they face from natural predators, food supply, weather, and human influence.

name: Eene Meene
description:
The title is more recognisable to English speakers as
"Eeny Meeny Miney Moe
Catch a ****** by his toe
If he wriggles, let him go
Eeny Meeny Miney Moe"

Card game. 32 cards in four sets of eight. Each set is in the same colour and is numbered from one to eight.

Four cards are dealt to each player and 4 are turned up in the middle of the table. The rest are placed in a stack to the side. Each turn a player may exchange one card from his hand with one from the middle. Or, he can take all four cards with his hand. After everyone has had a turn and nobody has exchanged a card, the four in the middle are replaced by four new cards.

The object is to collect together 4 cards of the same colour or four cards of any colours that have four numbers in consecutive order.

If you achieve either of the two objectives, you lay down your hand. All the other players now reveal their hands. For each card not in any order, they score one to three points. In effect, this means that they will score one to three points. After nine rounds of play, the player with the highest score, loses.
categories: Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Hippo Hunt Game
description:
From the package:

Spill the critters
take your pick
find the hippo
Do it QUICK!

The game pieces are 24 plastic animals packaged in a plastic tube.

There are 2 ways to play the game.

- Dump all the animals onto a table. The first player to find the hippo wins.

- Put all the animals in a bag. The first player to find the hippo wins.

Another animal may be picked to vary the game.

name: Contactics
description:
Contactics is a business card with a set of rules which allow you to play an area control boardgame in which the components are other business cards.

Each player's stack of business cards is shuffled into a deck, and a hand of 6 is drawn. The list on the back of Contactics uses a sequence of four questions to define which effects your card has. Each turn a player plays a card, and its effect takes place.
The game ends when the board (3x3 grid) is full, and the player who conquered the most grid spaces wins.

It's meant to aid in networking.
categories: Abstract Strategy, Card Game, Collectible Components
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Area Movement, Deck, Bag, and Pool Building

name: Tri-Logie
description:
Abstract game.
There are 49 double-sided pieces on the board, each consisting of 2 pieces glued together. One color is up, the other one is down. The active player replaces one of the pieces with the 50th piece, trying to create a line of exactly three adjacent pieces of the same color. The other player contiunues with the replaced piece. The player who cannot create a correct line, loses the game.

name: Konfusion!
description:
From the instruction sheet:

The object of Konfusion! is to "make it through the day." We've all had one of those days...sometimes they last a week! By moving logically and with planning, one can get through a simple day with ease...Right? Well...at least once in a while. But all days are not that simple -- as one trip around this board will show you. It will be your logic and luck that will get you through one of those KONFUSING days. The first player to reach the end of the day (the finish line space) may earn that coveted three (or five or 52) week vacation AND does win the game of Konfusion.
categories: Card Game, Dice, Humor, Mature / Adult, Party Game
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move, Team-Based Game

name: Age of Space
description:
Age of Space is an economic space colonization "spaceship placement" game.

Age of Space continues the story of "Ryce: Empire of Sand". After exploiting the new energy resource "Ryce" on Mars, the manship is ready for the journey to the stars. You take the role of a space flight nation and your order is to colonize new planets.

The players build spaceships and use them to explore new planets and build colonies on them. Colonies produce raw materials or make further processing of goods (example: water and chemicals is processed to medicine). Goods can have different conditions (piece good, bulk goods, fluid goods). The player have to transport these goods from one colony to another or sell them to the market. There are different ships for the different kinds of goods.

Players can get influence points for money, for delivery of goods, exploring new planets, the most colonies on one planet, the majority of colonies of one kind of good, and for the most cargo area of one kind of good. The player with the most influence points at the end of the game wins.
categories: Civilization, Economic, Industry / Manufacturing, Science Fiction, Space Exploration, Transportation
mechanics: Action Queue, Area Majority / Influence, Pick-up and Deliver, Tile Placement, Trading, Worker Placement

name: Hunted: The Tactical Miniatures Game
description:
Hunted is a tabletop Tactical miniatures game in which your faction fights to survive! Whether it is small skirmishes or flat out war, Hunted can be played with 2 players or as many players as you like.

In Hunted, you control units from one of four Factions, which are portrayed with 28mm scale models:

- United Terran Defence Force, humans who are fighting to survive on an unknown planet.

- SESHIMAI (SEed SHIp Modulator AI, often shortened to MAI), AI control robotics whose corrupted data cores have listed all organic life as needing to be destroyed rather than protected.

- Predators, defending their territory from new and strange beings.

- Herbivores, fending off new predators and old in order to continue to live.

Players build their own armies with models in each faction and build a deck to complement it, then take turns in order to wipe out their opponents models.
Unlike traditional miniature games, there is limited use of dice within the game, with no dice rolls to hit or save your miniatures; instead you rely on your cards.

name: Passport to Adventure
description:
Passport to Adventure is an imaginative play and storytelling board game that develops creativity, critical thinking, active listening, and expressiveness.

Players choose heroes with unique powers and move through a fantasy realm where they must collect treasure cards (or avoid pitfall), used to defeat various monsters through imaginative storytelling. A player (or team) wins when she navigates to the final battle and defeats the boss monster.

name: Tabletoons!
description:
Cartoon is a 3 players simulation boardgame of a cartoonish situation. The players are a dog, a cat and a mouse - each one a pwn moving on the squared-grid map of a house with garden. During the 61-75 turns of the game, the dog will try to put the cat KO and keep order, the mouse witt try to put the cat KO and stay in the kitchen as long as possible, and the cat will try to put both opponents KOas much as possible. Objects can be taken, thrown and broken in the process.

Each turn, each player secretly choose an action: attack, move, take an object, drop or throw an object and so on. Actions are executed in a strict order according to the turn structure.

First Published on Kaos magazine 1.5 (Nexus Editrice, 1994). Available since 2014 as print'n'play by 2 Cents Boardgames.

From the official 2014 presentation:
Dear old Granny says goodbye to her pets, Trusty the dog, and the cat Scamp, and peacefully goes to the grocery store.

She doesn't think of staying away much: 75 turns at most.

Meanwhile, Nibble, the mouse, has decided to pay a visit to the kitchen, thereby causing a ruckus: cat and dog have some old scores to settle ...

A Print & Play boardgame for three players inspired by classic cartoon animations, fast and easy but rigorous as a simulation.

name: Düdle
description:
A game of illustrating ridiculous randomly generated phrases.

The game has four decks of cards separated by parts of speech. Each player draws 5 cards: 1 adjective, 2 nouns, 1 verb, and 1 adverb. These 5 words make the phrase the player will illustrate. All the players keep their words secret while they draw their own phrases. When everyone finishes, the group works together trying to guess the words that each artist had based on their drawings. Each correct word guessed earns the artist two points, while each close, but not exact word earns the artist 1 point. The player with the most points wins!

Since it’s a game about creativity, adapting the game and playing by house rules are encouraged. For instance, younger players may want to only draw 4 cards (skipping the adverb) to adjust the game to fit their level.

While groups of 2-8 players work best, the game can be played alone as a drawing exercise or even in a group of up to 54 players each with their own 5-card phrase!

Game Includes: 54 red Adjective cards, 108 yellow Noun Cards, 54 green Verb cards, 54 blue Adverb cards, 8 small pencils, and a pad a paper. Instructions on box.
categories: Card Game, Educational, Party Game, Word Game

name: Das Berlin-Spiel
description:
This is a simple trivia game played on a map of Berlin. Movement is decided by a die. There are five categories of questions about Berlin, which the players have to answer, if they get on a space marked with a:
A = General knowledge
K = Culture
W = Economic
P = Politics and History
S = Super questions

If the answer is correct, the player may advance as many spaces, as indicated on the card. If the answer is wrong, the player has to move 3 spaces backwards.
On a space marked with an "E" the player has to draw an event card and follow its instructions. The first player to reach the end (Ziel) wins the game.

The game was published 1989, so the game board still features the Berlin Wall between West-Berlin and Ost-Berlin.
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Fädelspiel: Polizei
description:
Little threading experts can choose! Children may use the task cards. They must match the wooden pieces to the illustrations on the cards. The object is to thread the wooden pieces in the correct sequence.

They can also play a tactile game. Children pull the play figures out of the sensing bag, by feeling for the different shapes.

Contents: 1 thread with police station, 1 thread with police car, 1 bank, 2 police officers, 1 police dog, 1 thief, 3 play counters with accessories, 4 templates, 1 tactile bag, set of game instructions.

Part of the Meine erste Spielwelt Stadt series.

name: Bilderlotto Bauernhof Wiesenglück
description:
A simple variant of picture Bingo for young children. Each player is given a board containing four images of farm animals, and the players compete to be the first to acquire four matching tiles.

Publisher's description:

Here, everything revolves around the farm Wiesenglück: large and small animals, children, Paul and Mary and of course the tractor. It takes a little luck, find the animals of his picture board the fastest and win the game. A fun matching game for 1-6 children 2-99 years. With game version for older children. Contents: 24 wooden pieces, 6 picture boards made of cardboard.

name: Sortierspiel Auf Dem Land
description:
Which animal belongs to which stable? Little explorers find out according to the shape of the wooden pieces. Two different games boards and the additional die game ensure variety and long lasting interest, as well as lots of fun. A tremendously fun sorting game for 1-4 animal lovers.

One of the boards is placed over the bottom of the game box (one corner is cut so that it is lined up correctly). The boards have different shaped cutouts that correspond to the shapes of the animal pieces and the shapes on the die (star is wild). Players have to match the corresponding pieces to the different cutouts, which go into different (walled) areas of the game box.

There are several options for play:

(For two players) With the green board in place, give each player a set of the animal pieces, so each player has one of each animal. On their turn, a player rolls the die, and fits the piece shown on the die into the matching hole. When a star is rolled, any piece may be selected. The object is to put all of the pieces into the holes. When the board is lifted, players can see that all pieces are in the correct stable.

(For two players) Place the blue board on the box. Rules are the same as the green board rules, above, except when the board is lifted, the animals are not yet in the right stalls. The second phase begins. The players win if they can sort the animals into the correct stalls.

The components can also be used in more open-ended play:

(For several players and one adult) Only the game box is used, no board is placed on it. The adult tells a story, and the players must do what the story tells them ("The chicken goes to the chicken coop"). The instructions provide ten examples, and more can be created by the adult. For more advanced play, the story can give a sequence of moves ("The cow jumps from the stable to the gardens").

(An adult and a child) The boards and wooden pieces are not used, only the box. Questions are asked about the scenes on the game box.

- Who lives in the garden?
- Where are the two chicks?
- What color are the animals?
- How many beets are in the pigsty? (2)
- How many apples are in the basket? (4)

name: The Capture of Constance
description:
From the introduction:
The Capture of Constance is a set of three linked scenarios specifically designed for Eureka Miniatures' Musketeer figures and rules, ...And One for All! Each scenario is playable in approximately 45-60 minutes, making it possible to conduct a complete mini-campaign in one evening! The scenarios involve the capture and rescue of Constance Bonancieux, the wife of D'Artagnan’s landlord and the object of D'Artagnan's desires.

...Inspired by the 1973 movie The Three Musketeers, based on a novel by Alexander Dumas.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Fighting, Miniatures, Novel-based, Pike and Shot, Wargame
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game, Simulation

name: Teddies of the Caribbean!
description:
Teddies of the Caribbean! Hunt for the Golden Honeypot is a card-driven ruleset designed for Eureka Miniatures 28mm Teddy Bear Pirate figures.

The goal of the game is to grab treasure (either from the island or another player) and escape off the edge of the play area.

name: ABC-Reise
description:
From the publisher's website:

The three-piece puzzle cards show the letters from A to Z each as upper and lower case letters with matching motifs and a corresponding word. Players look for each of the matching combinations. In solo play children learn the world of letters. They can assign the letters to the accompanying illustrations and the matching words. They learn the order of the alphabet when they put together the letter cards correctly.

They can then apply the newly acquired knowledge to the other game ideas in the instructions. Includes a dice game for older children.

An educational game collection for 1 - 4 children aged 4+ years and an adult to help.

name: Depredadores
description: This page does not exist. You can edit this page to create it.
categories: Card Game, Dice, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Print & Play

name: Scendincampo: Corri la tua Campagna Elettorale
description:
Italy has been divided by politics!

As a Candidate to Italy's Premier Minister role, answer to people needs with your Political Line, backed up by caricature twins of Italian politicians, and build up your victory challenging their political strategy on the field, by controlling mass media, or by trying your luck with unconventional methods.

An easy but challenging satiric strategy game for 3 to 6 players with 21 Satiric Characters, a 50x50cm game board plus 140 100% originally illustrated Cards. (Illustration by Manuel Simonetti Arts)
mechanics: Action Queue, Area Majority / Influence, Auction/Bidding, Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Hand Management, Open Drafting, Roll / Spin and Move, Trading, Variable Player Powers

name: Retreat to Harrison's Landing: June 30th to July 1st 1862
description:
The eighteenth battle in the American Civil Wargames in 3D series. The Confederate Army is continuing its attack on the Union army, who are retreating towards the safety of Harrisons Landing. This is the largest set battle to date comprising of three battlefields, White Oak Swamp, Glendale and Malvern Hill. The battle is fought over two consecutive days.

Historically it was the best chance that General Robert E Lee would have to break the Union army. The forces are evenly balanced but the Confederates are facing the largest concentration of artillery that the Civil War would see.

Retreat to Harrisons Landing initially has a time limit of 36 bounds in which the Confederates must attack and gain objective ground, the game also comes with additional play options. The games design allows for a fast, fun and realistic game within a 6-8 hour period of continuous play. The game gives a flavour of the American Civil War period and a simple chain of command solution adds intrigue to the game.

Combat is designed around the three factors that appear on the unit counters, these indicate the Range, Attack and Strength of the represented unit. You don’t even need any dice to play the game since a dice tile system is included with the game, but if you want to roll dice then it’s the simple six sided variety that you will require.

The game board is designed to be used either 2 dimensionally as a straight print and play or 3 dimensionally. The 3D game board gives you a realistic feel to the terrain and shows the tactical dispositions of all the game counters."

- information from Wargame Shop
categories: American Civil War, Print & Play, Wargame

name: Cedar Mountain: August 9th 1862
description:
The nineteenth battle in the American Civil Wargames in 3D series. The Confederate Army is countering an advance through Virginia by the newly formed Union Army of Virginia.

Historically Major General Thomas J “Stonewall” Jackson attacked the centre of the advancing army and caught the Corp of Major General John Pope. Initially Pope was driving the Confederates back until reserves from Major General A P Hill arrived.

Cedar Mountain initially has a time limit of 10 bounds in which the Confederates must attack disperse the Union forces, the game also comes with additional play options. The games design allows for a fast, fun and realistic game within a 2-4 hour period of continuous play. The game gives a flavour of the American Civil War period and a simple chain of command solution adds intrigue to the game.

Combat is designed around the three factors that appear on the unit counters, these indicate the Range, Attack and Strength of the represented unit. You don’t even need any dice to play the game since a dice tile system is included with the game, but if you want to roll dice then it’s the simple six sided variety that you will require.

The game board is designed to be used either 2 dimensionally as a straight print and play or 3 dimensionally. The final 3D game board gives you a realistic feel to the terrain and shows the tactical dispositions of all the game counters."

- information from the Wargame Shop
categories: American Civil War, Print & Play, Wargame

name: Williamsburg: May 5th 1862
description:
1862: Williamsburg (American Civil War in 3D)

Game #11 of 19

"Williamsburg is the eleventh battle in the series and is the first in the Peninsula Campaign of 1862. The Union have encountered the Confederate rear guard on the outskirts of the town of Williamsburg, the Union need a quick, decisive victory.

Combat is designed around the three factors that appear on the unit counters, these indicate the Range, Attack and Strength of the represented unit. You don’t even need any dice to play the game since a dice tile system is included with the game, but if you want to roll dice then it’s the simple six sided variety that you will require.

The game comes with a printable game board that can be constructed 3 dimensionally for an impressive realistic feel. Counters, rules and all playing aids accompany the game including a set of tile dice for those of you without any cube dice." -Wargame Shop
categories: American Civil War, Print & Play, Wargame

name: Beaver Dam Creek: June 26th 1862
description:
1862: Beaver Dam Creek (American Civil War in 3D)

Game 13 of 19.

"Beaver Dam Creek is the thirteenth battle in the series and is the third in our Peninsula Campaign set of 1862. The Confederates are attacking the Union forces on the north side of the Chicahominy River in a hope that they can defeat this much smaller force.

The game comes with a printable game board that can be constructed 3 dimensionally for an impressive realistic feel. Counters, rules and all playing aids accompany the game including a set of tile dice for those of you without any cube dice.

Combat is designed around the three factors that appear on the unit counters, these indicate the Range, Attack and Strength of the represented unit. You don’t even need any dice to play the game since a dice tile system is included with the game, but if you want to roll dice then it’s the simple six sided variety that you will require.

The game board is designed to be used either 2 dimensionally as a straight print and play or 3 dimensionally, this takes a little more time to construct but it is well worth the effort for the impressive game board you get at its completion. The final 3D game board gives you a realistic feel to the terrain and shows the tactical dispositions of all the game counters." - Wargame Shop
categories: American Civil War, Print & Play, Wargame

name: Savage's Station: June 29th 1862
description:
1862: Savage's Station (American Civil War in 3D)

Game #16 of 19

"Savage's Station is the fifteenth battle in the series and is the fifth in our Peninsula Campaign set of 1862. The Confederates are in a position to attack a Union rear guard at Savage's Station.

Combat is designed around the three factors that appear on the unit counters, these indicate the Range, Attack and Strength of the represented unit. You don’t even need any dice to play the game since a dice tile system is included with the game, but if you want to roll dice then it’s the simple six sided variety that you will require.

The game board is designed to be used either 2 dimensionally as a straight print and play or 3 dimensionally, this takes a little more time to construct but it is well worth the effort for the impressive game board you get at its completion. The final 3D game board gives you a realistic feel to the terrain and shows the tactical dispositions of all the game counters." - Wargame Shop
categories: American Civil War, Print & Play, Wargame

name: Berlin-Bagdad
description:
Objective: be the first to reach Bagdad (space 90)
- moving by turns -
Starting in Berlin each player moves forward according to die roll; ending on a marked space follow instructions glued into the lid.

Note:
Likely published mid 1910's;
Cute pewter pawns;
For more historical background see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baghdad_Railway
categories: Children's Game, Dice, Racing, Trains, Travel
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement, Race, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Roulette Rennen
description:
This game can be used for car-, horse- or mortorcycle-races.
The spinner determines which color moves how many spaces.
The first player to complete the track, wins the game.

This game was published before 1945.
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Wir sammeln Kräuter, Pilze, Beeren
description:
Objective: Be the first reaching target space (30); learn more about mushrooms, herbs, berries.
- moving by turns -

Simple 'Roll & Move' game; ending on a marked space (1-30) follow instructions glued into the lid.
categories: Children's Game, Dice, Educational, Environmental, Racing

name: Die Reise in das Himmelreich
description:
Objective: be the first ending upon space '90'
- moving by turns -

Translation: 'journey into the kingdom of heaven'

It is a simple game of racing with lovely illustrations. The main principle is one shared with Snakes and Ladders, but not using a spiral track; virtue is rewarded and vice is punished. Winner gets most of the wager (each player has to pay before starting the game)

Remarks:
Likely published ~ 1920s;
Comparable also with the well known 'Reise in die Ewigkeit' games (journey into eternity) from that period, similar to Die Reise ins Himmelreich
categories: Children's Game, Dice, Fantasy, Racing, Religious

name: Fiction or Diction
description:
Do you really know it all or are you just bluffing?

In Fiction or Diction each player takes a turn to pull a card from the top of the deck. On each card is three obscure words with their definitions. On your turn, you will choose to either read one of the words with the corresponding definition or to make up a word and definition.

The other players then will guess whether the word is a real one from the card (Diction), or a fake one that you made up on the spot (Fiction). If the other players are wrong and you read a word from the card, you will get one point. If the other players are wrong and you made the word up, you get two points. If the other players were right, no points are awarded.

The deck then passes to the next clockwise player. The first player to be awarded 10 points ends the game and wins.
categories: Bluffing, Card Game, Print & Play, Word Game

name: Eroberung Lüttichs
description:
Objective: Be the first reaching target space (75/capture of Lüttich aka Luik/Liège); indoctrination about a glorious war.
- moving by turns -
Simple 'Roll & Move' game; ending on a marked space follow instructions;

Note:
Likely published end 1914/1915 (Liège was captured August 1914);
cute pewter pawns; drawn picture (in the centre of the board) shows Graf von Schlieffen; for more historical data see
Source: Wikipedia, "Battle_of_Liège," available under the CC-BY-SA License.
categories: Children's Game, Dice, Educational, Racing, World War I

name: Das Fackelfeuer-Spiel
description:
This is a project of an 8th grade school class in Altensteig/ black forest/ Germany. The game is about an old tradition in this city: On christmas eve big fires are lit on two hilltops in the city. Torchbearers light their torch on one of the fires and spread out in the darkness to make a torch chain across the city.

The game contains a gameboard, playing cards (people: the torch expert and torch novices, several kinds of wood needed for the torch fire = a tree and a wood base, then the wood that is to be stacked), action cards for the players to select their appropriate actions, 5 playing pieces, a torch point marker, one d6 die for dice duels and one die for the actions (one action, two actions, rainy day, unhappy face = sick torchbearers). Then there is the fire itself considering of a stack, a base and 14 wood pieces (actually from plastic).

Gameplay: Each player gets a pawn, action cards, and 3 people cards and 3 wood cards. The game has two phases: first the fire is prepared: Torch bearers have to be found, the wood has to be gathered. Then the wood is stacked. When 14 stacks have been reached (the point marker or one of the player pawns reaches past 14 wood on the game board) the fire is ready to be lit. There is a final dice throw, and then the winner is the one having advanced the furthest up the game board, meaning the one who stacked the most wood.

For the first phase a fire master is chosen - the first one rolling a 6 with the d6-die. Then each player chooses an action - gathering wood or getting torch bearers. The action die thrown by the fire master determines if an action is successful (no rainy day, no sick persons are rolled) and if successful if a single or double action is possible. If more than two players want the same action they roll the d6 to determine who can have a go.

The fire master title changes clockwise to the next player each time a turn is finished.

In the second phase the players - who have to have at least 3 torch bearer cards, one of them being an expert, first plant the tree, then the wood base, then wood stacks. For this they need to have the appropriate type and amount of wood cards. More than two people wanting to do the same roll it out with a d6. The action die determines if an action is successful (no rain), if torch bearer cards must be given up (sick persons) or an action can even be done twice. For a successful action the player pawn is moved one space up on the game board, for a double action two spaces. The point marker moves up one space up too (but only one even when two actions are made). Once the full stack of 14 is reached, either by a player pawn or indicated by the point marker, the game enters its last phase. To maximize their score each player can roll the d6. The player furthest behind has as many die rolls as are players present (e.g. player in 4th place can roll 4 times). If he/she rolls a 6 he/she can move up 4 spaces, player in 3rd place can roll 3 times and move up 3 spaces when rolling a 6 in these 3 rolls). Then the game ends and the player who is up the furthest is the winner.

Apart from the cards the game contains a 3D-woodstack to visualize the fires progress.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Open Drafting, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Bellum se ipsum alet: Conquest and Devastation
description:
Bellum se ipsum alet - the Board Game is a game about war and devastation during the Thirty Year's War. The players take on the roles of commanders and have to fight not only each others on the battle field but also the devastation that follows the war. Bellum se ipsum alet is a tactical game but unlike many others in the genre, the resources are not unlimited. The players must continuously feed their armies by storming and occupying cities but the cities will continuously fight to free themselves and for each new occupant, there will be less to plunder. Add to this a battle system where the players need to balance between wasting soldiers to win the battle and saving them for the next battle. Each player must thus find a way to make best use of the scarce and diminishing resources at hand to be able to deliver the final blow at the right place at the right time.

Game mechanisms include:

1. Tile laying: You gain influence by simply passing through areas and leaving your influence tiles behind you. However, you must defend your influence not only against your opponents but also against the cities, that eventually will revolt and reclaim the influence.
2. Resource economy: Your army is no better than your economy, its strength is linked to supply from cities and if you lose the cities, you will eventually (but not immediately) lose your army and the war.
3. Hidden bidding: The battle system is a kind of \"hidden bidding\", which does not reward the player with the strongest army but rather the player who throws in just about more soldiers into the battle. The more you spend, the more you lose, and like Pyrrhus, you may find that your victories are so expensive that they will cause you to lose.
4. Changing game board: The more the cities are conquered, the more they are devastated and the less they will contribute to your army. Your army must claim the victory before there is nothing left to feed it with.

Bellum se ipsum alet is the second game in the Nova Suecia series.
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Hexagon Grid, Tile Placement

name: Floh-Express
description:
Objective: be the first with your flea reaching target zone
- moving/acting by turns -

place the parts/spaces of the board randomly forming a race track.

Throw the die and move forward according rolled numbers; use drawn cards to speed up/overtake or handicap other players.

name: Thrift Shop
description:
Each player in the game is a shopper at a Thrift Shop. The players are competing against each other to be the first shopper to save an amount of money predetermined by the group before play begins. An end goal of $25 is the normal amount for a 4 player, 30 minute game.

You save money as a thrifty shopper by rolling the six (6) dice provided. Each side of each die has either a monetary amount ($1, $2, $3, $5 & $10) or a special character ($, a circular arrow, X or Gift Card) on it. Earning money is as simple as rolling the dice and matching like amounts. After any roll, you must add at least one die to the scoring pool (these are the dice you are attempting to match like amounts with). You may stop rolling to score the amount of money shown on the dice once you have at least four (4) like amounts in your scoring pool. You may continue to roll the remaining dice, if you choose. You may also attempt to roll for the straight. A straight is one of each of the five different dollar amounts on the dice. If a player manages to roll a straight without using any “Wild” faces, that player may then choose to score $7.00. Should you not be able to add a die to your scoring pool, or once you have scored, your turn ends and the turn passes to the next player.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Push Your Luck, Set Collection

name: Ecopolitics
description: Ecopolitics is a game containing economy and politics, as indicated by its title. Each player starts with an amount of money, building resources and producting goods. After some turns the players try to change the rules of the game by politics. They can earn some politicians and form a goverment. Then they can introduce new laws which change the rules of the game. The final winner can be the player who will balance his power to politics and economy.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Simulation, Team-Based Game, Trading

name: Scholars of Fortune
description:
In this custom card game, players are adventuring archaeologists trying to remove the most valuable set of items from a seismically unstable cave. The deck contains 54 item cards and 14 seismograph cards. The item cards show an item name, its volume, its weight, and its value. These quantities range from 1 to 5. The seismograph cards show a picture of a seismograph and a number from 1 to 5.

To play, all the cards are shuffled together and the deck is cut into 4 face down piles. Players take turns using action points to uncover cards from the piles and add items to (or remove them from) their backpacks. The backpacks hold a maximum weight of 15 and a maximum volume of 15.

When seismograph cards appear they are put in a separate pile. When the total of the numbers on these cards reaches 21, each player takes one final turn and the game ends.

The winner of the game is the one who, at the end, has the most total value for the cards in his or her backpack.
categories: Card Game, Economic, Exploration, Number, Post-Napoleonic
mechanics: Action Points, Open Drafting, Push Your Luck

name: U-Boot torpediert Geleitzug!
description:
Objective: sink most boats with 5 torpedoes
- acting by turns –

4 ships are positioned at an agreed distance;
An elastic band is stretched and a ‘wooden’ torpedo is loaded; each player has 5 shots to hit as many boats as possible; aim and unleash – after you’ve made 5 shots it’s next player’s turn.

Note:
Likely published early 1940’s
categories: Action / Dexterity, Children's Game, Nautical, World War II

name: Torpedo-Angriff
description:
Objective: be the first player reaching target zone (space 60)
- acting by turns –

Each player rolls the die and steps forward on his/her own racing line.

Ending on a red marked space follow instructions glued into the lid.

Note:
Likely published early 1940’s
categories: Children's Game, Dice, Nautical, Racing, World War II

name: Sonne, Mond und Sterne
description:
Objective: be the first player reaching target zone (space 82)
- acting by turns –

Each player rolls the die and steps forward.

Ending on a marked space follow instructions glued into the lid.

Note:
Likely published ~1900
Cute pewter pawns & drawings

name: Autorennen
description:
Objective: be the first player reaching target zone (space 60)
- acting by turns –

Each player rolls the die and steps forward.

Ending on a marked space follow instructions glued into the lid.

Notes:
Likely published late 1920s
Cute pewter pawns

name: Mittelmeer-Reise
description: The players have to travel from Genua to Elba or Triest (first edition). The movement of the meeples is determined by a die. In some cities, the players gain or lose game coins. The first player who arrives on Elba and the player with the most game coins at the end of the game share the first prize.
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Der Apfelbaum
description:
Objective: place most of your markers upon the board; improve the multiplication up to 100.
- acting by turns –

Each player gets his/her coloured markers/chips and rolls the 4 dice (with numbers up to 10):

Form a square with the 4 dice and multiply either the horizontal, vertical or diagonal numbers:

Both results may be marked with your chips on the board. Achieving a 9, 25, 49 or 81 you have a second turn, a ‘100’ gives you a third turn. If you cannot use numbers you loose that turn, game ends after all numbers are marked.

Note:
Likely published during 1930's

name: Sundhedsspillet
description:
This is an educational health quiz game for children and adults, developed by Danish doctors, with 400 questions about health (200 questions for kids and 200 questions for adults).

The game is made to challange your knowledge about you health, change your opinions and ways and thereby improve your health.

The game board is divided into 100 spaces in five different colours: Yellow, Red, Black, Blye and Green.
Each colour have two corresponding decks of cards; one for Children and one for Adults. Each card contains a question if different categories - and one of them (Black) is about you and your habbits!

If you answer the question correct you will gain an extra roll. Some questions might leave you skip a turn if your answer is not healthy enough!

The winner is the one who first arraives to the finish space (Snakes head)
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Memory, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Der Mohr geht vor
description:
Promotional game -

Collect as many chocolate bonus points as possible
- acting by turns -

Collection of different games with activities like Activity and Memory; for each successfully solved challenge you are going to achieve chocolate bonus points.
categories: Children's Game, Dice, Humor, Party Game, Puzzle
mechanics: Acting, Line Drawing, Open Drafting, Set Collection

name: Big or Clever
description:
A word game in which you gain points for finding synonyms to complicated English words. The opponent draws and reads a word for you and you need to find simple alternatives that match the ones on the other side of that card. The person who gains the most points is the winner.

From the publisher:
"This is a great game for those with extensive vocabularies... Use your knowledge of language semantics to simplify the meaning of ‘big’ words into ‘small’ ones. For example, if the ‘big’ word on the card was countenance, the ‘small’ word could be visage or expression.
So let the battle of the minds commence and it will be clear who is the victor and has the greater understanding of the English Language.
A great little game for airplanes, train or car journeys, or perhaps you could make it some sort of drinking game!"

name: The Last Fajita
description:
A family game for 2-4 players about becoming the head chef in the world famous "Burrito! Burrito!" restaurant.

The world famous Tex-Mex Restaurant “Burrito! Burrito!” is looking for a new head chef. As an up-and-coming chef, this is a huge opportunity for you. However, you are not alone in your quest to become world renowned.
The restaurant owners are running an open competition to find the right chef for the job, and you will have to compete with other chefs, for the position. The task is simple; be the most productive and resourceful chef to complete the last fajita and the job will be yours.

Chefs will compete to be the first to complete 5 finished fajitas. The first chef to fulfill their fifth fajita order is the winner.

name: PIIGS: European Economy in the New Era
description:
Are you tired of seeing on TV the latest data of the Risk premium? Bored of hearing experts macroeconomic data retrospectively? Overwhelmed by high unemployment and social decline? In PIIGS players represent that pipe dream called "markets", whose purpose is to enrich themselves at the cost of eliminating the welfare state of the five countries that make up what some economists call PIIGS: Portugal, Italy, Ireland, Greece and Spain.

The game is played in several rounds, split shifts players who make reservations debt countries can buy and sell it later for a profit. On each turn a new debt issue comes into the world economic circuit, which can be purchased in successive turns, and the price will vary as dictated by the rating agencies and the European Central Bank.

The objective of the game is to buy the largest possible number of companies for which we have to get the maximum amount of money on successive shifts, buying and selling bonds of debt to debt reserves of the countries they last or the bankrupt companies. The player at the end of the game has more companies will be the winner.

name: Christina Regina: The Queen's Path
description:
Christina Regina - the Board Game is a game about politics and intrigues in 17th century Sweden where each player represents a faction with a hidden agenda. The end of their intrigues is the newly appointed queen Christina of Sweden and their means include persuasion, agitation, manipulation and even assassination. This is achieved by carefully steering the queen towards influence tiles bearing their faction colors and away from other influence tiles. At the same time, they must closely monitor the other players' actions to guess their agendas. But beware, if your own agenda is too obvious, you may yourself become the victim of your opponents' intrigues!

Game mechanisms include:

1. Tile laying: Tiles are laid at the start of the game and make every session unique.
2. Asymmetric scoring: There are no "good" or "bad" tiles but they all score differently for different players.
3. Hidden agendas: The players do not know how much the other players score until the very end.
4. Guessing game: Based on how players play, the other players may gain points by guessing their agendas (or lose points by guessing wrong).

Christina Regina is the third game in the Nova Suecia series.

name: Vasa Regalis: The Maiden Voyage
description:
Vasa Regalis: The Maiden Voyage is a game of the building and launching of the Vasa ship. The players take on the roles of shipyard leaders in 17th century Stockholm who have been given a royal order - the building and launching of the greatest battle ship ever seen. But to manage the delivery, they must procure goods, craft them into building material and use them to build the ship. At the same time, they must make a profit by secretly deciding how much to use for the ship and how much to keep for themselves. The players' total contribution determines the fate of the ship. If she is successful, the player who put most aside wins but if she is a disaster, only the player who put most into the ship will be spared the King's wrath. Each player must thus closely monitor the other players' strategies to determine whether to spend or to save. The victory conditions will not be clear until the game is over - but then it is too late to change the strategy.

Game mechanisms include:

1. Role-based: The players choose roles to perform actions, actions that give some players more benefits than others.
2. Economic balance: The players need to balance between the good types (wood, cloth, iron and sculptures) so that they always have something to work with.
3. Ambiguous victory conditions: The victory conditions depend on the sum of the players' actions and will not be clear until the game ends.
4. Guessing game: A player strategy is not visible to the other players and must be deduced from their actions.

Vasa Regalis is the fourth game in the Nova Suecia series.
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Memory, Role Playing, Set Collection, Trading

name: Military Geography
description: Military Geography is a game of strategy similar to the war exercises played out by Admirals and Generals in the defense Department and the United States War College. Player learn about navigations, military strategy, tactical, maneuvering, positioning, networking, and logistics.

name: DD Mau
description:
A fast paced, "in your face card game" or slow down and teach the kids strategy, math and decision making skills. Skip and hit any other player on the table, lay down long runs like in rummy. Go out with big points. Get caught with the Deck Master and you're the dealer. If you've ever liked UNO, Then you'll love DD Mau!

The deck consists of 80 playing cards, 52 of which are numbered 1 - 13 in four colors. The remaining 28 cards are “Power Cards”.

Players get rid of their cards by following the color, matching the number of the card on the discard pile or by playing a “POWER CARD”.

The hand is over when any player gets rid of all the cards in his or her hand. That player SUBTRACTS the total points from the card or cards that player went out with from their base score. All other players ADD the total of the card or cards in their hand and add it to their base score. The game is over when any player's score EXCEEDS 505 points. In the event that a player's score is 500, 501, 502, 503, 504 or 505 then that player's score is reduced to 400 and play resumes.

The winner is the player with the lowest score at the end of the game.

name: Space Racing Game
description:
Space Racing Game is a tactical racing game in which players take control of powerful space ships, facing them against each other. Players race simulated space ships with the hope of crossing the finish line first.

Each ship has its own unique maneuvers and powers.

At start of the game the players will buy ships and components.

Space Racing Game is a tactical game of miniatures, cards and dice which takes place in two phases:
1. Planning
2. Moving

Planning phase: at the same time each Player secretly chooses one maneuver and speed using dial.

After Planning phase, each Player move their ships and use its powers.

In sequential order all Players perform their “Moving phase” (Player initiative).

Moving phase: the player has to use a move template and move their space ship, which was secretly chosen.

Players take penalties if they miss their maneuvers, bump into another ship, are blocked by other ships.
The player with the most game points wins the game.

Space Racing Game has 3 different scenarios (racing types) and each of them has its own set of special rules and victory conditions.
However, the fun does not end with a single race! The game rules include the ability to customize your ships and change ships components types to modify your speed, maneuvers, powers and special abilities.
You should plan your strategy, and complete your mission!
categories: Aviation / Flight, Miniatures, Racing, Science Fiction, Wargame
mechanics: Action Queue, Simultaneous Action Selection, Variable Player Powers

name: Mesa Playing Cards
description:
Mesa is an original deck of whimsical, fantasy-adventure cards that allows for a variety of game-play. The deck consists of 48 cards, 42 Character cards and 6 Object cards.

Each card has a set of three Attributes: Value, Power and Clan. Value Attribute is the general value of the card. Power Attribute is a specific break-down of a character's/object's strength. It is expressed on a 3×3 grid and shows six different categories: Body, Mind, Spirit, Land, Water, and Air. The Clan Attribute shows the cards suit. There are six different Clans and each Clan has its own unique symbol.

Currently, there are 9 different games for the Mesa deck. They are the following: "Playground Wars", "Heroic Dreams", "Revolution", "Great Escape", "Power of Love", "Save the Baby", "Mesa Puzzle", "Tower Building Babel", "Mesa Patterns".

Integrates With:

Mesa Grown-ups Playing Cards

name: Bürgermeisterspiel:  	Werde Bürgermeister in Hannover
description:
Objective: be the first to get the permanent majority of votes for the coming election of the mayor - learn more about the city of Hannover
- moving/acting by turns.

Each player rolls the die, moves according the number, follows instructions of space landed on; buys, if possible and/or (preferable) votes.

"Chance" cards are created with circumstances out of the history of Hannover. Correct answers give economic advantages.

Voting process about the next mayor: Each owned company corresponds to a number of votes. The results of each voting are kept and the final winner is the first player who reaches the target.
categories: Dice, Economic, Educational, Negotiation, Political, Trivia
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Open Drafting, Set Collection, Stock Holding, Trading

name: Bürgermeisterspiel: Werde Bürgermeister in Jena
description:
Objective: be the first to get the permanent majority of votes for the coming election of the mayor - learn more about the city of Jena
- moving/acting by turns.

Each player rolls the die, moves according the number, follows instructions of space landed on; buys, if possible and/or (preferable) votes.

"Chance" cards are created with circumstances out of the history of Jena. Correct answers give economic advantages.

Voting process about the next mayor: Each owned company corresponds to a number of votes. The results of each voting are kept and the final winner is the first player who reaches the target.
categories: Dice, Economic, Educational, Negotiation, Political, Trivia
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Open Drafting, Set Collection, Stock Holding, Trading

name: Bürgermeisterspiel:	Werde Bürgermeister in Itzehoe
description:
Objective: be the first to get the permanent majority of votes for the coming election of the mayor - learn more about the city of Itzehoe
- moving/acting by turns.

Each player rolls the die, moves according the number, follows instructions of space landed on; buys, if possible and/or (preferable) votes.

"Chance" cards are created with circumstances out of the history of Itzehoe. Correct answers give economic advantages.

Voting process about the next mayor: Each owned company corresponds to a number of votes. The results of each voting are kept and the final winner is the first player who reaches the target.
categories: Dice, Economic, Educational, Negotiation, Political, Trivia
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Open Drafting, Set Collection, Stock Holding, Trading

name: Expo
description:
Players take the roll of stall holders at Expo, a comic book and media show, moving around the board collecting resources in order to serve the customers and get their money. The player with the most money at the end of three days is the winner.

Players can move anywhere they choose on the board but the player in last place always moves next, so it is important not to run too far ahead and give other players an advantage as they catch up to you.

name: Das lustige und spannende Zwergenspiel
description:
Objective: be the first capturing an opponent's home base (hort)
- moving by turns -
each player places his/her troops - 4 dwarfs, 1 imp, 1 goblin - upon the home base/coloured spaces; troops can be moved into any direction, green spaces in the centre are save.
Try to reach one of the 2 other home bases with your goblin first: dwarfs & imps can be hit and removed by dwarfs & imps, goblins can't hit anyone, but will be beaten by imps only. If you loose your goblin you loose the game.
mechanics: Player Elimination, Point to Point Movement

name: nanDARK
description:
This is a Print&Play solo game: you are trapped in a maze filled with monsters, with only one laser-gun and two random objects, the goal in the first level is to find the three parts of the sword, and exit.

You can download all you need to play in the file section.

name: Stop: Das Verkehrsspiel für Jung und Alt
description: The players start at the lower right corner of the game map and try to be the first at the train station at the upper right corner. They beginn as pedestrians, but can take the tram or a car along the way, if they pay a certain amount of game coins. Whenever a player gets on a numbered space, he has to consult the game rules and follow the instructions. In the center of the game board, there is a crossroad with a traffic cop. The cop is rotated every turn to block one road or the other.
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Schön ist so ein Ringelspiel
description: The players start on the dots of their color inside the pink ring and have to get to the numbered spaces of their color alongside the pink ring. The direction of movement is indicated by arrows. If a meeple is on the pink ring and gets on an arrow, which points to a yellow, blue, green or red colored ring, the meeples have to take a detour on this ring, before they can return to the pink ring. This way, they may overshoot their destination and have to travel an additional round on the pink ring.
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Patricius
description:
This ancient game was played in the 18th century by noble families in the city of Bern in Switzerland. Although it all but disappeared in the 20th century, it has survived thanks to an enthusiast who was one of the last remaining connoisseurs.

Patricius is some kind of "bingo meets freecell".

In this abstract game, players are trying to form four stacks of numbers starting with 1 and going up to 16. However, the numbered tiles are drawn randomly and players will have to store the numbers in five columns until they are able to place them on a stack.

All players play with the same draw, and when all the tiles have been drawn, whoever has made the highest stacks is the winner.

name: Babbmheimor: Das sächsische Schimpfwortspiel
description:
Memory-style game to build Saxonian-German swearwords out of pairs. Just for the fun of learning or revisiting Saxonian dialect words.

The game plays like memory (unlike memory you don't keep matching pairs - put them back on the table, again). One word is the first half of the full word, one the second (1:1 match). To avoid unclarities, the matching parts have the same color - wrong combinations result in funny new creations, adding to the fun. The cards contain also an explanation what the resulting words actually mean (for those that did not know the word before).

It's mainly a fun party game leading to dicussions about local dialects, but the one finding most (new) matching pairs is the winner.

name: Pixelmon
description:
In Pixelmon, also known as "Prehistoric Pixelmon - The Deckbuilding Game", 2 to 5 players tame, train and battle with pixellated prehistoric monsters in order to win Prizes.

The goal of the game is to win the most prizes after 8 game turns, whereby the first 5 turns are for taming and training your Pixelmon only, whereas in turns 6 to 8 and possibly beyond, players battle each other with their fighting teams of three Pixelmon each. The "last man standing" in a battle will be awarded a prize card and the player with the most prize cards after three battles were fought is declared victor (in case of ties, additional turns will be held until one player emerges victorious).

This game is a deckbuilding game on the lines of Dominion, Thunderstone, Nightfall and others as each player will start out with one Starting Pixelmon and a Starting Deck associated with it. Over the course of the game players will build up and optimize their decks by "learning" (buying from a supply) new attacks which they can use in battle phase to overcome the other player's Pixelmon teams.

The game will be illustrated in glorious retro-style pixel artwork and graphics by the game's designer himself.
categories: Card Game, Fantasy, Fighting, Humor, Prehistoric
mechanics: Commodity Speculation, Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Hand Management, Rock-Paper-Scissors, Variable Phase Order

name: Offnschädl: Das Wiener Schimpfwortspiel
description:
Memory-style game to build Viennese-German swearwords out of pairs. Just for the fun of learning or revisiting Viennese dialect words.

The game plays like memory (unlike memory you don't keep matching pairs - put them back on the table, again). One word is the first half of the full word, one the second (1:1 match). To avoid unclarities, the matching parts have the same color - wrong combinations result in funny new creations, adding to the fun. The cards contain also an explanation what the resulting words actually mean (for those that did not know the word before).

It's mainly a fun party game leading to discussions about local dialects, but the one finding most (new) matching pairs is the winner.

name: Wat mutt, dat mutt: Das Plattdeutsche Weisheitenspiel
description:
Memory-style game to build North-German sayings out of pairs. Just for the fun of learning or revisiting North-German dialect words.

The game plays like memory (unlike memory you don't keep matching pairs - put them back on the table, again). One word is the first half of the full word, one the second (1:1 match). To avoid unclarities, the matching parts have the same color - wrong combinations result in funny new creations, adding to the fun.The cards contain also an explanation what the resulting words actually mean (for those that did not know the word before).

It's mainly a fun party game leading to discussions about local dialects, but the one finding most (new) matching pairs is the winner.

name: Es geht de Mensche wie de Leidt: Das hessische Weisheitenspiel
description:
Memory-style game to build Hessian sayings out of pairs. Just for the fun of learning or revisiting Hessian dialect words.

The game plays like memory (unlike memory you don't keep matching pairs - put them back on the table, again). One word is the first half of the full word, one the second (1:1 match). To avoid unclarities, the matching parts have the same color - wrong combinations result in funny new creations, adding to the fun.The cards contain also an explanation what the resulting words actually mean (for those that did not know the word before).

It's mainly a fun party game leading to discussions about local dialects, but the one finding most (new) matching pairs is the winner.

name: Into the Dragon's Cave
description:
Times are tough for ninjas. Smoke bombs are waaaaay more than you'd think, and jobs are scarce - so both you and this other ninja have to take the almost impossible task of breaking into Tomiko, the Dragon Queen's cave and stealing back the Kyorinrin scroll.

Into the Dragon's Cave is a custom dice game for 2 players, who'll attempt to make sets and earn 60 silver before their opponent. They'll work their way into the cave as far as they think is best and judiciously use smoke bombs to get out of tight spots.

Players will roll custom dice (or a set of standard d6s with conversion table) trying to create sets - and choosing to push their luck if they think they can earn more.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Push Your Luck, Set Collection

name: Mesa Grown-ups Playing Cards
description:
The Mesa Grown-ups card deck is a special version of the Mesa Playing Cards that uses caricatures of real people for the card faces. The deck consists of 48 cards, 42 Character cards and 6 Object cards. Each card has a set of attributes: Value, Power and Clan. The attributes are different than the attributes in the regular Mesa deck.

The Mesa Grown-ups deck can be played independently or with the regular Mesa deck.

There are 9 games that have been created for the Mesa card: "Playground Wars", "Heroic Dreams", "Revolution", "Power of Love", "Save the Baby", "Mesa Puzzled", "Tower Building Babel" and "Mesa Patterned."

"Revolution" game uses both the regular deck and the Mesa Grown-ups deck of cards.

name: Shopping Cart Showdown!
description:
Complete grocery shopping lists in this race for the most groceries you can get into your shopping bag, basket or cart. Be quick to finish them before your opponents steal your groceries! Very fast paced game for everyone 8-80 to enjoy.

There are 52 shopping cards with point values from 1 - 8. 68 grocery cards with matching pictures and point values. 4 Robber cards and 2 \"Buy one - Get one\" coupons. The shopping lists are randomly placed in piles of 3,4,5 in front of the players. The storeroom is setup with 2 of each grocery. Players get 5 cards each and one bag, basket and cart to fill. The bag holds max 3 items, the basket 4 and the cart 5. Match the cards in your hand to the shopping lists and collect the points.

You can move one item between bag, basket or cart once per turn. You can discard one card per turn. Lastly, you can go to the storeroom to make one trade per turn. This works with a equal number trade mechanic.

Fill the shopping lists before your opponents to collect the points!

name: Blankety Blank: Travel
description:
Blankety Blank is based on the UK BBC TV quiz show of the same name first introduced by Terry Wogan in 1977, itself based on the 1970's version of the US Game Show MATCH GAME.

The game involves guessing the missing "blank" in a sentence. The sentence itself often gives an innocuous clue to the blank. Players then compare answers and score points for matching answers.

One player acts as quizmaster and the other players take turns to be a "contestant" and a "panelist." The quizmaster decides who the first contestant is going to be the first question is read out and the contestant and panelists write their answers on the sheet provided.

When everyone has recorded their answer, the contestant reads out his answer first, followed by each panelist in turn. Each time that the answer of the contestant matches that of the panelist the contestant gets a point.

The two contestants with the highest number of points then go on to play the "Super Match Game." In this game there are three possible answers to each question--the answers are worth 50 points, 100 points or 150 points. When a player matches any of these answers, they record the number of points won. The player with the most points at the end of the Super Match is the winner and goes on to the Head to Head game, the last round.

Blankety Blank: Travel allows 3-9 players where the base game allows 3-6, and may be played alone or with the base game.
categories: Movies / TV / Radio theme, Party Game

name: Meet the Missus at the Broadcast
description:
"An exciting radio 'quiz' game for all the family!"

One of a series of games based on an early audience-participation radio show. "Meet the Missus at the Broadcast" (1940) is a parchesi game with quiz questions thrown in. Gameboards were printed on heavy paper and measure 18" square when unfolded. Game instructions printed on the back of the mailing envelope. Fitzpatrick Brothers Inc. (out of Chicago) were the radio show sponsor. Their products included "Kitchen Klenzer Automatic Soap Flakes" and "Big Jack Laundry Soap"
categories: Card Game, Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Trivia

name: Sight Word Spy 1
description:
Sight Word Spy 1 is a fun and challenging game designed to reinforce sight words and develop spelling skills. The game contains 57 of the first 100 sight words children need to learn to become fluent readers. Each card has one sight word that matches with every other card in the deck!

To play the game in a whole group, pass out one card to each student. The other cards are placed around the room. Children travel around the room to find the sight word on each card that matches with one of the words on their card. Children can write the matching words and/or make a tally mark for each match they find as they go around the room. Students can also work with a partner to find the matching words.

When playing in a small group, one card is dealt to each player with remaining cards face up in a pile in the center.The first player to find their match calls out the word and takes that card. The player with the most cards at the end of the game wins!

name: Speed Bump
description:
Start your engines and buckle up! It’s going to be a bumpy and puzzling ride!

ROAD RACE #1
Keep an eye on the shape outlines, your hands on the tiles, and give it some gas! Spin, switch and swap the road sign tiles in front of you to match the sign outlines on the challenge card.

Are your tiles turned correctly? Then, hit the “SPEEEED BUMMMP” buzzer to let the other players know that they’ve just run into a Speed Bump themselves! If your tiles are correct, you win the round!

ROAD RACE #2
Once you’ve mastered the traffic signs – you’re ready to hit the streets! Level 2 requires shifting your brain into high gear. Now, this is the fast track to thinking fun!

Faced with roundabouts, bridges, tunnels, construction zones, ponds, traffic signs, (daisies and one cute frog) – can you use the very limited, partial-shadow outlines to put your tiles into correct formation? And can you do it without letting up on the accelerator?

“SPEEEED BUMMMP!” (Better luck next time. That NASCAR-style drafting - by watching the guy next to you - was not helpful.)

Rev up the excitement and take the corner toward fun interaction! There’s no final lap in sight. Speed Bump sends families cruisin’ for another lap around – and another, and another...

Speed Bump


Two fast-paced racing games in one!
Follow shape and position clues as the road map to your success!
Develops visual-spatial reasoning, fast thinking, and interaction
16 double-sided graphic tiles
50 double-sided challenge cards
Durable plastic components
Buzzer Announcer for every, “SPEEEED BUMMMP!”
Fun for a wide range of ages
Ideal for group play and solitaire play

name: Wanderung durch die Sächsische Schweiz
description:
Objective: collect most of 8 sightseeing items during your trip through the Saxon Switzerland.
- simple 'Roll&Move' game/ moving by turns -
roll the die and move forward; ending on a red/blue/green space follow instructions glued into the lid; ending on a space with a sightseeing item take it with you. Winner is the player with most items.
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Pitt und Sepp.. auf fröhlicher Jagd
description:
Objective:
For players belonging to the 'hunter' group: catch 3 wildlife.
For players belonging to the 'wildlife' group: bring 3 animals to a safe place.

acting by turns (per group)
Depending on no. of participants each player receives 1 or more tasks to fulfill: moving dogs and/or hunter - or moving hares and/or deers.
On a hex-grid board animals start from blue/pink spaces at one side, trying to reach target (red) spaces on the other side, by moving up to 4 spaces.
Hunter and 2 dogs start in the centre of the board; hunter may move up to 4 spaces, too, but on trails only; dogs also, but they may move in other terrain (opening, thicket/wood) 2 spaces only.
Animals are caught if the hunter has unobstructed, straight line view. Dogs can be used to block and/or push back wildlife.

name: Die lustige Autoreise
description:
Objective: be the first reaching target space
- moving by turns -
each player chooses his/her own route (blue/green/red) by turning the spinner (integrated into the board). A '5' let you start. Depending on the space you land on follow instructions (printed next to the space). Black spaces force you to step backwards, target must be reached with a matching number.

note: likely published during 1950s

name: Laß dich nicht erwischen!
description:
In this game, one player plays as the policeman, while the others are thieves.

The policeman attempts to keep the majority of the horses safe. The thieves each try to steal the most horses.

Each turn, a player rolls the die. Each thief moves 4 meeples into direction of the centre of the board, where one policeman is trying protecting horses by catching thieves.

A '5' let you bring in a thief and you may roll again. As long as your meeple/thief stands on a white space it's invisible for the policeman; after your thief has reached the centre (field) he may try to lead one (of totally 8) horses down to your base. Unfortunately horses and thieves must be moved separatly.

A caught thief is out of game, a caught horse will be moved back to the centre. Game ends after all horses are stolen or all thieves are caught.

name: Münchenspiel
description:
Objective: Gain as many bonus (=victory) points as possible
- acting by turns -
Place your meeple upon start area and make up your mind how to travel through Munic (bus, cap...) by drawing (movement) cards and collecting bonus points (photo cards). Depending on how fast you want to pick up points the higher the risc to be stopped or thrown back to start. Depending on the field you land on you may also push back an opponent (who looses all yet not saved bonus points), draw 'event' (=telex) cards ... A special telex-card is going to end the game by a race to an actually drawn area (photo card), granting additional bonus points.

name: Quer durch Sachsen-Anhalt
description:
Objective: Be the first finishing the 'orbit' around Magdeburg
- moving by turns -
Roll the die and move forward; ending on a space with an arrow you must follow that direction next turn; if the space shows a 'Z' (event), 'W' (knowledge) or an 'H' (performance) your right neighbour draws an appropiate card and you have to follow instructions. Finding correct answer or performing well you may make one additional step.
If you meet/hit an opponent's meeple he/she must start again.

name: Finopolis
description:
Players are going through life from baby age to age 80. The years are represented by fields on which the players move, dice-driven.
Each field has a function: Players can speculate with stock, get insurance, etc. Market development is influenced by the players secret bids.
The first player to reach the 80th field ends the game, the richest player wins.

Finopolis was published in cooperation with an insurance portal named avanturo.

name: Cars 2: Spy & Red Light Green Light
description:
Red Light, Green Light is played like "War".

Spy is a matching game.

2 to 4 player card game. All cards are distributed to player into individual piles, face down. The top card of each is turned face up in turn. If it matches the top card of another pile, that pile is placed on top of the active players face up cards, with the turned over card. If not, just the turned over card is placed on top. If you run of a draw pile turn over the face up pile. If you run out of cards entirely you are out of game. Last player left wins.

Each card game is separately packaged inside a larger outer box.
categories: Card Game, Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: High Banks
description:
Roll the dice, send your Crew Chief (pawn) out to answer all questions correctly. Race your car around the High Banks race track avoiding crashes and black flags. Be the first team to cross the finish line on the last lap and collect the most points to be declared the High Banks champion!

Questions are from the first years of stock car racing up through 1993.

name: In Death Ground: Wargames Rules for the Pre-Gunpowder Era, c. 2500 BC to 1300 AD
description:
From the Introduction:

In Death Ground is a set of rules for gaming medium to large scale battles sent in the pre-gunpowder era, or roughly between 2500 BC and 1300 AD…

A great deal in these rules will be familiar to those who have played Ruga-Ruga Publications' previous sets, "Death In the Dark Continent" and "Too Few to Fight, Too Many to Die". We believe that the basic mechanisms produce a game which is simple enough to be enjoyable - and to be played to a finish in a leisurely evening - while retaining as much tactical interest and period flavor as possible.

name: Fairy Tale Assassin League: City of Broken Dreams
description:
Fairy Tale Assassin League is a storytelling card game in which the Wizard of Oz crew have gone to Hollywood in search of stardom. The catch is that only one of them will make it. Who will it be? The over-acting scarecrow, Dorothy, or the Flying Monkeys?

Multiple FTAL decks are available, and they can be combined for a larger scale game.

Due to difficulties this game won't come out in 2014. Hopefully we can get it out next year!

name: Tre Kronor Infernum: Fire to Ashes
description:
Tre Kronor Infernum - the Board Game© is a game about a fight between a castle and a fire. You are in charge of a group of servants and responsible for extinguishing the fire that has broken out in the royal castle of Tre Kronor. Your servants must set up a human chain together with the other players' servants and pass water buckets to each other. You must also save the possessions from the burning inferno but not at the cost of letting a room burn down. How should you prioritize? What if the other players WANT the room to burn down so that they can steal possessions for themselves? What if you want to do it yourself? Beware, if the entire castle burns down, all players lose!
Game mechanism include:

1. Changing game board: The basic game board is fixed but the spread of the fire is unique for every game.
2. Interdependence: The players cooperate to extinguish the fire.
3. Asymmetric scoring: The score from a room depends on whether it is rescued or burns down.
4. Hidden agendas: The players decide whether they want a room to be rescued or burn down.
5. Guessing game: By guessing the other's agenda, a player can benefit from their actions or disrupt their strategies.

Tre Kronor Infernum is the fifth game in the Nova Suecia series.
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Memory, Network and Route Building, Tile Placement
